div0.head: Ο

div1.head: ὀά
div1.sense: woe, woe! Lat. vae! Aesch.

div1.head: ὀαρίζω
div1.sense: to converse or chat with one, c. dat., Il.; ὀαριζέμεναι (Epic inf.) Il.

div1.head: ὀαριστής
div1.sense: a familiar friend, Od.

div1.head: ὀαριστύς
div1.sense: familiar converse, fond discourse, Il., Theocr.:—generally, ἡ γὰρ πολέμου ὀαριστύς such is warʼs intercourse, Il.
as concrete, προμάχων ὀαριστύς the company of out-fighters, Il.

div1.head: ὄαρος
div1.sense: familiar converse, fond discourse, chat, talk, Hhymn., Hes.
a song, lay, ditty, Pind.

div1.head: ὄαρ
div1.sense: a wife, in gen. pl., ὀάρων ἕνεκα σφετεράων Il.; contr. dat. pl., ἀμυνέμεναι ὤρεσσιν Il.

div1.head: Ὄασις
div1.sense: a name of the fertile islets in the Libyan desert, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀβελίσκος
div1.sense: a small spit, Ar., Xen., etc.
a coin stamped with a spit, Plut.
the leg of a compass, Ar.

div1.head: ὀβελός
div1.sense: a spit, Il., Hdt., Attic
ὀβ. λίθινος a pointed square pillar, obelisk, Hdt.
div1.etym: ὀβελός is prob. βέλος with ο prefixed.

div1.head: ὀβολός
div1.sense: an obol, as a weight, = 1/6th part of a δραχμή, worth rather more than three halfpence, Ar.; ἐν δυοῖν ὀβολοῖν θεωρεῖν, as we might say "to sit in the shilling gallery, " Dem.

div1.head: ὀβολοστατέω
div1.sense: to weigh obols: practise petty usury, Luc.

div1.head: ὀβολοστάτης
div1.sense: a weigher of obols, i. e. a petty usurer, Ar.

div1.head: ὀβολοστατική
div1.sense: (sc. τέχνη) , the trade of a petty usurer, usury, Arist.

div1.head: ὄβρια
div1.sense: the young of animals, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ὀβριμοεργός
div1.sense: doing deeds of violence, Il.

div1.head: ὀβριμόθυμος
div1.sense: strong-minded, Hes.

div1.head: ὀβριμοπάτρη
div1.sense: daughter of a mighty sire, Il., Solon., etc.

div1.head: ὄβριμος
div1.sense: strong, mighty, Il.:—neut. as adv., ὄβριμον ἐβρόντησε he thundered mightily, Hes.
div1.etym: From βρι-, βριαρός, with ο prefixed.

div1.head: ὀγδόατος
div1.etym: poetic for ὄγδοος, as τρίτατος for τρίτος
div1.sense: the eighth, Hom.

div1.head: ὀγδοήκοντα
div1.sense: eighty, Lat. octoginta, Thuc., etc.:—Ionic and Doric ὀγδώκοντα, Il., Theocr.

div1.head: ὀγδοηκοντατέσσαρες
div1.sense: eighty-four, NTest.

div1.head: ὀγδοηκοντούτης
div1.sense: eighty years old, Luc.:— Ionic and Doric ὀγδωκοντα-έτης, ες, Solon.

div1.head: ὀγδοηκοστός
div1.sense: eightieth, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ὄγδοος
div1.sense: eighth, Lat. octavus, Hom., etc.

div1.head: ὅ γε
div1.sense: ὅ γε, ἥ γε, τό γε, the demonstr. Pron. ὁ, ἡ, τό, made more emphatic by the addition of γε, like Lat. hicce, haecce, hocce, he, she, it, Hom., Hes., etc.:— γε may be rendered sometimes by indeed or at least, Lat. quidem.
Adverbial usages:
dat. τῇγε, of place, here, on this very spot, Il.
acc. neut. τόγε, on this account, for this very reason, Hom.

div1.head: ὀγκάομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to bray, of the ass, Luc.

div1.head: Ὄγκα
div1.etym: a name of Athena at Thebes, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀγκηρός
div1.sense: bulky, swollen:—metaph. stately, pompous, Xen.; τὸ ὀγκηρόν trouble, Arist.

div1.head: ὀγκητής
div1.sense: a brayer, i. e. an ass. Anth.

div1.head: ὄγκιον
div1.sense: a case for arrows and other implements, Od.

div1.head: ὄγκος
div1.sense: the barb of an arrow, in pl. the barbed points, Il.
div1.etym: From same Root as Lat. uncus.

div1.head: ὄγκος2
div1.sense: bulk, size, mass, Lat. moles, Plat., etc.
a bulk, mass, heap, ὄ. φρυγάνων a heap of fagots, Hdt.; σμικρὸς ὄ. ἐν σμικρῷ κύτει, of a dead manʼs ashes, Soph.; ὅ. γαστρός, of a child in the womb, Eur.
metaph. weight, trouble, Soph.
weight, importance, dignity, pride, and in bad sense self-importance, pretension, Soph., Eur., etc.
div1.etym: From Root !εγκ, in ἐνεγκεῖν to bear.

div1.head: ὀγκόω
div1.sense: to heap up a mound:—Pass., Anth.

metaph. to bring to honour and dignity, exalt, extol, Eur.; ὀγκῶσαι τὸ φρόνημα to puff up oneʼs conceit, Ar.; so in Mid., Ar.:—Pass. to be puffed up, inflated, Eur.: in good sense, to be honoured, Eur.

div1.head: ὀγκύλλομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be puffed up, Ar.

div1.head: ὀγκώδης
div1.sense: swelling, rounded, Xen.
metaph. swollen, inflated, Plat.

div1.head: ὀγκωτός
div1.sense: heaped up, Anth.

div1.head: ὀγμεύω
div1.sense: to move in a straight line, properly of ploughers or mowers; metaph., ὀγμ. στίβον to trail oneʼs weary way, of a lame man, Soph.; ὤγμευον αὐτῷ they were marching in file before him, Xen.

div1.head: ὄγμος
div1.sense: any straight line, a furrow in ploughing, Il.: a swathe in reaping, Il.
metaph. the path of the heavenly bodies, Hhymn.; ὄγμος ὀδόντων a row of teeth, Anth.

div1.head: ὄγχνη
div1.sense: a pear-tree, Od.

div1.head: ὁδαῖος
div1.sense: = ἐνόδιος:—ὁδαῖα, ων, τὰ goods with which a merchant travels, his freight, Od.

div1.head: ὀδάξ
div1.sense: by biting with the teeth, Lat. mordicus, Hom.; ὀδὰξ ἕλον οὖδας they bit the ground, of men in the agonies of death, Il.; so, γαῖαν ὀδὰξ ἑλόντες Eur.; ὀδὰξ ἐν χείλεσι φύντες biting the lips in smothered rage, Od.; διατρώξομαι ὀδὰξ τὸ δίκτυον Ar.

div1.head: ὀδάξω
div1.sense: to feel a biting, stinging pain, feel irritation, Xen.

div1.head: ὁδάω
div1.sense: to export and sell; generally, to sell, Eur.:—Pass. to be carried away and sold, Eur.

div1.head: ὅδε
div1.sense: demonstr. Pron., this, formed by adding the enclit. -δε to the old demonstr. Pron. τό, and declined like it: Epic dat. pl. τοῖσδεσσι, τοῖσδεσσιν and τοῖσδεσι; Ionic τοισίδε:—ὅδε, like οὗτος opp. to ἐκεῖνος, to designate the nearer as opp. to the more remote; but ὅδε is also deictic, i. e. refersto what can be pointed out. This deictic force is more emphat. in the forms ὁδί, ἡδί, etc. [ῑ], which belong to Com. and Oratt., and are never used in Trag.:

of Place, like French voici, to point out what is before one, Ἕκτορος ἥδε γυνή here is the wife of Hector, Il., etc.:—also with Verbs, here, ὅστις ὅδε κρατέει who holds sway here, Il.; ἔγχος μὲν τόδε κεῖται here it lies, Il.:—in Trag., to indicate the entrance of a person on the stage, καὶ μὴν Ἐτεοκλῆς ὅδε χωρεῖ and see here comes . . , Eur.; ὅδʼ εἰμʼ Ὀρέστης here I am—Orestes, Eur.
so also with τίς interrog., τίς ὅδε Ναυσικάᾳ ἕπεται; who is this following her.? Od.
in Trag., ὅδε and ὅδʼ ἀνήρ, emphatic for ἐγώ; so, τῇδε χερί with this hand of mine, Soph.
of Time, to indicate the immediate present, ἥδʼ ἡμέρα Soph., etc.; τοῦδʼ αὐτοῦ λυκάβαντος on this very day, Od.; νυκτὸς τῆσδε in the night just past, Soph.
ἐς τόδε, elliptic c. gen., ἐς τόδʼ ἡμέρας Eur.; ἐς τόδε ἡλικίης Hdt.
in a more general sense, to indicate something before one, οὐκ ἔρανος τάδε γʼ ἐστίν these preparations which I see are not an ἔρανος, Od., ; Ἀπόλλων τάδʼ ἦν this was Apollo, Soph.
to indicate something immediately to come, ταῦτα μὲν Λακεδαιμόνιοι λέγουσι, τάδε δὲ ἐγὼ γράφω Hdt.
Adverbial usage of some cases:
fem. dat. τῇδε , of Place, here, on the spot, Lat. hac, Hom., etc.:—of Way or Manner, thus, Il., Attic
acc. neut. τόδε, hither, to this spot, Hom.; δεῦρο τόδε Hom.
therefore, on this account, Od.; acc. neut. pl., τάδε Od.
neut. dat. pl. τοῖσδε and τοισίδε, in or with these words, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁδεύω
div1.sense: to go, travel, Il., Xen.
Pass. to be provided with thoroughfares, Strab.

div1.head: ὁδηγέω
div1.sense: to lead one upon his way, c. acc. pers., Aesch.; absol. to lead the way, Eur.

div1.head: ὁδηγός
div1.sense: a guide, Plut.

div1.head: ὅδιος
div1.sense: belonging to a way, ὄρνις ὅδ. a bird of omen for the journey (or seen by the way), Aesch.

div1.head: ὅδισμα
div1.sense: a road-way, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁδίτης
div1.sense: a wayfarer, traveller, Od., Soph.; Doric ὁδίτας, Theocr.

div1.head: ὁδοιπλανέω
div1.sense: to stray from the road, wander or roam about, Ar.

div1.head: ὁδοιπλανής
div1.sense: straying from one road into another, wandering about, Anth.

div1.head: ὁδοιπορέω
div1.sense: to travel, walk, Hdt., Soph., etc.; ὁδ. τοὺς τόπους to walk over this ground, Soph.

div1.head: ὁδοιπορία
div1.sense: a journey, way, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὁδοιπόριον
div1.sense: provisions for the voyage, Lat. viaticum, Od.

div1.head: ὁδοιπόρος
div1.sense: a wayfarer, traveller, Aesch., Soph., Ar.;—in Il., a fellow-traveller, or guide.

div1.head: ὀδοντοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing teeth, κόσμος ὀδ. an ornament formed of strings of teeth, Anth.

div1.head: ὀδοντοφυής
div1.sense: sprung from the dragonʼs teeth, Eur.

div1.head: ὁδοποιέω
div1.sense: to make or level a road, Xen.:— Pass., of roads, to be made fit for use, Xen.
metaph. to reduce to a system, τι Arist.
c. dat. pers. to act as pioneer, serve as guide, Xen.:—Pass. to make oneʼs way, advance, Lat. progredi, Plat.

div1.head: ὁδοποίησις
div1.sense: a making of roads:—hence, a pioneering, preparation, Arist.

div1.head: ὁδοποιία
div1.sense: the work of a pioneer, Xen.

div1.head: ὁδοποιός
div1.sense: one who opens the way, a pioneer, Xen.
a road-surveyor, Aeschin.

div1.head: ὁδός
div1.sense: a threshold, Soph., etc.

div1.head: ὁδός2
div1.sense: a way, path, track, road, highway: ποταμοῦ ὁδός the course of a river, Xen.; the path of the heavenly bodies, Eur.
with Preps., πρὸς ὁδοῦ further on the way, forwards, Il. (cf. φροῦδος) :—κατʼ ὁδόν by the way, Hdt.;— ἐκ τῆς ὁδοῦ on his road Hdt.
a travelling, journeying, whether by land or water, a journey or voyage, Hom., etc.:—also an expedition, foray, Il.:—c. gen., τὴν εὐθὺς Ἀργοῦς ὁδόν the way leading straight to Argos, Eur.
metaph. a way or manner, θεσπεσία ὁδός the way or course of divination, Aesch.; ὁδ. μαντικῆς Soph.; λογίων ὁ the way, intent of the oracles, Ar.
a way of doing, speaking, etc., τριφασίας ἄλλας ὁδοὺς λόγων three other ways of telling the story, Hdt.; ὁδὸν ἥντινʼ ἰών by what course of action, Ar., etc.
a way, method, system; ὁδῷ methodically, systematically, Plat.
the Way, i. e. the Christian Faith, NTest.

div1.head: ὁδουρός
div1.sense: a conductor, conductress, Eur.

div1.head: ὀδούς
div1.sense: Lat. dens, dentis, a tooth, Hom., Hes., etc.; ἕρκος ὀδόντων, v. ἕρκος 1; πρίειν ὀδόντας, v. πρίω.

div1.head: ὁδοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a watcher of the roads, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁδόω
div1.sense: to lead by the right way, Aesch.; c. inf., τὸν φρονεῖν βροτοὺς ὁδώσαντα who put mortals on the way to wisdom, Aesch.: of things, to direct, ordain, Eur.:—Pass. to be on the right way, be conducted, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀδυνάω
div1.sense: to cause one pain or suffering, to distress, Eur., etc.:—Pass. to feel pain, suffer pain, Soph., Ar.; ἃ ὠδυνήθην the pains I suffered, Ar.

div1.head: ὀδύνη
div1.sense: pain of body, Lat. dolor, Hom., Attic
pain of mind, grief, distress, Hom., etc.; ὀδύνη τινός grief for him, Il.

div1.head: ὀδυνηρός
div1.sense: painful, Pind., Ar.
painful, distressing, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: ὀδυνήφατος
div1.sense: killing, i. e. stilling, pain, Il.

div1.head: ὄδυρμα
div1.sense: a complaint, wailing, Trag.

div1.head: ὀδυρμός
div1.sense: a complaining, lamentation, Aesch., Eur., etc.

div1.head: ὀδύρομαι
div1.etym: the Trag. use a form δύρομαι when required by the metre.
Dep., mostly in pres. and impf.,
div1.sense: to lament, bewail, mourn for:
c. acc. pers., Hom., Soph.; c. acc. rei, ὁ δʼ ὀδύρετο πατρίδα γαῖαν mourned for it, i. e. for the want of it, Od.; so, νόστον ὀδυρομένη Od.
c. gen. pers. to mourn for, for the sake of, Hom.
c. dat. pers. to wail or lament to or before others, Hom.
absol. to wail, mourn, Hom., Eur.

div1.head: ὀδυρτικός
div1.sense: disposed to complain, querulous, Arist. adv. -κῶς, comp. κωτέρως, Arist.

div1.head: ὀδυρτός
div1.sense: mourned for, lamentable: neut. pl. ὀδυρτά, as adv., painfully, Ar.

div1.head: Ὀδύσσεια
div1.sense: the Odyssey, Arist.

div1.head: Ὀδύσσειος
div1.sense: of Ulysses, Od.

div1.head: Ὀδυσσεύς
div1.sense: Lat. Ulysses, Ulixes, king of Ithaca, whose adventures after the fall of Troy are told in the Odyssey: Epic Ὀδυσεύς, Aeolic gen. Ὀδυσεῦς: acc. Ὀδυσσέᾱ, but the two last syll. form one in Soph. Cf. ὀδύσσομαι.

div1.head: ὀδύσσομαι
div1.etym: Prob. from the Root δυσ- with ο) prefixed.Ὀδυσσεύς is derived from it, v. Od. 19. 407 sq.
Epic verb, only in aor1 Mid.
div1.sense: to be wroth against, to hate another, c. dat., Hom., Hes.

div1.head: ὀδωδή
div1.sense: smell, scent, Anth.

div1.head: ὁδωτός
div1.sense: passable: practicable, Soph.

div1.head: ὀζαλέος
div1.sense: branching, Anth.

div1.head: Ὀζόλαι
div1.sense: the Ozolae, a tribe of the Locrians, perhaps from the strong-smelling sulphur-springs in their country, Strab.

div1.head: ὄζος
div1.sense: a bough, branch, twig, shoot, Il., Hes., etc.
metaph. an offshoot, scion, ὄζος Ἄρηος, of a famous warrior, Il.; so, τὼ Θησείδα ὄζω Ἀθηνῶν Eur.

div1.head: ὀζόστομος
div1.sense: with bad breath, Anth.

div1.head: ὄζω
div1.etym: ὄδωδα pf. with pres. sense and and plqpf. as impf
div1.sense: to smell, whether to smell sweet or to stink, used by Hom. only in 3rd sg. plup.:—c. gen. rei, to smell of a thing, ὄζων τρυγός smelling of wine-lees, Ar.; metaph. to smell or savour of a thing, Lat. sapere aliquid, Κρονίων ὄζων smelling of musty antiquity, Ar.

impers., ὄζει ἀπʼ αὐτῆς ὡσεὶ ἴων there is a smell from it as of violets, Hdt.; ὄζει ἡδὺ τῆς χρόας there is a sweet smell from the skin, Ar.;—so c. dupl. gen., ἱματίων ὀζήσει δεξιότητος there will be an odour of cleverness from your clothes, Hdt.

div1.head: ὅθεν
div1.sense: relat. adv., answering to demonstr. τόθεν and interr. πόθεν, Lat. unde, whence, from which, Hom., etc.:— also from whom, ὅθεν περ αὐτὸς ἐσπάρη from whom himself was born, Soph.
ὅθεν δή from whatever source, in what manner soever, Plat.
= ὅθι, οὗ, ὅπου, where, Il., Soph.
whence, wherefore, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: ὅθι
div1.sense: relat. adv., answering to demonstr. τόθι and interr. πόθι, poet. for οὗ, Lat. ubi, where, Hom., Trag.

div1.head: ὀθνεῖος
div1.sense: strange, foreign, Lat. alienus, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: ὄθομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to care for, take heed, regard, reck, always with a negat., Hom.

div1.head: ὀθόνη
div1.sense: fine linen, in pl., fine linen cloths, Hom.
sails, Anth.: in sg. a sail, Luc.

div1.head: ὀθόνιον
div1.sense: a piece of fine linen:— in pl. linen cloths, bandages, Ar.

div1.head: ὁθούνεκα
div1.etym: for ὅτου ἕνεκα as οὕνεκα for οὗ ἕνεκα
div1.sense: because, Soph.
like οὕνεκα, simply for ὡς or ὅτι, that, Lat. quod, Trag.

div1.head: ὄθριξ
div1.sense: with like hair, Il.

div1.head: Ὄθρυς
div1.sense: Mount Othrys in Thessaly, Hdt.

div1.head: οἰακίζω
div1.sense: to steer, and so to guide, manage, Hdt., Arist.

div1.head: οἰακονόμος
div1.sense: a helmsman: metaph. a pilot, ruler, Aesch.

div1.head: οἰακοστροφέω
div1.sense: to steer, direct, Aesch.

div1.head: οἴαξ
div1.sense: the handle of the rudder, the tiller, and generally, the helm, Aesch., Eur., etc.:— metaph. the helm of government, Aesch.
in Il., οἴηκες are the rings of the yoke, through which pass the reins for guiding the mules.

div1.head: οἰάτης
div1.sense: a villager: Οἰᾶτις, νομός is a pasture in the Attic deme Οἴα, Soph.

div1.head: οἴγω
div1.sense: to open, ὤιξα θύρας Il.: absol., ὦιξε γέροντι he opened the door to the old man, Il.; [οἶνον ὤιξεν ταμίη she broached the wine, Od.; πρὸς φίλους οἴγειν στόμα Aesch.

div1.head: οἰδάνω
div1.sense: to make to swell, Lat. tumefacere, Il.:— Pass. to swell, Lat. tumere, Il.
= οἰδέω, Ar.

div1.head: οἶδα
div1.sense: to know, εὖ οἶδα I know well; εὖ ἴσθι be assured: often c. acc. rei, νοήματα οἶδε, μήδεα οἶδε he is versed in counsels, Hom.; with neut. Adjs., πεπνυμένα, φίλα, ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς Hom.; also c. gen., τόξων εὖ εἰδώς cunning in the use of the bow; οἰωνῶν σάφα εἰδώς Od.: —χάριν εἰδέναι τινί to acknowledge a debt to another, thank him, Il., etc.:—the Imperat. in protestations, ἴστω Ζεὺς αὐτός be Zeus my witness, Il.; Doric ἴττω Ζεύς, ἴττω Ar.: —εἰδώς absol. one who knows, εἰδυίηι πάντʼ ἀγορεύω Il.; ἰδυίηισι πραπίδεσσι with knowing mind, Il.
c. inf. to know how to do, Il., Attic
with the part. to know that so and so is the case, ἴσθι μοι δώσων know that thou wilt give, Aesch.; τὸν Μῆδον ἴσμεν ἐλθόντα Thuc.
οὐκ οἶδα εἰ, I know not whether, expresses disbelief, like Lat. nescio an non, οὐκ οἶδʼ ἂν εἰ πείσαιμι Eur.

οἶδα or ἴσθι are often parenthetic, οἶδʼ ἐγώ Eur.; οἶδʼ ὅτι, οἶσθʼ ὅτι, ἴσθʼ ὅτι, πάρειμι Soph.; so, εὖ οἶδʼ ὅτι Dem.: —in Trag. also, οἶσθʼ ὃ δρᾶσον; equivalent to δρᾶσον — οἶσθʼ ὅ; do— knowʼst thou what? i. e. make haste and do; οἶσθʼ ὡς ποίησον, etc.

div1.head: οἰδέω
div1.sense: to swell, become swollen, Lat. tumere, ὤιδεε δὲ χρόα he had his body swollen, Od.; οἰδεῖν τὰ πόδε to have swollen feet, Ar.
metaph. of inflated style, Ar.; also, οἰδεόντων πρηγμάτων when times were troublous (like tument negotia in Cic.), Hdt.

div1.head: οἴδημα
div1.sense: a swelling, tumour, Dem.

div1.head: Οἰδιπόδειος
div1.sense: of Oedipus, Plut.

div1.head: Οἰδίπους
div1.sense: Oedipus, i. e. the swollen footed (v. Soph. O. T. 718, Eur. Phoen. 25):—gen. Οἰδίποδος, but in Trag. Οἰδίπου (as if from Οἴδιπος) , acc. Οἰδίπουν: voc. Οἰδίπους.

div1.head: οἶδμα
div1.sense: a swelling, swell, οἴδματι θύων raging with swollen waves, Il.; in pl., Soph.:—generally, the sea, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: οἴεος
div1.sense: of or from a sheep, Hdt.

div1.head: οἰέτης
div1.sense: of the same age, Il.

div1.head: ὀΐζυος
div1.sense: sorry, wretched, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀϊζυρός
div1.sense: woful, pitiable, miserable, Hom.; of conditions, toilsome, dreary, Hom.; also sorry, poor, Hdt. [Though Hom. makes ῡ, he forms the comp. and Sup., metri grat., ὀιζυρώτερος, ὀιζυρώτατος, for -ότερος, -ότατος.

div1.head: ὀϊζύς
div1.sense: woe, misery, distress, hardship, suffering, Hom.
div1.etym: ῡ in nom. and acc.; υ in trisyll. cases.

div1.head: ὀϊζύω
div1.sense: to wail, mourn, lament, περὶ κεῖνον ὀΐζυε (imperat.) Il.
c. acc. rei, to suffer, ὀϊζύομεν κακὰ πολλά Il.: absol. to suffer greatly, Od.

div1.head: οἰήϊον
div1.sense: a rudder, helm, Hom.

div1.head: οἴησις
div1.sense: opinion, an opinion, Plat.: self-conceit, Bion.

div1.head: οἰητέος
div1.sense: one must suppose, Arist.

div1.head: οἶις
div1.sense: a sheep, Theocr.

div1.head: οἴκαδε
div1.sense: to oneʼs home, home, homewards, Hom., etc.
= οἴκοι, at home, Xen. οἴκαδις, Doric for οἴκαδε, Ar.

div1.head: οἰκειακός
div1.sense: oneʼs own, Plut.

div1.head: οἰκειοπραγία
div1.sense: a minding oneʼs own affair, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκεῖος
div1.sense: in or of the house, domestic, Hes., etc.; τὰ οἰκεῖα household affairs, property, Lat. res familiaris, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
of persons, of the same family or kin, related, Lat. cognatus, Hdt., Attic; οἱ ἑωυτοῦ οἰκηιότατοι his own nearest kinsmen, Hdt.; κατὰ τὸ οἰκεῖον Ἀτρεῖ because of his relationship to Atreus, Thuc.
friendly, Dem.

of things, belonging to oneʼs house or family, oneʼs own, Aesch., etc.; ἡ οἰκεία (sc. γῆ) , Ionic ἡ οἰκηίη, Hdt.; τὰ οἰκήια oneʼs own property, Hdt.; οἰκεῖοι πόλεμοι wars in oneʼs own country, Thuc.; of corn, home-grown, Thuc.
personal, private, opp. to δημόσιος, κοινός, Theogn., Hdt., Attic; μηδὲν οἰκειοτέρᾳ τῇ ἀπολαύσει with enjoyment not more our own, Thuc.; οἰκεία ξύνεσις mother wit, Thuc.
proper to a thing, fitting, suitable, becoming, Hdt., Dem.
c. dat. rei, belonging to, conformable to the nature of a thing, Plat.
οἰκ. ὄνομα a word in its proper, literal sense, Arist.
the adv. οἰκείως has the same senses as the adj., familiarly, Thuc., Xen.
affectionately, dutifully, Xen.

div1.head: οἰκειότης
div1.sense: kindred, relationship, Hdt., Attic: intimacy, friendliness, kindness, Thuc.:—in pl. friendly relations, Dem.
of words, the proper sense, Plut.

div1.head: οἰκειόω
div1.sense: to make oneʼs own:
to make a person oneʼs friend, Thuc.; so in Mid. to win his favour or affection, conciliate, Hdt.:—Pass. to be made friendly, Thuc.: to be closely united, Plat.
Mid. also, c. acc. rei, to make oneʼs own, claim as oneʼs own, appropriate, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: οἰκείωμα
div1.sense: kindred, relationship, Strab.

div1.head: οἰκείωσις
div1.sense: a taking as oneʼs own, appropriation, Thuc.

div1.head: οἰκετεία
div1.sense: the household, Lat. familia, Strab., Luc.

div1.head: οἰκετεύω
div1.sense: to inhabit, Eur.

div1.head: οἰκέτης
div1.sense: a house-slave, menial, Hdt., Attic; οἱ οἰκέται, Lat. familia, oneʼs household, the women and children, Hdt., Attic; opp. to οἱ δοῦλοι, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκετικός
div1.sense: of or for the menials or household, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: οἰκέτις
div1.sense: fem. of οἰκέτης, Eur.
the mistress of the house, Lat. matrona, Theocr.

div1.head: οἰκεύς
div1.sense: an inmate of oneʼs house, Hom.
a menial, servant, Od., Soph.

div1.head: οἰκέω
div1.sense: trans. to inhabit, occupy, Il., Hdt., Attic:—Pass. to be inhabited, Il., Hdt., etc.; cf. οἰκουμένη.

Pass. to be settled, of those to whom new abodes are assigned, Il.; οἱ ἐν τῆι ἠπείρωι οἰκημένοι those who have been settled, i. e. those who dwell on the mainland, Hdt.; of cities, to be situate, to lie, Hdt.
to manage, direct, govern, like διοικέω, Soph., etc.
intr. to dwell, live, be settled, Hom., etc.; ἔξω τῶν κακῶν οἰκεῖν γλυκύ sweet is it to live free from cares, Soph.
of cities, in a pass. sense, to be settled, be situated, Hdt., Xen.
to conduct oneself or be conducted so and so, σωφρόνως γε οἰκοῦσα πόλις εὖ ἂν οἰκοῖτο a state with habits of self-control would be well governed, Plat.

div1.head: οἴκημα
div1.sense: any inhabited place, a dwellingplace, Pind., Attic: a chamber, and in pl. a house, Hdt.
special senses,
a brothel, Hdt.: a tavern, Isae.
a cage or pen for animals, Hdt.
a temple, fane, chapel, Hdt.
a prison, Dem.
a storeroom, Plat., Dem.
a workshop, Plat.
a story, Lat. tabulatum, Xen.

div1.head: οἰκήσιμος
div1.sense: habitable, Polyb.

div1.head: οἴκησις
div1.sense: the act of dwelling, habitation, Hdt., Attic
management, administration, Plat.
a house, dwelling, residence, Hdt., Soph., etc.; κατασκαφὴς οἴκ. of the grave, Soph.

div1.head: οἰκητήριον
div1.sense: a dwelling-place, habitation, Eur.

div1.head: οἰκητός
div1.sense: inhabited, Soph.

div1.head: οἰκήτωρ
div1.sense: an inhabitant, Hdt., Attic; οἰκ. θεοῦ one who dwells in the temple of the god, Eur.; Ἅιδου οἰκ., of one dead, Soph.
a colonist, Thuc.

div1.head: οἰκιακός
div1.sense: of or belonging to a house, οἱ οἰκ. oneʼs domestics, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκία
div1.sense: a building, house, dwelling, Hdt.
a household, domestic establishment, Plat.; οἰκίας δύο ᾤκει, i. e. he kept two establishments, Dem.
the household, i. e. inmates of the house, Lat. familia, Plat.
the house or family from which one is descended, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: οἰκίδιον
div1.sense: a chamber, Ar.

div1.head: οἰκίζω
div1.sense: c. acc. rei, to found as a colony or new settlement, πόλιν Hdt., Ar., etc.:— Pass., πόλις οἴκισται Hdt.
to people with new settlers, colonise, χώρην Hdt.; νήσους Thuc.:—Mid. ὅπη γῆς πύργον οἰκιούμεθα in what part of the world we shall make ourselves a fenced home, Eur.
c. acc. pers. to remove, transplant, Eur.; metaph., τὸν μὲν ἀφʼ ὑψηλῶν βραχὺν ὤικισεν brought him from high to low estate, Eur.:—Pass. to settle in a place, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: οἰκίον
div1.sense: in form a Dim. of οἶκος: only in pl. like Lat. aedes, a house, dwelling, abode, Hom., Hdt.

div1.head: οἴκισις
div1.sense: a peopling, colonisation, Thuc.

div1.head: οἰκίσκος
div1.sense: a small room, Dem.

div1.head: οἰκιστήρ
div1.etym: poetic for οἰκιστής, Pind., Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: οἰκιστής
div1.sense: a coloniser, founder of a city, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: οἰκογενής
div1.sense: born in the house, homebred, of slaves, Lat. verna, Plat.; of quails, Ar.

div1.head: οἰκοδεσποτέω
div1.sense: to be master of the house, to rule the household, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκοδεσπότης
div1.sense: the master of the house, the good man of the house, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκοδομέω
div1.sense: to build a house: generally, to build, οἰκίαν, γέφυραν, τεῖχος Hdt.:—Mid., οἰκοδομεῖσθαι οἴκημα to build oneself a house, have it built, Hdt.:—Pass. to be built, Hdt.
metaph. to build or found upon, ἔργα ἐπί τι Xen.; οἰκ. τέχνην ἔπεσιν Ar.
metaph., also, to build up, edify, NTest.:—Pass., οἰκοδομηθήσεται εἰς τὸ ἐσθίειν will be emboldened to eat, Ar.

div1.head: οἰκοδόμημα
div1.sense: a building, structure, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: οἰκοδομή
div1.etym: a late form for οἰκοδόμημα, Plut., NTest.

div1.head: οἰκοδόμησις
div1.sense: the act or manner of building, Thuc.
= οἰκοδόμημα, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκοδομητέος
div1.sense: one must build, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκοδομητικός
div1.sense: fitted for building: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) architecture, Luc.

div1.head: οἰκοδομητός
div1.sense: built, Strab.

div1.head: οἰκοδομία
div1.sense: = οἰκοδόμησις, Thuc.
a building, edifice, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκοδομικός
div1.sense: practised or skilful in building, Plat.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the art of building, architecture, Plat.; so, τὰ οἰκοδομικά Plat.

div1.head: οἰκοδόμος
div1.sense: a builder, an architect, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: οἴκοθεν
div1.sense: from oneʼs house, from home, Il., Thuc.; οἴκοθεν οἴκαδε from house to house, proverb. of one who has two homes, Pind.; εὐθὺς οἴκ., i. e. from childhood, Arist.:—often without any sense of motion, τὰ οἴκ. domestic affairs, Eur.; στρατηγοὺς εἵλοντο ἐκ τῶν οἴκ. Xen.
from oneʼs household stores, Il.
from oneʼs own resources, by oneʼs own virtues, by nature, Pind., Eur.
wholly, absolutely, Aeschin.

div1.head: οἴκοθι
div1.sense: at home, Hom.

div1.head: οἴκοι
div1.sense: at home, in the house, Lat. domi, Il., Hes., etc.; τὰ οἴκοι oneʼs domestic affairs, Xen., Plat.; so, ἡ οἴκοι δίαιτα Soph.; ἡ οἴκοι (sc. πόλις) oneʼs own country, Soph.

div1.head: οἰκονομέω
div1.sense: to manage as a house steward, to manage, order, regulate, Soph., Xen.
metaph. of an artist, to treat, handle a subject, Arist., Luc.
intr. to be a house-steward, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκονομία
div1.sense: the management of a household or family, husbandry, thrift, Plat., etc.

div1.head: οἰκονομικός
div1.sense: practised in the management of a household or family, Plat., etc.: hence, thrifty, frugal, economical, Xen.:— ὁ οἰκ. title of a treatise on the duties of domestic life, by Xen.; and τὰ οἰκονομικά, a similar treatise by Arist.: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , domestic economy, Plat., Xen., etc.

div1.head: οἰκονόμος
div1.sense: one who manages a household, Xen., Plat.
generally, a manager, administrator, Arist.: οἱ Καίσαρος οἰκ. the Roman procuratores, Luc.
as fem. a housekeeper, housewife, Aesch.

div1.head: οἰκόπεδον
div1.sense: the site of a house, Xen., Aeschin., etc.
the house itself, a building, Thuc.

div1.head: οἰκοποιός
div1.sense: constituting a house, οἰκ. τροφή the comforts of a house, Soph.

div1.head: οἰκόσιτος
div1.sense: taking oneʼs meals at home, living at oneʼs own expense, unpaid, Menand.

div1.head: οἶκος
div1.sense: a house, abode, dwelling, Hom., Hes., etc.:— acc. οἶκον, οἶκόνδε, οἴκαδε, homeward, home, Od.; κατʼ οἴκους at home, within, Hdt.; κατʼ οἶκον Soph., etc: —ἐπʼ οἴκου ἀποχωρεῖν to go home wards, Thuc., etc.: ἀπʼ οἴκου from home, Thuc.
part of a house, a room, chamber, Od.: pl. οἶκοι for a single house, Lat. aedes, tecta, Od., Attic
the house of a god, a temple, Hdt., Eur.
oneʼs house, household goods, substance, Hom., etc.
a house, household, family, Od., etc.

div1.head: οἰκοτριβής
div1.sense: ruining a family, Critias.

div1.head: οἰκότριψ
div1.sense: a slave born and bred in the house, Dem.

div1.head: οἰκοτύραννος
div1.sense: a domestic tyrant, Anth.

div1.head: οἰκότως
div1.etym: Ionic adv. part. perf. of οἰκώς for ἐοικώς
div1.sense: reasonably, probably, Hdt.

div1.head: οἰκουμένη
div1.sense: ( sc. γῆ) the inhabited world, a term used to designate the Greek world, as opp. to barbarian lands, Hdt., Dem., etc.:—so in Roman times, the Roman world, NTest.: metaph., ἡ οἰκ. ἡ μέλλουσα the world to come, i. e. the kingdom of Christ, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκουμενικός
div1.sense: of or from the whole world (ἡ οἰκουμένη) ; of Eccl. Councils, oecumenical.

div1.head: οἰκουργός
div1.sense: a house-steward, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκουρέω
div1.sense: to watch or keep the house, Aesch., Soph.: generally to keep safe, guard, Ar.
to keep at home, as women, Soph., Plat.
ἕβδομον οἰκ. μῆνα πολιορκοῦντες they idled away seven months in the siege, Plut.

div1.head: οἰκούρημα
div1.sense: the watch or keeping of a house, Eur.; οἰκ. τῶν ξένων οἱ οἰκουροῦντες ξένοι, Soph.
a keeping the house, staying, at home, Eur.
in concrete sense, of persons, οἰκουρήματα φθείρειν to corrupt the stay-at-homes, i. e. the women, Eur.

div1.head: οἰκουρία
div1.sense: housekeeping, the cares of housekeeping, Eur.
a staying at home, of women, Plut.

div1.head: οἰκουρικός
div1.sense: inclined to keep at home: — τὸ -κόν, οἰκουρία, Luc.

div1.head: οἰκούριος
div1.sense: of or for housekeeping: hence οἰκούρια (sc. δῶρα) , τά, wages, reward for keeping the house, Soph.
keeping within doors, ἑταῖραι οἰκόριαι (Doric for οἰκούριαι) female house- mates, Pind.

div1.head: οἰκουρός
div1.sense: watching the house, of a watchdog, Ar.
as Subst., οἰκουρός, ἡ, the mistress of the house, housekeeper, Eur.:—contemptuously of a man, a stay-at-home, opp. to one who goes forth to war, Aesch.; so, δίαιτα οἰκ. Plut.

div1.head: οἰκοφθορέω
div1.sense: to ruin a house, squander oneʼs substance, Plat.:—Pass., aor1 οἰκοφθόρην, perf. οἰκοφθόρημαι, to be ruined, undone, Hdt.

div1.head: οἰκοφθορία
div1.sense: a squandering oneʼs substance, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκοφθόρος
div1.sense: one who ruins a house, a prodigal, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a house-guard, Anth.

div1.head: οἰκτίρω
div1.etym: Pass., only in pres. and impf.
div1.sense: to pity, feel pity for, have pity upon, c. acc., Il., Hdt., Attic:— οἰκτ. τινά τινος to pity one for or because of a thing, Aesch.:—also c. acc. rei, Ar.
c. inf., οἰκτ. νιν λιπεῖν I am sorry to leave her, Soph.

div1.head: οἰκτίζω
div1.sense: to pity, have pity upon, c. acc., Aesch., Soph., etc.:— Mid. in same sense, Eur., Thuc.
in Mid. also, to bewail, lament, Eur.: absol. to express oneʼs pity, Eur.; οἶκτον οἰκτίζεσθαι to utter a wail, Aesch.

div1.head: οἰκτιρμός
div1.sense: pity, compassion, Pind.:—in pl. compassionate feelings, mercies, NTest.

div1.head: οἰκτίρμων
div1.sense: merciful, Theocr., NTest.

div1.head: οἴκτισμα
div1.sense: lamentation, Eur.

div1.head: οἰκτισμός
div1.sense: lamentation, Aesch., Xen., etc.

div1.head: οἴκτιστος
div1.etym: irreg. Sup. of οἰκτρός (cf. αἰσχρός, αἴσχιστος)
div1.sense: most pitiable, lamentable, Hom.:—neut. pl. οἴκτιστα as adv., Od.

div1.head: οἶκτος
div1.sense: pity, compassion, Od., Dht., Attic:—c. gen. objecti, compassion for, οἶκτος τῆς πόλιος Hdt.

div1.head: οἰκτρόγοος
div1.sense: wailing piteously, piteous, Plat.

div1.head: οἰκτρός
div1.sense: pitiable, in piteous plight, Il., Soph., etc.
of things, pitiable, piteous, lamentable, Hdt., Aesch., etc.

in act. sense, piteous, Od., Soph.; οἰκτρᾶς γόον ὄρνιθος, of the nightingale, Soph.;—neut. pl. as regul. adv. οἰκτρῶς, Aesch., Soph. —Besides comp. and Sup. οἰκτρότερος, -τατος, Hom. has an irreg. Sup. οἴκτιστος (q. v.).

div1.head: οἰκτροχοέω
div1.sense: to pour forth piteously, Ar.

div1.head: οἰκωφελής
div1.sense: profitable to a house, γυνὴ οἰκ. a wife whose prudence makes the house thrive, Theocr.

div1.head: οἰκωφελία
div1.sense: profit to a house, housewifery, Od.

div1.head: Ὀϊλεύς
div1.sense: Oi_leus, a Locrian chief, father of Ajax the Less, Il.
div1.etym: The orig. form was ϝῑλεύς, from ϝίλη (ἴλη) , a troop.

div1.head: οἶμα
div1.sense: = ὅρμημα, Lat. impetus, οἶμα λέοντος ἔχων with the spring of a lion, Il.; αἰετοῦ οἴματʼ ἔχων with the swoop of an eagle, Il.

div1.head: οἰμάω
div1.sense: to swoop or pounce upon its prey, of an eagle, Hom.; κίρκος οἴμησε μετὰ τρήρωνα πέλειαν swooped after a dove, Il.
absol. to dart along, Orac. ap. Hdt.

div1.head: οἴμη
div1.sense: =οἶμος: metaph. a song, lay, Od.

div1.head: οἴμοι
div1.sense: exclam. of pain, fright, pity, anger, grief, also of surprise, properly οἴ μοι ah me! woeʼs me! Theogn., Trag.:— οἴμοι is mostly absol., or is used with a nom., οἴμοι ἐγὼ τλάμων, οἴμοι τάλας etc., Soph.;—c. gen. causae, οἴμοι τῶν κακῶν, οἴμοι γέλωτος ah me for my misfortunes, for the laughter, Trag.
div1.etym: The last syll. in οἴμοι may be elided before ὡς.

div1.head: οἶμος
div1.sense: a way, road, path, Hes., Aesch., etc.
a strip of land, tract, country, Σκύθην ἐς οἶμον Aesch.
metaph. the course or strain of song, Hhymn., Pind.

div1.head: οἰμωγή
div1.sense: loud wailing, lamentation, Il., Hdt., Trag., etc.

div1.head: οἴμωγμα
div1.sense: a cry of lamentation, wail, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: οἰμώζω
div1.sense: to wail aloud, lament, Hom., Trag.
in familiar Attic, οἴμωζε is a curse, plague take you, go howl! Lat. abeas in malam rem, Ar.; οἰμώζετε Ar.; οἰμώξεσθʼ ἄρα Ar.; οἰμώζειν λέγω σοι Ar.; so, οὐκ οἰμώξεται; Ar.
trans. to pity, bewail, c. acc., Tyrtae., Trag.: Pass., οἰμωχθείς bewailed, Theogn.; ὠιμωγμένος Eur.

div1.head: οἰμωκτός
div1.sense: pitiable, Ar.

div1.head: οἰνάνθη
div1.sense: the first shoot of the vine: generally, the vine, Eur., Ar.
the soft down of the young vine-leaves, Pind.

div1.head: οἰνάρεον
div1.sense: a vine-leaf, Theocr.

div1.head: οἰναρίζω
div1.sense: to strip off vine-leaves, as is done when the grapes are ripening, Ar.

div1.head: οἰνάριον
div1.sense: weak or bad wine, Dem.

div1.head: οἴναρον
div1.sense: a vine-leaf, Xen.

div1.head: οἰνάς
div1.sense: the vine, Babr.
adj. of wine, vinous Anth.

div1.head: οἴνη
div1.sense: the vine, Hes., Eur.
= οἶνος, wine, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνηρός
div1.sense: of wine, Eur.
containing wine, Hdt., Pind.
of countries, rich in wine, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνήρυσις
div1.sense: a vessel for drawing wine, Ar.

div1.head: οἰνίζω
div1.sense: Mid. to procure wine by barter, buy wine, Il.

div1.head: οἰνοβαρέω
div1.sense: to be heavy with wine, Theogn.

div1.head: οἰνοβαρής
div1.sense: heavy with wine, Lat. vino gravis, Il., Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοβρεχής
div1.sense: wine-soaked, drunken, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοδόκος
div1.sense: holding wine, Pind.

div1.head: οἰνοδότης
div1.sense: giver of wine, of Bacchus, Eur.

div1.head: Οἰνόη
div1.sense: Oenooe, name of an Attic deme, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: οἰνόμελι
div1.sense: honey mixed with wine, mead, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνόπεδος
div1.sense: with soil fit to produce wine, wine-producing, Od.
οἰνόπεδον, ου, τό, as Subst. a vineyard, Il., Theogn.:—also οἰνοπέδη, ἡ, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοπέπαντος
div1.sense: ripe for wine-making, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοπλάνητος
div1.sense: wine-bewildered, Eur.

div1.head: οἰνοπληθής
div1.sense: abounding in wine, Od.

div1.head: οἰνοπλήξ
div1.sense: wine-stricken, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοποτάζω
div1.sense: to drink wine, Hom.

div1.head: οἰνοποτήρ
div1.sense: a wine-drinker, Od.

div1.head: οἶνος
div1.sense: Lat. vinum, wine, Hom., etc.; παρʼ οἴνῳ over oneʼs wine, Lat. inter pocula, Soph.; οἶνος ἐκ κριθῶν barley- wine, a kind of beer, Hdt.

div1.head: οἰνοτρόφος
div1.sense: rearing or bearing wine, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοῦττα
div1.sense: a cake or porridge of wine mixed with barley, water and oil, eaten by rowers, Ar.

div1.head: οἰνοφαγία
div1.sense: meat full of wine, Luc.

div1.head: οἰνοφλυγία
div1.sense: drunkenness, Xen.

div1.head: οἰνόφλυξ
div1.sense: given to drinking, drunken, Xen., etc.

div1.head: οἰνοφόρος
div1.sense: holding wine, Critias; οἰνοφόρον, (sc. σκεῦος) a wine-jar, oenophrus, in Hor.

div1.head: Οἰνόφυτα
div1.sense: a place in Boeotia, Thuc.

div1.head: οἰνόφυτος
div1.sense: planted or grown with vines, Strab.

div1.head: οἰνοχαρής
div1.sense: rejoicing in wine, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοχάρων
div1.sense: wine Charon, nickname of Philip of Macedon, because he put poison in his enemiesʼ wine, and so, sent them over the Styx, Anth.

div1.head: οἰνοχοέω
div1.sense: to pour out wine for drinking, Hom.
c. acc., νέκταρ ἐωινοχόει she was pouring out nectar for wine, Il.

div1.head: οἰνοχόημα
div1.sense: a festival, at which wine is offered, Plut.

div1.head: οἰνοχόη
div1.sense: a can for ladling wine from the mixing bowl (κρατήρ) into the cups, Hes., Eur.

div1.head: οἰνοχόος
div1.sense: a wine-pourer, cupbearer, Hom., etc.

div1.head: οἰνόχυτος
div1.sense: of poured wine, πῶμα οἰν. a draught of wine, Soph.

div1.head: οἶνοψ
div1.sense: wine-coloured, wine-dark (never in nom.), ἐπὶ οἴνοπι πόντῳ Hom.; of oxen, wine-red, Hom.

div1.head: οἰνόω
div1.sense: to intoxicate, οἰνῶσαι σῶμα ποτοῖς Critias.
Pass. οἰνόομαι to get drunk, be drunken, οἰνωθέντες Od.; perf. part., ᾠνωμένος, Ionic οἰνωμένος, Hdt., Soph.

div1.head: οἰνών
div1.sense: a wine-cellar, Xen.

div1.head: οἰνωπός
div1.sense: of a fresh, ruddy complexion, Eur., Theocr.

div1.head: οἰνώψ
div1.sense: generally, dark, Soph.

div1.head: οἰόβατος
div1.sense: lonesome, Anth.

div1.head: οἰοβώτας
div1.sense: feeding alone, of cattle: metaph. of Ajax, φρενὸς οἰοβώτας μονόφρων, Soph.

div1.head: οἰόθεν
div1.sense: from one only, i. e. by oneself, alone, in phrase οἰόθεν οἶος all alone, Il.

div1.head: οἴομαι
div1.sense: to suppose, think, deem, imagine, c. acc. et inf., mostly inf. fut., Hom., etc.

c. inf. alone, when both Verbs have the same subject, as, κιχήσεσθαί σε ὀΐω I think to catch, i. e. I think I shall. . , Il.; οὐ γὰρ ὀΐω πολεμίζειν I do not think, i. e. mean, to fight, Il.; ἐν πρώτοισιν ὀΐω ἔμμεναι I expect to be, Od.
sometimes the subject of the inf. is to be supplied from the context (as in I), τρώσεσθαι ὀΐω I fear [that many] will be wounded, Il.; διωκέμεναι γὰρ ὀΐω I fear [they] are pursuing me, Od.

absol., αἰεὶ ὀΐεαι thou art ever suspecting, Il.: also, to deem, forebode, θυμὸς ὀΐσατό μοι my heart foreboded it, Od.; ὀΐσατο κατὰ θυμόν he had a presage of it in his soul, Od. :—impers., ὀΐεταί μοι ἀνὰ θυμόν there comes a boding into my heart, Od.
trans. to wait for, look for, κεῖνον ὀϊομένη looking for his return, Od.; γόον δʼ ὠίετο θυμός his soul was intent on grief, Od.
used by Hom. parenthetically, in first person, ἐν πρώτοισιν, ὀΐω, κείσεται among the first, I ween, will he be lying, Il.; ἔπειτά γʼ, ὀΐω, γνώσεαι Od.

in Attic this parenthetic use in confined to the contr, form οἶμαι, imperf. ὤιμην, I think, I suppose, I believe; even between a prep. and its case, ἐν οἶμαι πολλοῖς Dem.:—answering a question, expressive of positive certainty, I believe you, of course, no doubt, Ar., etc. ; οἶμαι ἔγωγε yes I think so, yes certainly, Plat.:—also in a parenthetic question, πῶς οἴει; πῶς οἴεσθε; how think you ? like πῶς δοκεῖς; also οἴει; alone, donʼt you think so? what think you? Ar.
οἴομαι δεῖν I hold it necessary, think it my duty, like Fr. je crois devoir, Soph., Plat.

div1.head: οἱονεί
div1.sense: as if, Lat. quasi, tanquamsi, Arist.

div1.head: οἰονόμος
div1.sense: (οἶος) feeding alone: hence, lone, lonely, of places, ἐπʼ οἰονόμοιο (neut.) in solitude, Anth.
(ὄϊς, οἶς) as Subst., a shepherd, Anth.

div1.head: οἱονπερεί
div1.sense: adj. = οἷόν περ εἰ, as it were, Plat.

div1.head: οἷόντε
div1.sense: possible; οὐχ οἷόντε impossible: v. οἷος III. 2.

div1.head: οἰόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be left alone, abandoned, forsaken.
div1.etym: only in 3rd sg. aor1 οἰώθη Il.

div1.head: οἰοπολέω
div1.sense: to tend sheep, to roam the mountains, Eur.:—c. acc. loci, to roam over, Anth.

div1.head: οἰοπόλος
div1.sense: traversed by sheep, Hom.
lonely, solitary, single, Pind.
act. tending sheep, Hhymn.

div1.head: οἰόρπατα
div1.sense: Scyth. for ἀνδρο-κτόνοι, οἰόρ, being = ἀνήρ (vir), Hdt.

div1.head: οἱοσδήποτε
div1.sense: of such and such a kind, Arist.

div1.head: οἶος
div1.sense: alone, lone, lonely, though it can often only be rendered by an adv. alone, only, Hom., Hes.; οἶος ἄνευθʼ ἄλλων Il. ;—with negat., οὐκ οἶος, ἅμα τῷγε. . , not alone, but. . , Il.;—neut., οἶον as adv., Il.
strengthd., εἷς οἶος, μία οἴη one alone, one only, Hom.; in dual, δύο οἴω Hom.; in pl., δύο οἴαι Od.:—rare in Attic

c. gen., οἴη θεῶν alone of the gods, Il.; so, οἴη ἐν ἀθανάτοισιν alone among the goddesses, Il.; οἶος μετὰ τοῖσι Od.; but, οἶος ἀπʼ ἄλλων alone from, apart from, Od.; οἶος Ἀτρειδῶν δίχα, clam Atridis, Soph.
single in its kind, unique, excellent, Il.

div1.head: οἷος
div1.sense: such as, what sort or manner of nature, kind, or temper, Lat. qualis, relat. Pronoun, correlative to the interrog. ποῖος, the indef. ποιός, and the demonstr. τοῖος, Hom., Hes., etc.; strengthd., ὅσσος ἔην οἷός τε, Lat. qualis erat quantusque, Il.: c. acc., οἷος ἀρετήν what a man for virtue, Il.; often only to be rendered by an adv., οἷος μέτεισι πόλεμόνδε how he rushes into war, Il. Usage:

οἷος in an indepent sentence expresses astonishment, strengthd. by δή, οἷον δὴ τὸν μῦθον ἐπεφράσθης ἀγορεῦσαι why, what a word it has come into thy mind to speak! Od.; so in neut., as adv., v. infr. v.
so in indirect sentences, where no antec. can be supplied, ὁρῶν ἐν οἵοις ἐσμέν Xen.

containing a Comparison, often without an antec., οἷος ἀστὴρ εἶσι like as a star wanders, Il.; οἷος καὶ Πάρις ᾔσχυνε like as Paris also dishonoured, Aesch.:—in this sense, οἷος is often attached to the case of its antec., πρὸς ἄνδρας τολμηρούς, οἵους Ἀθηναίους (for οἷοι Ἀθηναῖοι) , Thuc.

οἷος, οἵα, οἷον, esp. in Attic, often stand for ὅτι τοῖος, τοία, τοῖον, so that the relat. introduces the reason for the preceding statement, ἄνακτα χόλος λάβεν, οἷον ἄκουσεν anger seized the king, because of what he heard. Il.

but if the Comparison is general, Hom. uses οἷός τε (which must be distinguished from οἷός τε c. inf., v. infr. III. 2), οἷός τε Ἄρης some such one as Ares, Il.; also, οἷός τις the sort of person who, Hom.
when a Comparison involves Time, οἷος ὅ τε is used, like as when . . , Od.

οἷος is used in many brief Attic phrases, οὐδὲν γὰρ οἷον ἀκούειν αὐτοῦ τοῦ νόμου thereʼs nothing like hearing the words of the law, Dem.; —it adds force to the Sup., χωρίον οἷον χαλεπώτατον, τοιοῦτον οἷόν ἐστι χαλεπώτατον, Xen.

οἷος with inf. implies Fitness or Ability to do, οἷος ἔην τελέσαι ἔργον τε ἔπος τε so ready was he to make good both deed and word, Od.; οἷος ἔην βουλευέμεν ἠδὲ μάχεσθαι so good both at counsel and in fight, Od.; τὸ πρᾶγμα μέγα καὶ μὴ οἷον νεωτέρῳ βουλεύσασθαι the matter is great and not such as for a young man to advise upon, Thuc.; without an inf., ὁ δʼ οἷός ἐστιν οἰκουρὸς μόνον fit only [to be] a house-dog, Ar.

but this sense is commonly expressed by οἷός τε, c. inf., fit or able to do, λέγειν οἷός τε κἀγώ Ar.; οἷός τε ἦν πείθειν Dem.: freq. in neut. sg. and pl., οἷόν τε ἐστί and οἷά τε ἐστί, οἷόν τε γίγνεται it is possible, Hdt., Attic; without inf., οἷόν τε ἐστίν it is possible, οὐχ οἷόν τε ἐστίν it cannot be, Ar.; with a Sup., καλὸν ὡς οἷόν τε μάλιστα as beautiful as is possible, Plat.; ὡς οἷόν τε διὰ βραχυτάτων Plat.

the relat. is in Attic often repeated in the same clause, οἷʼ ἔργα δράσας οἷα λαγχάνει κακά after what deeds what sufferings are his! Soph.; οἵαν ἀνθʼ οἵων θυμάτων χάριν what thanks and for what offerings! Soph.
as adv. in neut., to add force, οἷον ἐερσήεις how fresh, Il.; οἷα ἀτάσθαλα Od.:—the regul. adv. οἵως is seldom used, οἷος ὢν οἵως ἔχεις in what a state art thou for such a man! Soph.
in Comparisons, as, like as, just as, Hom., Trag.; οἷά τις ἀηδών Aesch.;— οἷον ὅτε like as when, cf. II. 4.
as, οἷον τί λέγεις; as for example, what do you mean? Plat.
like ὡς with a partic., οἷα ἀπροσδοκήτου γενομένου inasmuch as it was unexpected, Thuc.
with Numerals, about, οἷον δέκα σταδίους, etc.

div1.head: οἰοχίτων
div1.sense: with only a tunic on, lightly clad, Od.

div1.head: οἴ
div1.sense: exclam. of pain, grief, pity, astonishment, ah! woe! Lat. heu! vae! sometimes with nom., οἲ ʼγώ Soph.; mostly c. dat., v. οἴμοι; c. acc., οἲ ἐμὲ δειλήν Anth.

div1.head: οἷ
div1.sense: relat. adv.
whither, Lat. quo, Trag.; οὐκ ἤκουσας οἷ προβαίνει τὸ πρᾶγμα Ar.:—c. gen., οἷ μʼ ἀτιμίας ἄγεις to what a height of dishonour you lead me, Soph.
with Verbs of rest, οἷ φθίνει τύχα where, i. e. how, in what, it ends, Eur.; so, οἷ κακίας τελευτᾷ in what state of vice he ends, Plat.

div1.head: οἷπερ
div1.sense: whither, Lat. quo, v. οἷ.

div1.head: ὄϊς
div1.sense: Lat. ovis, sheep, both ram and ewe, Hom., etc.; but the gender is sometimes marked by a word added, ὄϊν ἀρνειὸν ῥέζειν θῆλύν τε to sacrifice a male sheep and a female, Od.

div1.head: οἰστέος
div1.sense: to be borne, Soph.
οἰστέον one must bear, Eur.
one must get, κέρδος Soph.

div1.head: ὀϊστευτήρ
div1.sense: an archer, Anth.

div1.head: ὀϊστεύω
div1.sense: to shoot arrows, Hom.: c. gen. to shoot at, ὀϊστευσον Μενελάου Il.

div1.head: ὀϊστοβόλος
div1.sense: arrow-shooting, Anth.

div1.head: ὀϊστοδέγμων
div1.sense: an arrow-holder, a quiver, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀϊστός
div1.sense: an arrow, Hom., Hes., etc.

div1.head: οἰστός
div1.sense: that must be borne, endurable, Thuc.

div1.head: οἰστράω
div1.sense: to sting, properly of the gadfly; then metaph. to sting to madness, αὐτὰς ἐκ δόμων οἴστρησα I drave them raging out of the house, Eur.:—Pass., οἰστρηθείς driven mad, Soph.
intr. like Pass. to be driven by the gadfly, driven mad, οἰστρήσασα in frenzy, frantically, Aesch.; of Menelaus, Eur.; ἡ ψυχὴ οἰστρᾶι Plat.

div1.head: οἰστρήλατος
div1.sense: driven by a gadfly, Aesch.

div1.head: οἴστρημα
div1.sense: the smart of a gadflyʼs sting: metaph. frenzy, Soph.

div1.head: οἰστροβολέω
div1.sense: to strike as with a sting, Anth.

div1.head: οἰστροδίνητος
div1.sense: driven round and round by the gadfly, Aesch.

div1.head: οἰστροπλήξ
div1.sense: stung by a gadfly, driven wild, Trag.

div1.head: οἶστρος
div1.sense: the gadfly, breese, Lat. asilus, an insect which infests cattle, Od., Aesch.
metaph. a sting, anything that drives mad, Eur.: absol. the smart of pain, agony, Soph.
mad desire, insane passion, Hdt., Eur., etc.:—generally, madness, frenzy, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: οἰσύα
div1.sense: a tree of the osier kind.

div1.head: οἰσύϊνος
div1.sense: of osier, of wicker-work, Od., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: οἰσύπη
div1.sense: the grease extracted from sheepʼs wool, Hdt.

div1.head: οἰσυπηρός
div1.sense: with the grease in it, greasy, Ar.

div1.head: Οἰταῖος
div1.sense: of Oeta, Soph., etc.; οἱ Οἰταῖοι the men of Oeta, Thuc.

div1.head: Οἴτη
div1.sense: Mount Oeta in Thessaly, Strab.

div1.head: οἶτος
div1.sense: fate, doom, Hom., Soph., Eur.

div1.head: Οἰχαλία
div1.sense: name of a city in Thessaly, Il.

div1.head: Οἰχαλιεύς
div1.sense: an Oechalian, Il.

div1.head: Οἰχαλίηθεν
div1.sense: from Oechalia, Il.

div1.head: οἰχνέω
div1.etym: only in pres. and Ionic imperf. οἴχνεσκον
div1.sense: to go, come, Od.; to walk, i. e. to live, Soph.
like οἴχομαι, to be gone, Soph.
c. acc. pers., like προσέρχομαι, to approach, Pind.

div1.head: οἴχομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to be gone, to have gone, Lat. abesse (not abire), in perf. sense, and imperf. ὠιχόμην in plup. sense, directly opp. to ἥκω, to have come, while ἔρχομαι, to go or come, serves as the pres. to both, Hom., etc.;—often c. part., οἴχεται φεύγων is fled and gone, Il.; ὤιχετʼ ἀποπτάμενος he hath taken flight and gone, Il.; οἴχεται θανών (v. infr. II. 1); also with an adj., οἴχεται φροῦδος heʼs clean gone, Ar.:—c. acc. pers. to have escaped from, Il.
Special usages,

euphem. for θνῄσκω, to be gone hence, οἴχεται εἰς Ἀΐδαο Il.; in Attic, οἴχεται θανών Soph., etc.:—part. οἰχόμενος for θανών, departed, dead, Trag.; but in Hom. simply absent or away, Ὀδυσῆος πόθος οἰχομένοιο desire of the absent Ulysses, Od.
to be undone, ruined, Soph.; esp. in ὤιχωκα or οἴχωκα, Lat. perii, Aesch., etc.
of things, to denote any quick, violent motion, to rush, sweep along, Il.

div1.head: οἰωνίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep.
to take omens from the flight and cries of birds, Lat. augurium, capere, Xen.
generally, to divine from omens, augur, c. acc. et inf., Xen.

div1.head: οἰώνισμα
div1.sense: divination by the flight or cries of birds, Lat. augurium, Eur.

div1.head: οἰωνιστήριον
div1.sense: a place for watching the flight of birds:—an omen or token, Xen.

div1.head: οἰωνιστής
div1.sense: one who foretells from the flight and cries of birds, an augur, Il., Hes.

div1.head: οἰωνιστικός
div1.sense: of or for an omen: ἡ -κή (sc.τέχνη) , augury, Plat.

div1.head: οἰωνόθροος
div1.sense: of the cry of birds, οἰ. γόος the wailing cry of birds, Aesch.

div1.head: οἰωνοκτόνος
div1.sense: killing birds, Aesch.

div1.head: οἰωνόμαντις
div1.sense: one who takes omens from the flight and cries of birds, an augur, Eur.

div1.head: οἰωνοπόλος
div1.sense: one busied with the flight and cries of birds, an augur, Il., etc.

div1.head: οἰωνοσκοπέω
div1.sense: to watch the flight of birds, to take auguries, Eur.

div1.head: οἰωνός
div1.sense: a large bird, bird of prey, such as a vulture or eagle, and so distinguished from a common bird (ὄρνις) , Hom., etc.
a bird of omen or augury, Hom., etc.:—the flight to (not from) the right, i. e. towards the East, was fortunate, and vice versa.

an omen, presage, drawn from these birds, Lat. auspicium or augurium, according as taken from seeing their flight or hearing their cry, Il., etc.; δέκομαι τὸν οἰωνόν I accept the omen, hail it as favourable, Hdt.
div1.etym: commonly deriv. from οἶος, most birds of prey being solitary, — cf. κοινωνός from κοινός

div1.head: ὀκέλλω
div1.sense: a nautical word, used,
trans. of the seamen, to run [a ship] aground or on shore, Hdt., Thuc.
intr. of the ship, to run aground, Thuc., Xen.; so, metaph., Ar.

div1.head: ὀκλαδίας
div1.sense: a folding-chair, camp-stool, Ar.

div1.head: ὀκλαδιστί
div1.sense: squatting, of a frog, Babr.

div1.head: ὀκλάζω
div1.sense: to crouch down on oneʼs hams, to squat, Xen.: ἐς γόνυ ὀκλάσας δέχεται τῇ σαρίσσῃ τὴν ἐπέλασιν, of a soldier waiting an attack, Luc.; of a weary traveller, Soph.:—c. acc., ὀκλ. τὰ ὀπίσθια, τοὺς προσθίους to bend their hind or fore legs, Xen.

div1.head: ὀκνέω
div1.sense: to shrink from doing, to scruple, hesitate to do a thing, c. inf., Il., etc.; ὀκνῶ προδότης καλεῖσθαι I shrink from being called, fear to be called, Soph.; ὀκνῶ ὀνομάσαι I shrink from naming, hesitate to name, Dem.; rarely c. acc., ὃν ὀκνεῖτε Soph.; ὀκνεῖν περί τινος Xen.
absol. to shrink, hesitate, hang back, Hdt., Soph., etc.

div1.head: ὀκνηρός
div1.sense: shrinking, hesitating, backward, unready, timid, Pind.; ὀκνηρὸς ἐς τὰ πολεμικά Thuc.:—adv. -ρῶς, Xen., etc.
of things, causing fear, vexatious, troublesome, Soph.

div1.head: ὄκνος
div1.sense: shrinking, hesitation, unreadiness, sluggishness, Il., Aesch.; ὄκνος καὶ μέλλησις Thuc.
alarm, fear, Aesch., Soph.
c. gen., τοῦ πόνου οὐκ ὄκνος ἐστί I grudge not labour, Soph.
c. inf., παρέσχεν ὄκνον μὴ ἐλθεῖν made them hesitate to go, Thuc.; ὄκνος ἦν ἀνίστασθαι Xen.

div1.head: ὀκριάομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be made rough or jagged: metaph. to be exasperated, πανθυμαδὸν ὀκριόωντο Od.

div1.head: ὀκρίβας
div1.sense: a kind of tribune on the stage, from which the actors declaimed, Plat.

div1.head: ὀκριόεις
div1.sense: having many points or roughnesses, rugged, jagged, Il., Aesch.

div1.head: ὄκρις
div1.sense: like ἄκρις, ἄκρα, a jagged point or prominence.
as adj. ὀκρίς, ίδος, ὀκριόεις, rugged, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀκρυόεις
div1.sense: chilling, horrible, Il.

div1.head: ὀκτάβλωμος
div1.sense: consisting of eight pieces, Hes.

div1.head: ὀκτάδραχμος
div1.sense: weighing or worth eight drachmae, Anth.

div1.head: ὀκταήμερος
div1.sense: on the eighth day, NTest.

div1.head: ὀκτάκις
div1.sense: adv. eight times, Luc.

div1.head: ὀκτακισχίλιοι
div1.sense: eight thousand, Hdt., Xen.; in sg., ἵππος ὀκτακισχιλίη "8000 horse, " Hdt.

div1.head: ὀκτάκνημος
div1.sense: eight-spoked, Il.

div1.head: ὀκτακόσιοι
div1.sense: eight hundred, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀκτάμηνος
div1.sense: eight months old, Xen.

div1.head: ὀκταπλάσιος
div1.sense: eightfold, Lat. octuplus, Ar.

div1.head: ὀκταπόδης
div1.sense: eight feet long, Hes.

div1.head: ὀκτάπους
div1.sense: eight-footed, Batr., Anth.

div1.head: ὀκτάρριζος
div1.sense: with eight roots: of a stagʼs horns, with eight points, Anth.

div1.head: ὀκτάρρυμος
div1.sense: of chariots, with eight poles, i. e. drawn by eight pairs of oxen abreast, Xen.

div1.head: ὀκτάτονος
div1.sense: eight-stretched, ἕλικες ὀκτ. the eight arms of the cuttlefish, Anth.

div1.head: ὀκτωκαιδεκάδραχμος
div1.sense: weighing or worth 18 drachmae, Dem.

div1.head: ὀκτωκαίδεκα
div1.sense: eighteen, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὀκτωκαιδέκατος
div1.sense: eighteenth: ὀκτωκαιδεκάτῃ (sc. ἡμέρᾳ) on the eighteenth day, Od.

div1.head: ὀκτωκαιδεκέτης
div1.sense: eighteen years old, Dem., Theocr.:—fem. έτις, ιδος, Luc.

div1.head: ὀκτώ
div1.sense: Lat. octo, eight, Hom., etc.

div1.head: ὀκτώπους
div1.sense: eight feet long, broad or high, Plat.

div1.head: ὁλάω
div1.etym: a lisping way of pronouncing ὁράω, Ar.

div1.head: ὀλβίζω
div1.sense: to make happy, Eur.:— to deem or pronounce happy, Aesch., Soph., etc.:—Pass. to be or be deemed happy, perf. part. ὠλβισμένοι Eur.; aor1 part. ὀλβισθείς Eur.

div1.head: ὀλβιοδαίμων
div1.sense: of blessed lot, Il.

div1.head: ὀλβιόδωρος
div1.sense: bestowing bliss, Eur.

div1.head: ὀλβιοεργός
div1.sense: making happy, Anth.

div1.head: ὄλβιος
div1.sense: of persons, happy, blest, in Hom., always in reference to worldly goods, wealth, like Lat. beatus, Hom., etc.

of things, in neut. pl., θεοὶ δέ τοι ὄλβια δοῖεν may they give thee rich gifts, Od.; neut. pl. as adv., ὄλβια ζωέμεναι to live happily, Od.:—adv. -ίως, Soph.; Sup. ὀλβιώτατος Hdt.; in later Poets, ὄλβιστος.

div1.head: ὀλβοδότης
div1.sense: giver of bliss, of good or wealth, like ὀλβιοδώτης, Eur.

div1.head: ὄλβος
div1.sense: happiness, bliss, weal, wealth, Hom., etc.

div1.head: ὀλβοφόρος
div1.sense: bringing bliss or wealth, Eur.

div1.head: ὀλέθριος
div1.sense: destructive, deadly, ὀλ. ἦμαρ the day of destruction, Il.; ψῆφος ὀλεθρία a vote of death, Aesch.:— ὀλέθριον as adv. fatally, Soph.
c. gen., γάμοι ὀλέθριοι φίλων bringing ruin on his friends, Aesch.
of persons, ruined, lost, undone, Soph.:— rascally, worthless, Luc.

div1.head: ὄλεθρος
div1.sense: ruin, destruction, death, Hom., Trag., etc.; ὀλέθρου πείρατα, Like θανάτου τέλος, the consummation of death, Il.:— οὐκ εἰς ὄλεθρον; as an imprecation, ruin seize thee! Soph.:— χρημάτων ὀλέθρῳ by loss of money, Thuc.; ἐπʼ ὀλέθρῳ Plat.
like Lat. pernicies and pestis, that which causes destruction, a pest, plague, curse, Hes.; of persons, Hdt.; so Oedipus calls himself τὸν ὄλεθρον μέγαν Soph.; ὄλ. Μακεδών, of Philip, Dem., etc.

div1.head: ὀλέκω
div1.sense: Epic imperf. ὄλεκον, Ionic ὀλέκεσκον, like ὄλλυμι, to ruin, destroy, kill, Hom., Trag.:—Pass. to perish, die, esp. a violent death, ὀλέκοντο δὲ λαοί Il.

div1.head: ὀλεσήνωρ
div1.sense: man-destroying, Theogn.

div1.head: ὀλεσίθηρ
div1.sense: beast-slaying, Eur.

div1.head: ὀλεσσιτύραννος
div1.sense: destroying tyrants, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλετήρ
div1.sense: a destroyer, murderer, Il.:— fem. ὀλέτειρα, Babr., Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγάκις
div1.sense: but few times, seldom, Eur., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ὀλιγάμπελος
div1.sense: scant of vines, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγανδρέω
div1.sense: to be scant of men, Plut., etc.

div1.head: ὀλιγανδρία
div1.sense: scantiness of men, Strab.

div1.head: ὀλιγανθρωπία
div1.sense: scantiness of men, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: ὀλιγάνθρωπος
div1.sense: scant of men, Xen.

div1.head: ὀλιγαριστία
div1.sense: a scanty meal, Plut.

div1.head: ὀλιγαρκής
div1.sense: contented with little, Luc.

div1.head: ὀλιγαρχέω
div1.sense: to be member of an oligarchy, Arist.:—Pass. to be governed by the few, be under an oligarchy, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: ὀλιγαρχία
div1.sense: an oligarchy, government in the hands of a few families or persons, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: ὀλιγαρχικός
div1.sense: oligarchical, of, for or like oligarchy, ὀλ. κόσμος Thuc., Arist.:—adv. -χῶς, Plat., Dem.
of persons, inclined to oligarchy, Plat.

div1.head: ὀλιγαῦλαξ
div1.sense: having little arable land, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγαχόθεν
div1.sense: from some few parts, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀλιγαχοῦ
div1.sense: in few places, Plat.

div1.head: ὀλιγηπελέων
div1.sense: having little power, in feeble case, powerless, Od.

div1.head: ὀλιγηπελής
div1.sense: weak, powerless, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγηπελία
div1.sense: weakness, faintness, Od.

div1.head: ὀλιγηροσίη
div1.sense: want of arable land, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγησίπυος
div1.sense: with little corn, or with a small bread-basket, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγογονία
div1.sense: production of few at a birth, Plat.

div1.head: ὀλιγόγονος
div1.sense: producing few at a birth, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀλιγοδρανέω
div1.etym: , part. ὀλιγοδρανέων with no pres. in use
div1.sense: able to do little, feeble, powerless, Il.

div1.head: ὀλιγοδρανής
div1.sense: of little might, feeble, Ar.

div1.head: ὀλιγοδρανία
div1.sense: weakness, feebleness, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀλιγοετία
div1.sense: fewness of years, youth, Xen.

div1.head: ὀλιγόξυλος
div1.sense: with little wood, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγόπιστος
div1.sense: of little faith, NTest.

div1.head: ὀλιγόσαρκος
div1.sense: with little flesh, Luc.

div1.head: ὀλιγοσιτία
div1.sense: small eating, moderation in food, Arist.

div1.head: ὀλίγος
div1.sense: of Number or Quantity, few, little, scanty, small, opp. to πολύς, Hom., etc.; the governing body in Oligarchies was called οἱ ὀλίγοι, Thuc., etc.
c. inf. too few to do a thing, Hdt., Thuc.
of Size, little, small, opp. to μέγας, Hom.; ὀλίγον ἢ οὐδέν little or nothing, Plat.

neut. ὀλίγον as adv., little, a little, slightly, Hom., Eur.; with comp. Adjs., ὀλίγον προγενέστερος Il.; ὀλ. ἧσσον Od.; so, ὀλ. τι πρότερον Hdt.; but ὀλίγῳ is more common with the comp. in Prose, Hdt., etc.
special phrases:
ὀλίγου δεῖν almost, ὀλίγοῦ ἐδέησε καταλαβεῖν wanted but little of overtaking, Hdt.:—hence ὀλίγου alone, all but, almost, Od., Attic; ὀλίγου ἐς χιλίους hard upon 1000, Thuc.
διʼ ὀλίγου (sc. χώρου) at a short distance, Aesch., etc.: also, διʼ ὀλίγου (sc. χρόνου) at short notice, suddenly, Thuc.:— διʼ ὀλίγων in few words, Plat.
ἐν ὀλίγῳ (sc. χώρῳ) in a small space, within small compass, Thuc.:—also, ἐν ὀλίγῳ (sc. χρόνῳ) in a short time, suddenly, Plat., NTest.
ἐν ὀλίγοις one among few, i. e. exceedingly, remarkably, Hdt.
ἐξ ὀλίγου διʼ ὀλίγου, of Time, Thuc.
ἐς ὀλίγον within a little, Thuc.
κατʼ ὀλίγον by little and little, Thuc.; but the adj. often takes the gender and number of its Subst., κατʼ ὀλίγους few at a time, in small parties, Hdt., Thuc.
μετʼ ὀλίγον τούτων shortly after these things, Xen.
παρʼ ὀλίγον within a little, almost, Eur.:—but, παρʼ ὀλ. ποιεῖσθαι to hold of small account, Xen.
the adv. ὀλίγως is rare, οὐκ ὀλίγως Anth.
Comparison:
the comp. is commonly supplied by μείων, ἥσσων or ἐλάσσων· the form ὀλίζων, ονος, is rare.
Sup. ὀλίγιστος, η, ον, Il., Attic:— ὀλίγιστον or τὸ ὀλ., as adv., Lat. minime, Plat.; ὡς ὀλίγιστα Plat.

div1.head: ὀλιγοστιχία
div1.sense: the consisting of few lines, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλιγοστός
div1.sense: one out of a few, opp. to πολλοστός, Plut.
ὀλ. χρόνον for the smallest space of Time, Soph.

div1.head: ὀλιγότης
div1.sense: of Number, fewness, Plat.
of Amount, smallness, scantiness:—of Time, shortness, Plat.

div1.head: ὀλιγοφιλία
div1.sense: fewness of friends, Arist.

div1.head: ὀλιγοχρόνιος
div1.sense: lasting or living but little time, of short duration, Theogn., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὀλιγόψυχος
div1.sense: faint-hearted, NTest.

div1.head: ὀλιγωρέω
div1.sense: to esteem little or lightly, make small account of, c. gen., Xen., Plat.:—absol. to take no heed, Thuc.:—Pass., perf. ὠλιγώρημαι, to be lightly esteemed, Dem.

div1.head: ὀλιγωρία
div1.sense: an esteeming lightly, slighting, contempt, Hdt., Thuc., etc.
negligence, ap. Dem.

div1.head: ὀλίγωρος
div1.sense: little-caring, lightly-esteeming, scornful, contemptuous, Hdt., Dem.:—adv., ὀλιγώρως ἔχειν to be careless, negligent, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: ὀλισθάνω
div1.sense: to slip, slip and fall, Il.; ἐξ ἀντύγων ὤλισθε he slipped from the chariot, Soph.:—metaph. to make a slip, Ar.
to slip or glide along, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀλισθήεις
div1.sense: slippery, Lat. lubricus, Pind., Xen.
of persons, slippery, hard to catch and keep hold of, Plat., Anth.
liable to slip, Plut.

div1.head: ὄλισθος
div1.sense: slipperiness, Luc.
= a slip, Luc.

div1.head: ὁλκάς
div1.sense: a ship which is towed, a ship of burthen, trading vessel, merchantman, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁλκή
div1.sense: a drawing, dragging, tugging: a drawing on or towards a thing, attraction, force of attraction, Plat.

div1.head: ὁλκίον
div1.sense: a bowl or basin, Plut.

div1.head: ὁλκός
div1.sense: drawing to oneself, attractive, Plat.

div1.head: ὁλκός2
div1.sense: as an Instrument, a machine for hauling ships on land, a hauling-engine, Hdt., Thuc.
a strap, rein, Soph.
as an Effect, a furrow, Lat. sulcus, ὁλκὸς τοῦ ξύλου the furrow made by the wood, Xen.
periphr., ὁλκοὶ δάφνης drawings of laurels, i. e. laurel-boughs (or brooms made of them) drawn along, Eur.

div1.head: ὄλλυμι
div1.sense: Act. = Lat. perdo,
to destroy, make an end of, Hom., Trag.:—also of doing away with evil, ὤλεσεν νόσον Aesch.
to lose, θυμόν, ψυχήν, μένος, ἦτορ ὀλέσαι to lose life, Hom.; πόνον ὀλέσαντες having lost their labour, Aesch.
Mid., = Lat. pereo,

to perish, come to an end, Hom.; also c. acc. cogn., κακὸν οἶτον, κακὸν μόρον ὀλέσθαι to die by an evil death, Il.:— ὄλοιο, ὄλοισθε mayʼst thou, may ye, perish! an imprecation, Trag.; so, ὀλοίμην, ὄλοιτο, ὄλοιντο, Soph.
to be ruined, undone, Hom., Attic
of things, to be lost, Hom.
perf. ὄλωλα, in sense of Mid., to have perished, to be undone, ruined, Il., Aesch., etc.; τῶν ὀλωλότων of the dead, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁλμοποιός
div1.sense: a maker of mortars, Arist.

div1.head: ὅλμος
div1.sense: a round smooth stone, a roller, Il.
any round body: a mortar, Hes., Hdt.: a kneading-trough, Ar.

div1.head: ὀλοθρευτής
div1.sense: a destroyer, NTest.

div1.head: ὀλοθρεύω
div1.sense: to destroy utterly, NTest.

div1.head: ὀλοιός
div1.etym: an Epic form of ὀλοός, Il.

div1.head: ὀλοίτροχος
div1.sense: a rolling stone, a round stone, such as besieged people rolled down upon their assailants, Hdt., Xen.; ὀλοοίτροχος in Il. and Orac. ap. Hdt.
as adj., πέτροι ὁλοίτροχοι round stones, to which the muscles of an athleteʼs arm are compared, Theocr.

div1.head: ὁλοκαυτέω
div1.sense: to bring a burnt-offering, to offer whole, Xen.

div1.head: ὁλοκαύτωμα
div1.sense: a whole burnt-offering, holocaust, NTest.

div1.head: ὁλοκληρία
div1.sense: completeness or soundness in all its parts, NTest.

div1.head: ὁλόκληρος
div1.sense: complete in all parts, entire, perfect, Lat. integer, Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὀλολυγή
div1.sense: any loud cry, mostly of a joyous kind (unlike Lat. ululatus), used by women invoking a god, Il., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὀλόλυγμα
div1.sense: a loud cry, mostly of joy, Eur.

div1.head: ὀλολυγμός
div1.sense: a loud crying, mostly a joyous cry, in honour of the gods, Aesch., Eur.;—rarely of lamentation, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀλολυγών
div1.sense: an unknown animal, named from its note: prob. a kind of owl, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀλολύζω
div1.sense: to cry to the gods with a loud voice, cry aloud, of women crying aloud to the gods in prayer or thanksgiving, Od., Hhymn. Apoll.; so also in Aesch., Eur., etc.

div1.head: ὅλος
div1.sense: whole, entire, complete, Lat. integer, οὖλος ἄρτος a whole loaf, Od.; ὅλην πόλιν a whole city, Eur.; ὅλους βοῦς Ar., etc.;— πόλεις ὅλαι are whole, entire cities, opp. to ὅλη ἡ πόλις, the whole city, the city as a whole, Plat.:—with the Art. it may either precede or follow the Subst., τῆς ἡμέρας ὅλης the whole day, διʼ ὅλης τῆς νυκτός through the whole night, Xen., etc.
whole, i. e. safe and sound, Plat.
entire, utter, ὅλον ἁμάρτημα an utter blunder, Xen.; of a person, ὅλος εἶναι πρός τινι Lat. totus in illis, Dem.

neut. as adv., ὅλον or τὸ ὅλον, wholly, entirely, Plat.; ὅλῳ καὶ παντί Plat., etc.; τῷ ὅλῳ καὶ παντί Plat.;— so, κατὰ ὅλον on the whole, generally, Plat.; διʼ ὅλου, καθʼ ὅλου (v. sub διόλου, καθόλου) .
as Subst., τὸ ὅλον the universe, Plat.
τὰ ὅλα, oneʼs all, Dem.; τοῖς ὅλοις ὅλως, altogether, Philipp. ap. Dem.
adv. ὅλως, wholly, altogether, Plat., etc.
on the whole, speaking generally, in short, in a word, Like ἑνὶ λόγῳ, Lat. denique, Dem.
often with a neg., οὐχ ὅλως not at all, Plat., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὀλοός
div1.sense: destroying, destructive, fatal, deadly, murderous, Hom., Hes., Aesch., Eur.:— ὀλοὰ φρονεῖν to be bent on ill, design ill, Il.:—comp. ὀλοώτερος Il.; Sup. ὀλοώτατος (used as fem.) Od.
in pass. sense, lost, dead, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀλοόφρων
div1.sense: meaning mischief, baleful, Il.:—in Od. always of crafty, shrewd, men, not Greeks; such men being regarded as baneful.

div1.head: ὁλοπόρφυρος
div1.sense: all-purple, Xen.

div1.head: ὀλόπτω
div1.sense: to pluck out, tear out, Anth.

div1.head: ὀλός
div1.sense: mud, muddy liquor, Anth.

div1.head: ὁλοσφύρατος
div1.sense: made of solid beaten metal, Anth.

div1.head: ὁλοσχέρεια
div1.sense: a general survey or estimate, Strab.

div1.head: ὁλοσχερής
div1.sense: whole, entire, complete, Lat. integer, Theocr.
relating to the whole, important, considerable, Polyb.:—adv. -ρῶς, entirely, utterly, Polyb.

div1.head: ὁλόσχοινος
div1.sense: a coarse rush, used in wicker-work: —hence the proverb, ἀπορράπτειν τὸ φιλίππου στόμα ὁλοσχοίνῳ ἀβρόχῳ to stop Philipʼs mouth with an unsoaked rush, (for rushes were soaked to make them tough), i. e. without any trouble, Aeschin.

div1.head: ὀλοφυδνός
div1.sense: of lamentation, lamenting, Hom.: —ὀλοφυδνά, as adv., Anth.

div1.head: ὀλοφυρμός
div1.sense: lamentation, Ar., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ὀλοφύρομαι
div1.sense: intr. to lament, wail, moan, weep, Hom., etc.
to lament or mourn for the ills of others, to feel pity, Hom.: c. gen. to have pity upon one, Il.
to beg with tears and lamentations, καί μοι δὸς τὴν χεῖρʼ, ὀλοφύρομαι Il.
c. inf., πῶς ὀλοφύρεαι ἄλκιμος εἶναι; why lament that thou must be brave? Od.
c. acc. to lament over, bewail, Od., Hdt., Attic
to pity, Hom.

div1.head: ὀλόφυρσις
div1.sense: ὀλοφύρσεις τῶν ἀπογιγνομένων lamentations for the departed, Thuc.

div1.head: ὀλοφυρτικός
div1.sense: querulous, Arist.

div1.head: ὀλοφώϊος
div1.sense: Epic adj. destructive, deadly, pernicious, Od.; ὀλοφώια εἰδώς versed in pernicious arts, Od.
div1.etym: From !ολ, the Root of ὄλλυμι: the term. -φώιος has not been explained.

div1.head: ὄλπη
div1.sense: a leathern oil-flask, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπίαζε
div1.sense: to Olympia, Thuc.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπιακός
div1.sense: Olympian, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπία
div1.sense: Ὀλυμπία (sc. χώρα) , Olympia, a district of Elis round the city of Pisa, where the Olympic games were held, Hdt., etc.; or the city Pisa itself, Pind. Οὐλυμπία, Pind.

div1.head: Ὀλύμπια
div1.sense: Ὀλύμπια (sc. ἱερά) the Olympic games, in honour of Olympian Zeus, established by Hercules in 776 B. C., and renewed by Iphitus, and held at intervals of four years at Olympia, Hdt.; Ὀλ. ἀναιρεῖν, νικᾶν to win at the Olympic games, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπίασι
div1.sense: at Olympia, Ar., etc.; cf. θύρᾱσι.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπιάς
div1.sense: Olympian as epith. of the Muses, Il., Hes.; of the Graces, Ar.
Ὀλ. ἐλαία the olive-crown of the Olympic games, Pind.
as Subst.,
the Olympic games, Hdt., Pind.
(sub. νίκη) , a victory at Olympia, Hdt.

an Olympiad, i. e. the space of four years between the celebrations of the Olympic games; used as an historical date from about 300 B. C. The 1st Olympiad began 776 B. C.; the 293rd and last in 393 A. D.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπιεῖον
div1.sense: the temple of Olympian Zeus, Thuc., Plat.;—wrongly written Ὀλύμπιον.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπικός
div1.sense: of Olympus, Hdt.
of Olympia, Olympic, ὁ Ὀλ. ἀγών the Olympic games, Ar.

div1.head: Ὀλυμπιονίκης
div1.sense: a conqueror in the Olympic games, Pind.
as adj., Ὀλ. ὕμνος Pind.

div1.head: Ὀλύμπιος
div1.sense: Olympian, of Olympus, dwelling on Olympus, Hom., etc.; Zeus is called simple Ὀλύμπιος in Hom.; Ζεὺς πατὴρ Ὀλ. Soph.; ὁ Ζεὺς ὁ Ὀλ. Thuc.

div1.head: Ὄλυμπόνδε
div1.sense: to Olympus, Hom., etc.

div1.head: Ὄλυμπος
div1.sense: Olympus, a mountain on the Macedonian frontier of Thessaly.—Hom. makes it the seat of the gods, but distinguished from heaven (οὐρανός).
the name was common to several other mountains, each apparently the highest in its own district, in Mysia, Hdt.; in Laconia, Polyb., etc.

div1.head: Ὀλυνθιακός
div1.sense: of or relating to Olynthus (in Chalcidice), Dem.

div1.head: ὄλυνθος
div1.sense: a winter-fig which seldom ripens, an untimely fig, Lat. grossus, Hdt.

div1.head: ὄλυρα
div1.sense: mostly in pl. ὄλυραι, a kind of grain, spelt or rye, Il., Hdt.; cf. ζειά.

div1.head: ὁμαδέω
div1.sense: to make a noise or din, of a number of people speaking at once, Od.

div1.head: ὅμαδος
div1.sense: a noise, din, made by a number of people speaking together, Hom., Eur.; of a tempest, Il.
a noisy throng, Il.

div1.head: ὁμαίμιος
div1.sense: related by blood, Pind.

div1.head: ὅμαιμος
div1.sense: of the same blood, related by blood, Lat. consanguineus, Hdt., Aesch.; φόνος ὅμ. murder by one near of kin, Aesch.
as Subst., ὅμαιμος, a brother or sister, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: ὁμαιμοσύνη
div1.sense: blood-relationship, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμαίμων
div1.sense: = ὅμαιμος, Hdt., Aesch.: — ὁμαιμονέστερος more near akin, Soph.
as Subst. a brother or sister, Soph.
= ὁμόγνιος (II), Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμαιχμία
div1.sense: union for battle, a defensive alliance, league, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ὅμαιχμος
div1.sense: a fellow-fighter, an ally, Thuc.

div1.head: ὁμαλής
div1.sense: level, τὰ ὁμαλῆ level ground, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμαλίζω
div1.sense: to make even or level, Xen.
to level, equalise, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμαλός
div1.sense: of a surface, even, level, Od., etc.; ἐν τῷ ὁμαλῷ on level ground, Thuc.; ὁμαλώτατον Thuc.
of circumstances, on a level, equal, ὁμαλὸς ὁ γάμος marriage with an equal, Aesch.; ὁμαλοὶ ἔρωτες Theocr.; ἀλλάλοις ὁμαλοί on a level with one another, equal, Theocr.
of the average sort, ὁμ. στρατιώτης an ordinary sort of soldier, Theocr.
adv. ὁμαλῶς, evenly, ὁμ. βαίνειν to march in an even line, Thuc.; ὁμ. προϊέναι Xen.
of all alike, Plut.

div1.head: ὁμαλότης
div1.sense: evenness of surface, Arist.; a level, Arist.
equality, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: ὁμαρτέω
div1.sense: to meet,
in hostile sense, to meet in fight, τὼ δʼ ἄρʼ ὁμαρτήτην Il.
to go together, βῆσαν ὁμαρτήσαντες they walked together, Od.; οὐδέ κεν ἵρηξ κίρκος ὁμαρτήσειε could not keep pace with the ship, Od.
c. dat. to walk beside, accompany, attend, τινί Hes., Trag.:—also, to pursue, chase, Aesch.
of things, to attend, Aesch.
in Mid. c. acc. to go after or attack jointly, Il. Hence

div1.head: ὁμαρτῇ
div1.sense: together, Eur.
ὁμάρτη, Doric for ὁμάρτει, imperat. of ὁμαρτέω.

div1.head: ὅμασπις
div1.sense: a fellow-soldier, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμαῦλαξ
div1.sense: with adjoining lands, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμαυλία
div1.sense: a dwelling together, σύζυγοι ὁμ. wedded unions, Aesch.

div1.head: ὅμαυλος
div1.sense: sounding together or in concert, Soph.

div1.head: ὀμβρέω
div1.sense: to rain, μετοπωρινὸν ὀμβρήσαντος Ζηνός when Zeus sends the autumn rains, Hes.
trans. to bedew, Anth.

div1.head: ὄμβριος
div1.sense: rainy, of rain, ὕδωρ ὄμβριον rain water, Hdt.; ὀμβρία χάλαζα Soph.; νέφος Ar.

div1.head: ὀμβροδόκος
div1.sense: receiving rain, Anth.

div1.head: ὀμβροκτύπος
div1.sense: sounding with rain, Aesch.

div1.head: ὄμβρος
div1.sense: Lat. imber, a storm of rain, a thunderstorm, Il., Hdt.: heavy rain, Hdt., Soph., etc.
generally, water, Soph.
metaph. a shower of tears, blood, etc., Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: ὀμβροφόρος
div1.sense: rain-bringing, Lat. imbrifer, Aesch., Ar.

div1.head: ὅμευνος
div1.sense: a partner of the bed, consort, both of the man and woman, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμέψιος
div1.sense: playing together, a playmate, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμηγερής
div1.sense: assembled, ὁμηγερέεσσι θεοῖσι (Epic dat. pl.) Il.

div1.head: ὁμηγυρίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to assemble, call together, Od.

div1.head: ὁμήγυρις
div1.sense: an assembly, meeting, company, Il., Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ὁμηλικία
div1.sense: sameness of age, esp. of young persons; and as a collective, those of the same age, oneʼs friends, comrades, Hom., Theogn.
addressed to a female, = ὁμῆλιξ, ὁμηλικίη δέ μοι αὐτῷ but thou art of the same age with myself, Od.

div1.head: ὁμῆλιξ
div1.sense: of the same age, mostly of young persons, Od., Hdt., etc.
as Subst. an equal in age, comrade, Lat. aequalis, Od., Eur.
of like stature, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμηρεία
div1.sense: a giving of hostages or securities a security, Lat. vadimonium, Thuc.

div1.head: Ὁμήρειον
div1.sense: a temple of Homer, Strab.

div1.head: Ὁμήρειος
div1.sense: Homeric, Hdt.: τὸ Ὁμ. the Homeric phrase, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμήρευμα
div1.sense: a hostage, pledge, Plut.

div1.head: ὁμηρεύω
div1.sense: to be or serve as a hostage, Aeschin.
trans. to give as a hostage, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμηρέω
div1.sense: to meet, Od.
metaph. to accord, agree, φωνῇ ὁμηρεῦσαι (Ionic for ὁμηροῦσαι, part. pl. fem.) Hes.

div1.head: Ὁμηρίδαι
div1.sense: pl., the Homerids, a family or guild of poets in Chios, who traced their descent from Homer and recited his poems, Pind.:—generally, the imitators or the admirers of Homer, Plat.

div1.head: Ὁμηρικός
div1.sense: Homeric, in Homeric manner, Plat.

div1.head: Ὅμηρος
div1.sense: Homer; the name first occurs in a Fragm. of Hes.

div1.head: ὅμηρος
div1.sense: a pledge for the maintenance of unity, a surety, a hostage, Hdt., Attic
of things, a pledge, security, τὴν γῆν ὅμηρον ἔχειν Thuc.

div1.head: ο
div1.sense: Ο, ο, ὂ μικρόν, little or short o, as opp. to ὂ μέγα great or long o, i. e. double o (for ω was orig. written , i. e. oo) : fifteenth letter in the Greek alphabet: as numeral οʹ 70, but ͵ο 70,000. In early times ο represents both ο and ω; and in many words must have sounded like ου, as in βόλομαι for βούλομαι; while reversely, in Ionic μοῦνος νοῦσος κοῦρος οὔνομα stand for μόνος νόσος κόρος ὄνομα. Dialect. changes: Aeolic for α, as στροτός for στρατός;— for ε, Ἐρχόμενος for Ὀρχόμενος (Boeot.);—for υ, as ὄνυμα στύμα for ὄνομα στόμα.
Doric often into οι, ἀγνοιέω πτοιέω πνοιά for ἀγνοέω ἀλοάω πτοέω.
like α, ο is often rejected or prefixed for euphony, as κέλλω ὀκέλλω, δύρομαι ὀδύρομαι.
in compd. Adjectives, ο is changed metri grat. into η, θεογενής ξιφοφόρος into θεηγενής ξιφηφόρος.

div1.head: ὁμιλαδόν
div1.sense: in groups or bands, in crowds, Lat. turmatim, Il.

div1.head: ὁμιλέω
div1.sense: to be in company with, consort with others, c. dat. pl., Od., Attic; also, ὁμ. μετὰ Τρώεσσιν Il.; ἐνὶ πρώτοισιν ὁμιλεῖ is in company with the foremost, Il.
absol. to join in company, Od.; περὶ νεκρὸν ὁμ. to throng about the corpse, Hom.
in hostile sense, to join battle with, ὁμιλέομεν Δαναοῖσιν Hom.:—absol. to join battle, Il.

of social intercourse, to hold converse with, consort with, associate with others, c. dat., Hdt., Aesch.; ἀλλήλοις, μετʼ ἀλλήλων, πρὸς ἀλλήλους Plat.:—of scholars, ὁμ. τινι to frequent a teacherʼs lectures, be his pupil, Xen.
absol. to be friends, Hdt.
of marriage, Soph., Xen.

of things or business which one has to do with, to attend to, busy oneself with, ὁμιλεῖν πολέμῳ Thuc.; πράγμασι καινοῖς Ar.; φιλοσοφίᾳ Plat.:—then, much like χρῆσθαι, νομίζειν, Lat. uti, ὁμ. τύχαις to be in good fortune, Pind.; εὐτυχίᾳ ὁμιλεῖν Eur.; ἐκτὸς ὁμιλεῖ (sc. τῶν ὀργῶν) , i. e. wanders from his right mind, Soph.
of the things themselves, πλαγίαις φρένεσσιν ὄλβος οὐ . . ὁμ. does not consort with a crooked mind, Pind.; κυλίκων νεῖμεν ἐμοὶ τέρψιν ὁμιλεῖν gave me the delight of cups to keep me company, Soph.
to deal with a man, ταῦτα ἡ ἐμὴ νεότης ἐς τὴν Πελοποννησίων δύναμιν ὡμίλησε thus hath my youth wrought by intercourse with the power, Thuc.
of place, to come into, be in, visit, c. dat., Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμίλημα
div1.sense: intercourse, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμιλητής
div1.sense: a disciple, scholar, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμιλητός
div1.sense: with whom one may consort, οὐχ ὁμιλητός unapproachable, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμιλία
div1.sense: a being together, communion, intercourse, converse, company, Lat. commercium, Aesch., etc.:— ὁμ. τινός communion or intercourse with one, Hdt.; πρός τινα Soph., etc.; τοὺς ἀξίους δὲ τῆς ἐμῆς ὁμιλίας those who are worthy of my society, Ar.; ὁμ. χθονός intercourse with a country, Eur.; πολιτεία καὶ ὁμ. public and private life, Thuc.:—also in pl., Ἑλληνικαὶ ὁμιλίαι association with Greeks, Hdt.; αἱ συγγενεῖς ὁμιλίαι intercourse with kinsfolk, Eur.
sexual intercourse, Hdt., Xen., etc.
instruction, Xen.:—later, a homily, sermon.
an association, company, Hdt., Aesch.:—in collect. sense, fellow-sojourners, Aesch.; ναὸς ὁμ. ship- mates, Soph.

div1.head: ὅμιλος
div1.sense: any assembled crowd, a throng of people, Hom., Hdt., Aesch.: the mass of the people, the crowd, opp. to the chiefs, Il.; ὁ ψιλὸς ὅμ. the crowd of irregulars, as opp. to the ὁπλῖται, Thuc.
the throng of battle, Il.; πρώτῳ ἐν ὁμ., Lat. in prima acie, Il.: generally tumult, confusion, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀμιχέω
div1.sense: Lat. mingo, to make water, Hes.

div1.head: ὀμίχλη
div1.sense: a mist, fog, (not so thick as νέφος or νεφέλη) , Il.; κονίης ὀμίχλη a cloud of dust, Il.
metaph. a mist over the eyes, Aesch.: darkness, gloom, Anth.

div1.head: ὄμμα
div1.etym: Root found in ὦμμαι, perf. pass. of ὁράω
div1.sense: the eye, Hom., etc.; κατὰ χθονὸς ὄμματα πήξας Il.; ὀρθοῖς ὄμμασιν ὁρᾶν τινα, Lat. rectis oculis aspicere, to look straight, Soph., etc.; οὐκ οἶδʼ ὄμμασιν ποίοις βλέπων πατέρα ποτʼ ἂν προσεῖδον how I could have looked him in the face, Soph.; so, ὁρᾶν τινα ἐν ὄμμασι Soph.; λαμπρὸς ὥσπερ ὄμματι to judge by his eyes or expression, Soph.; ἐς ὄμμα τινὸς ἐλθεῖν to come within sight of him, Eur.;— κατʼ ὄμματα before oneʼs eyes, Soph.; ἐλθεῖν κατʼ ὄμμα face to face, Eur.; but κατʼ ὄμμα, also, in point of eye-sight, Soph.:— ὡς ἀπʼ ὀμμάτων to judge by the eye, Lat. ex obtutu, Soph.;— ἐν ὄμμασι, Lat. in oculis, before oneʼs eyes, Aesch., Thuc.; —ἐξ ὀμμάτων out of sight, Eur.
that which one sees, a sight, vision, Soph.
the eye of heaven, i. e. the sun, Soph., Eur.; but, ὄμμα νυκτός periphr. for νύξ (v. infr. V), Aesch., Eur.
generally, light, that which brings light, ὄμμα δόμων νομίζω δεσπότου παρουσίαν Aesch.; ὄμμα φήμης the light of glad tidings, Soph.:—hence, anything dear or precious, Aesch.
periphr. of the person, ὄμμα πελείας for πελεία, Soph.; ὄμμα νύμφας for νύμφα, Soph.; ξύναιμον ὄμμα for ξυναίμων, Soph.; ὦ ταυρόμορφον ὄμμα Κηφισοῦ for ὦ ταυρόμορφε Κηφισέ, Eur.

div1.head: ὀμματοστερής
div1.sense: bereft of eyes, Soph., Eur.
act. depriving of eyes, φλογμὸς ὀμμ. φυτῶν heat that robs plants of their eyes or buds, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀμματόω
div1.sense: to furnish with eyes:—Pass., φρὴν ὠμματωμένη a mind furnished with eyes, quick of sight, Aesch.

div1.head: ὄμνυμι
div1.sense: to swear, Hom.; c. acc. cogn., ὀμνυέτω δέ τοι ὅρκον Il.; ὅ τις κʼ ἐπίορκον ὀμόσσηι whosoever swears a false oath, Il.
to swear to a thing, affirm or confirm by oath, ταῦτα δʼ ἐγὼν ἐθέλω ὀμόσαι Il.; ὄμν. τὴν εἰρήνην Dem.

foll. by inf. fut. to swear that one will . . , Il., Soph.;—often with ἦ μέν or (in Attic) ἦ μήν preceding the inf., καί μοι ὄμοσσον ἦ μέν μοι ἀρήξειν Il.; so by inf. aor. and ἄν, Xen.:—foll. by inf. pres. to swear that one is doing a thing, Soph.; by inf. perf. to swear that one has done, Dem.
absol. εἰπεῖν ὀμόσας to say with an oath, Plat.

with acc. of the person or thing sworn by, to swear by, ὀμόσαι Στυγὸς ὕδωρ Il.; ὀμωμοκὼς τοὺς θεούς Dem.;—rarely c. dat., τῶι δʼ ἄρʼ ὄμνυτʼ; Ar.:—Pass., ὀμώμοσται Ζεύς Zeus has been sworn by, adjured, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμοβώμιος
div1.sense: having a common altar, Thuc.

div1.head: ὁμογάλακτες
div1.sense: persons suckled with the same milk, foster-brothers or sisters, clansmen, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμόγαμος
div1.sense: married to the same wife, Eur.; ὁμόγαμοι having married sisters, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμογάστριος
div1.sense: from the same womb, born of the same mother, Il.

div0.div1:
ὁμογενέτωρ , ορος, ὁ,
an own brother, Eur. Phoen. 165 (lyr.)[LSJ supp.]

div1.head: ὁμογενής
div1.sense: of the same race or family, Eur.; ὁμ. μιάσματα, of bloodshed in a family, Eur.:— also as Subst., ὁμογενής τινος oneʼs congener, Eur.
act. having the same wife, Soph.

div1.head: ὁμογέρων
div1.sense: one equally aged, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμόγλωσσος
div1.sense: speaking the same tongue, Hdt.; τινι with one, Hdt., Xen.

div1.head: ὁμόγνιος
