div1.sense: of the same race: ὁμόγν. θεοί gods who protect a race or family, Lat. Dii gentilitii, Soph.; Ζεὺς ὁμ. Eur. Ar.

div1.head: ὁμογνωμονέω
div1.sense: to be of one mind, to league together, Thuc., Xen.; ὁμ. τινί to consent to, Xen.; ὁμ. τινί τι to agree with one in a thing, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμογνώμων
div1.sense: of oneʼs mind, like-minded, τινί with one, Thuc., Xen., etc.; ὁμ. τινα λαμβάνειν, ποιεῖν, ποιεῖσθαι to bring to oneʼs own opinion, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμόγονος
div1.sense: = ὁμο-γενής, Pind.; τινι with one, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμοδέμνιος
div1.sense: sharing oneʼs bed, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμόδημος
div1.sense: of the same people or race, Pind.; τινι with one, Pind.

div1.head: ὁμοδίαιτος
div1.sense: living with others, Luc.; ὁμοδίαιτα τοῖς πολλοῖς common to the generality, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμοδοξέω
div1.sense: to be of the same opinion, agree perfectly, τινι with one, Plat.: absol. to agree together, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοδοξία
div1.sense: unanimity, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμόδοξος
div1.sense: of the same opinion, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμόδουλος
div1.sense: a fellow-slave, Eur., Plat., etc.; ὁμ. τινος Plat.; τινι Xen.

div1.head: ὁμοδρομία
div1.sense: a running together, meeting, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμοεθνής
div1.sense: of the same people or race, hdt., Arist.:—generally, of the same kind, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμόζυξ
div1.sense: yoked together, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοήθης
div1.sense: of the same habits or character, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: ὁμοθάλαμος
div1.sense: living in the same chamber with another, c. gen., Pind.

div1.head: ὁμόθεν
div1.sense: from the same place, properly a gen. (like ἐμέθεν, σέθεν, οὐρανόθεν) , ἐψ ὁμόθεν Od.
as adv. from the same source, Hhymn., Hes.; τὸν ὁμόθεν a brother, Eur.; so, τὸν ὁμ. πεφυκότα Eur.; ὁμ. εἶναί τινι to be from the same parents with him, Soph.
from near, hand to hand, ὁμ. μάχην ποιεῖσθαι, Lat. cominus pugnare, Xen.; ὁμόθεν διώκειν to follow close upon, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμόθρονος
div1.sense: sharing the same throne, Pind.

div1.head: ὁμοθυμαδόν
div1.sense: with one accord, Dem.; mostly joined with πάντες, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: ὁμοιάζω
div1.sense: to be like, NTest.

div1.head: ὁμοίιος
div1.etym: ῑ metri grat. before a long syll.

div1.head: ὁμοιοκατάληκτος
div1.sense: ending alike, rhyming, of verses.

div1.head: ὁμοιοπαθέω
div1.sense: to have similar feelings or affections, to sympathise, τινί with another, Arist.
of things, to be subject to the same laws, to be homogeneous, Strab.

div1.head: ὁμοιοπαθής
div1.sense: having like feelings or affections, sympathetic, τινί with another, Plat.
generally, of like nature, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοιοπρεπής
div1.sense: of like appearance with, τινι Aesch.

div1.head: ὅμοιος
div1.etym: Ionic and old Attic ὁμοῖος, η, ον
div1.sense: like, resembling, Lat. similis, Hom., etc.; proverb., τὸν ὁμοῖον ἄγει θεὸς ὡς τὸν ὁμοῖον "birds of a feather flock together, " Od.; so, ὁ ὅμοιος τῷ ὁμοίῳ Plat.:—comp. ὁμοιότερος more like, Plat.; Sup. -ότατος most like, Hdt., Soph., etc.
= ὁ αὐτός, the same, Hom.; ἓν καὶ ὅμ. one and the same, Plat.; ὁμοῖον ἡμῖν ἔσται it will be all one to us, Lat. perinde erit, Hdt.; σὺ δʼ αἰνεῖν εἴτε με ψέγειν θέλεις, ὁμοῖον Aesch.
shared alike by both, common, ὁμ. πόλεμος war in which each takes part, Hom.; γῆρας, θάνατος, μοῖρα common to all, Hom.
equal in force, a match for one, Lat. par, Il., Hdt.
like in mind, at one with, agreeing with, τινι Hes.:—hence (sub. ἑαυτῷ) always the same, Hes.; ὅμοιος πρὸς τοὺς αὐτοὺς κινδύνους Thuc.

τὸ ὁμοῖον ἀνταποδιδόναι to give "tit for tat," Lat. par pari referre, Hdt.; so, τὴν ὁμοίην (sc. χάριν) διδόναι or ἀποδιδόναι τινί Hdt.; τὴν ὁμοίην φέρεσθαι παρά τινος to have a like return made one, Hdt.; ἐπʼ ἴσῃ καὶ ὁμοίᾳ (v. ἴσος II.2).
ἐν ὁμοίῳ ποιεῖσθαί τι to hold a thing in like esteem, Hdt.
ἐκ τοῦ ὁμοίου, alike, much like ὁμοίως, Thuc.; ἐκ τῶν ὁμοίων with equal advantages, in fair fight, Aesch.
of the same rank or station, Hdt.: οἱ ὅμοιοι, the peers, Xen., Arist.
Construction:
absol., as often in Hom., etc.
the person or thing to which one is like in dat., as with Lat. similis, Hom., etc.; also in gen.: —ellipt., κόμαι Χαρίτεσσιν ὁμοῖαι, for -κόμαι ταῖς τῶν Χαρίτων ὁμοῖαι, Il.
that in which a person or thing is like another is in acc., ἀθανάτῃσι φυὴν καὶ εἶδος ὁμοίη Od.
with inf., θείειν ἀνέμοισιν ὁμοῖοι like the winds to run, Il.
foll. by καί, like Lat. perinde ac, Hdt., etc.
adv., often in the neuters, ὅμοιον and ὅμοια, Ionic and old Attic ὁμοῖον, ὁμοῖα, in like manner with, ὁμοῖα τοῖς μάλιστα "second to none, " Hdt.; ὁμοῖα τοῖς πρώτοισι Hdt.
alike, Aesch.
regul. adv. ὁμοίως, in like manner with, c. dat., Hdt., Attic; ὁμ. καὶ . . Hdt.
alike, equally, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμοιοτέλευτος
div1.sense: ending alike, Arist.: τὸ ὁμοιοτέλευτον the like ending of two verses.

div1.head: ὁμοιότης
div1.sense: likeness, resemblance, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοιοτροπία
div1.sense: likeness of manners and life, Strab.

div1.head: ὁμοιότροπος
div1.sense: of like manners and life, Thuc.:— adv. -πως, in like manner with another, c. dat., Thuc.

div1.head: ὁμοιόω
div1.sense: to make like, Lat. assimilare, τί τινι Eur., Plat.; πρὸς τὰ παρόντα τὰς ὀργὰς ὁμ. to make their feelings suitable to present circumstances, Thuc.:—Pass. to be made like, become like, Hom., Eur., etc.; in perf. ὡμοίωμαι, to be like, Plat.
to liken, compare, τί τινι Hdt., etc.; so in Mid., Hdt.:— in N. T. of parables.
in Mid. also to make a like return, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμοίωμα
div1.sense: a likeness, image, resemblance, counterfeit, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοίωσις
div1.sense: a becoming like, assimilation, Plat.
likeness, resemblance, NTest.

div1.head: ὁμόκαποι
div1.sense: eating together, ap. Arist.

div1.head: ὁμόκεντρος
div1.sense: concentric with, Strab.

div1.head: ὁμοκλάω
div1.sense: to call out together, Od., Soph.; ὁμ. τινι to call or shout to, whether to encourage or upbraid, threaten, Il.;—c. inf. to command loudly, call on one to do, Il.

div1.head: ὁμοκλή
div1.sense: properly of several persons, a joint call; but of single persons, μεῖναι ὁμοκλήν to bide his call, Il.; with a sense of reproof, rebuke, Hom.
generally, harmony.

div1.head: ὁμόκληρος
div1.sense: one who has an equal share of an inheritance, a coheir, Pind.

div1.head: ὁμοκλητήρ
div1.sense: one who calls out to, an upbraider, threatener, Il.

div1.head: ὁμόκλινος
div1.sense: reclining on the same couch, at table, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμόλεκτρος
div1.sense: sharing the same bed, Eur.; but, Ζηνὸς ὁμόλεκτρον κάρα, of Tyndareus, as husband of Leda, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμολογέω
div1.sense: to speak together; hence,
to speak one language, τινί with one, Hdt.:—generally, οὐδὲν ὁμ. τινί to have naught to do with, Hdt.
to hold the same language with, i. e. to agree with, τινί Hdt., Thuc.

to agree to a thing, allow, admit, confess, concede, grant, c. acc. rei, Hdt., Soph., etc.; ὁμ. τὴν εἰρήνην to agree to the terms of peace, Dem.:— without the acc. rei, ὁμολογῶ σοι I grant you, i. e. I admit it, Ar., Xen.:—c. inf. to allow, confess, grant that . . , Ar., Plat.
to agree or promise to do, c. inf., Plat.
the inf. is often omitted, ὁμολογήσαντες (sc. ἀπαλλάξεσθαι) Hdt.:—hence simply to make an agreement, come to terms, τινί with another, Hdt.
Mid., just like the Act., Plat., Xen.
Pass. to be agreed upon, allowed or granted by common consent, Xen.; c. inf. to be allowed or confessed to be, Plat., Xen.
absol., ὁμολογεῖται it is granted, allowed, Plat.; τὰ ὁμολογούμενα, τὰ ὡμολογημένα things granted, Lat. concessa, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμολόγημα
div1.sense: that which is agreed upon, taken for granted, a postulate, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμολογία
div1.sense: agreement, Plat.
an assent, admission, concession, Plat.: κατὰ τὴν ἐμὴν ὁμ. by my admission, Plat.
an agreement made, compact, Plat.; often in pl., Plat.; esp. in war, terms of surrender, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ὁμόλογος
div1.sense: agreeing, of one mind, ὁμ. γενέσθαι τινὶ περί τινος to be of one mind with one on a point, Xen.:—also of things, agreeing, correspondent, Arist.
adv. -γως, agreeably to, in unison with, Arist.:—so, ἐξ ὁμολόγου confessedly, Polyb.

div1.head: ὁμολογουμένως
div1.etym: adverb from part. pres. pass. of ὁμολογέω
div1.sense: conformably with, τοῖς εἰρημένοις Xen.
by common consent, confessedly, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: Ὁμολώϊος
div1.sense: a name of Zeus in Boeotia and Thessaly: —hence one of the Gates of Thebes were called πύλαι Ὁμολωίδες, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ὁμομαστιγίας
div1.sense: a fellow-knave (cf. μαστιγίας) Ar.

div1.head: ὁμομήτριος
div1.sense: born of the same mother, Lat. frater uterinus, Hdt., Plat.; ὁμοματρία ἀδελφή Ar.

div1.head: ὁμόνεκρος
div1.sense: companion in death, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμονοέω
div1.sense: to be of one mind, agree together, live in harmony, Thuc.; ὁμονοοῦσα ὀλιγαρχία a united oligarchy, Arist.
c. dat. to live in harmony with others, c. dat., Plat.

div1.head: ὁμονοητικός
div1.sense: conducing to agreement, in harmony, Plat.:—adv. -ικῶς ἔχειν to be of one mind, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμόνοια
div1.sense: oneness of mind or thought, unity, concord, Thuc., Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὁμόνοος
div1.sense: of one mind, Lat. concors: adv. -νόως, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμοπαθής
div1.sense: of like feelings or affections, sympathetic, Arist.; c. gen., ὁμ. λύπης καὶ ἡδονῆς affected alike by pain and pleasure, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοπάτριος
div1.sense: by the same father, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμοπλοέω
div1.sense: to sail together or in company, Polyb.

div1.head: ὁμόπλοια
div1.sense: a sailing in company, Cic.

div1.head: ὁμόπλοος
div1.sense: sailing together or in company, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμόπολις
div1.sense: from or of the same city: poet. ὁμό-πτολις, Soph.

div1.head: ὁμόπτερος
div1.sense: of or with the same plumage, Plat.; ὁμόπτεροι ἐμοί my fellow-birds, birds of my feather, Ar.
metaph. of like feather, closely resembling, Aesch., Eur.; νᾶες ὁμ. consort-ships (or equally swift), Aesch.; ἀπήνη ὁμ. i. e. the two brothers, Eteocles and Polynices, Eur.

div1.head: ὀμοργάζω
div1.sense: to wipe off, 3rd sg. imperf. ὠμόργαζε Hhymn.

div1.head: ὀμόργνυμι
div1.sense: to wipe:— Mid., δάκρυα ὠμόργνυντο were wiping away their tears, Od.; παρειάων δάκρυʼ ὀμορξαμένη were wiping the tears from their cheeks, Il.

div1.head: ὁμορέω
div1.sense: Ionic ὁμουρέω, fut. -ήσω to border upon, march with, οἱ Κελτοὶ ὁμουρέουσι Κυνησίοισι Hdt.

div1.head: ὅμορος
div1.sense: having the same borders with, marching with, bordering on, τοῖσι Δωριεῦσι, τῇ Λιβύῃ Hdt.; absol. bordering, Thuc.; πόλεμος ὅμορος a border war, Dem.
metaph. bordering on, closely resembling, Arist.
also as Subst., a neighbour, Hdt., Thuc.; κατὰ τὸ ὅμορον because of their neighbourhood, Thuc.

div1.head: ὁμορροθέω
div1.sense: to row together; metaph. to agree, consent, Soph.; ὁμ. τινι to agree with him, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμόρροθος
div1.sense: properly, rowing together: hence side by side, Theocr.:—so, ὁμορρόθιος, ον, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμόσε
div1.sense: to one and the same place, Il.; ὁμόσʼ ἦλθε μάχη the battle came to the same spot, i. e. the armies met, Il.; ὁμόσε ἰέναι, like Lat. cominus pugnare, ὁμ. ἰέναι τοῖς ἐχθροῖς to close with the enemy, Thuc.; ὁμ. χωρεῖν; so, ὁμ. θεῖν, φέρεσθαι to run to meet, Xen.
metaph., ὁμ. ἰέναι τοῖς λόγοις to come to issue with the arguments, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμοσθενής
div1.sense: of equal might, Anth.

div1.head: ὁμοσιτέω
div1.sense: to eat with, take oneʼs meals with others, c. dat., Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμόσιτος
div1.sense: eating together, μετά τινος Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμόσκευος
div1.sense: equipped in the same way, Thuc.

div1.head: ὁμοσκηνόω
div1.sense: to live in the same tent or house with others, c. dat., Xen.

div1.head: ὁμός
div1.sense: one and the same, common, joint, Lat. communis, Hom., Hes.; ὁμὰ φρονεῖν to be of one mind, Hes.

div1.head: ὁμόσπονδος
div1.sense: sharing in the drink-offering, sharing the same cup, Hdt., Dem.

div1.head: ὁμόσπορος
div1.sense: sown together: sprung from the same race, kindred, Hhymn., Trag.: as Subst. a brother or a sister, Trag.
ὁμ. γυνή a wife common to two (Laius and Oedipus), Soph.; of Oedipus, τοῦ πατρὸς ὁμόσπορος having the same wife with his father, Soph.

div1.head: ὁμόστολος
div1.sense: in company with others, c. gen., Soph.

div1.head: ὁμόταφος
div1.sense: buried together, Aeschin.

div1.head: ὁμότεχνος
div1.sense: practising the same craft with another, c. dat., Plat.:—as Subst., a fellow-workman, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοτιμία
div1.sense: sameness of value or honour, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμότιμος
div1.sense: held in equal honour, Il.; μακάρεσσι with the gods, Theocr.; c. gen. rei, τῆς στρατηγίας ὁμ. having an equal share in the command, Plut.
οἱ ὁμότιμοι, among the Persians, nobles of equal rank, the peers of the realm, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμότοιχος
div1.sense: having one common wall, separated by a party-wall, contiguous, Plat.:—metaph., of disease, γείτων ὁμ. a next-door neighbour, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμοτράπεζος
div1.sense: eating at the same table with another, c. dat., Hdt.; συνέστιος καὶ ὁμ. Plat.;— οἱ ὁμ., messmates, Persian name for certain courtiers, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμότροπος
div1.sense: of the same habits or life, Plat.:— as Subst., οἱ ὁμότροποί τινος oneʼs messmates, Aeschin.
of like fashion, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμότροφος
div1.sense: reared or bred together with another, c. dat., Hhymn.; ὁμότροφα τοῖσι ἀνθρώποισι θηρία, of domestic animals, Hdt.
absol., ὁμότρ. πεδία plains where we fed in common, Ar.

div1.head: ὁμοῦ
div1.sense: properly gen. neut. of ὁμός,
of Place, at the same place, together, Il., Soph., etc.
together, at once, ἄμφω ὁμοῦ Od.; δυοῖν ὁμοῦ Soph.; αἶγας ὁμοῦ καὶ ὄϊς both sheep and goats, Il.; λιμὸν ὁμου καὶ λοιμόν Hes., etc.
c. dat. together with, along with, κεῖσθαι ὁμοῦ νεκύεσσι Il.; οἰμωγὴ ὁμοῦ κωκύμασιν Aesch.
close at hand, hard by, Soph., Ar.: c. dat. close to, Soph., Xen.
rarely c. gen., νεὼς ὁμοῦ στείχειν to go to join my ship, Soph.
of amount, in all, εἰσὶν ὁμοῦ δισμύριοι Dem., etc.
ὁμοῦ καί just like, Xen.

div1.head: ὁμόφοιτος
div1.sense: going by the side of another, c. gen., Pind.

div1.head: ὁμοφρονέω
div1.sense: to be of the same mind, have the same thoughts, Od.; ὁμοφρονέοντε νοήμασιν in unity of purposes, Od.; πόλεμος ὁμοφρονέων a war of common consent, Hdt.:—c. dat., οὑ γὰρ ἀλλήλοισι ὁμοφρονέουσι are not agreed together, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμοφυής
div1.sense: of the same growth or nature, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμοφυλία
div1.sense: sameness of race or tribe, Strab.

div1.head: ὁμόφυλος
div1.sense: of the same race or stock, Thuc., etc.; οἱ ὁμ. those of the same race, Xen.; φιλία ὁμόφ. friendship with those of the same stock, Eur.:— τὸ ὁμόφυλον, ὁμοφυλία, Eur.; τὸ μὴ ὁμ. a city peopled by different races, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμοφωνέω
div1.sense: to speak the same language with another, c. dat., Hdt.
to sound together, c. dat., ὁ. τῷ λόγῳ chimes in with the argument, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμοφωνία
div1.sense: in Music, unison, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμόφωνος
div1.sense: speaking the same language with others, c. dat., Hdt., Thuc., etc.
of the same sound or tone, in unison with, τινι Aesch.

div1.head: ὁμόχροια
div1.sense: sameness of colour, Xen.
the even surface of the body, the skin, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμοχρονέω
div1.sense: to keep time with, τινί Luc.: absol. to keep time, Luc.

div1.head: ὁμόψηφος
div1.sense: having an equal right to vote with others, c. dat., Hdt.; μετά τινων Hdt.

div1.head: ὁμόω
div1.sense: to unite: aor1 pass. inf. ὁμωθῆναι Il.

div1.head: ὄμπνιος
div1.sense: of or relating to corn: hence bountiful, wealthy, ὄμπνια Anth.

div1.head: ὀμφακίας
div1.sense: made from unripe grapes: hence harsh, austere, crabbed, Ar.

div1.head: ὀμφακοράξ
div1.sense: with sour grapes, Anth.

div1.head: ὀμφάλιος
div1.sense: having a boss, bossy, Anth.

div1.head: ὀμφαλόεις
div1.sense: having a navel or boss, ἀσπίδος ὀμφαλοέσσης of the shield with a central boss, Il.; ζυγὸν ὀμφαλόεν a yoke with a knob on the top, Il.

div1.head: ὀμφαλός
div1.sense: the navel, Lat. umbilicus, Il., Hdt., etc.
anything central (like a navel):
the knob or boss in the middle of the shield, Lat. umbo, Il.
a button or knob on the horseʼs yoke to fasten the reins to, Il.
in pl. the knobs at each end of the stick round which books were rolled, Lat. umbilici, Luc.

the centre or middle point, as the island of Calypso is the ὀμφαλός of the sea, Od.; and Delphi (or rather a round stone in the Delphic temple) was called ὀμφαλός as marking the middle point of Earth, Pind., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ὄμφαξ
div1.sense: an unripe grape, πάροιθε δέ τʼ ὄμφακές εἰσιν Od.; ὅτʼ ὄμφακες αἰόλλονται Hes.; ὅταν δὲ τεύχῃ Ζεὺς ἀπʼ ὄμφακος οἶνον, i. e. autumn, when the unripe grapes become fit to make wine, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀμφή
div1.sense: the voice of a god (opp. to αὐδή, the human voice), Hom.; θείη δέ μιν ἀμφέχυτʼ ὀμφή, of the voice of the dream sent by Zeus to Agamemnon, Il.; κατʼ ὀμφὴν σήν on hearing the sound of thy name (for the name of Oedipus had something awful in it), Soph.
a sweet voice, Pind.:— a voice, sound, Eur.

div1.head: ὁμωνυμία
div1.sense: a having the same name, identity, an equivocal word, Arist.

div1.head: ὁμώνυμος
div1.sense: having the same name, Il., etc.; τινι with one, Thuc., etc.; τὸν ὁμ. ἐμαυτῷ my own namesake, Dem.:—as Subst., c. gen., ὁ σαυτοῦ or ὁ σὸς ὁμώνυμος your namesake, Plat.
of like kind, Plat.

div1.head: ὁμωρόφιος
div1.sense: lodging under the same roof with another, c. dat., Dem., Babr.

div1.head: ὅμως
div1.etym: Conj. from ὁμός but with changed accent
div1.sense: all the same, nevertheless, notwithstanding, still, Lat. tamen, Il., Soph., etc.:—often strengthened by other words, ἀλλʼ ὅμως, Lat. attamen, but still, but for all that, Ar., etc.; ὅμως μήν, ὅμως μέντοι Plat.; ὅμως γε μήν, ὅμως γε μέντοι Ar.:—used elliptically, οἴσεις οὐδὲν ὑγιές, ἀλλʼ ὅμως (sc. οἰστέον) Ar.

in apodosis after καί εἰ or καὶ ἐάν, as tamen after etsi or quamquam, κεἰ τὸ μηδὲν ἐξερῶ, φράσω δʼ ὅμως even if I shall say nothing plainly, yet I will speak, Soph.;—so, κλῦθί μου νοσῶν ὅμως (i. e. εἰ νοσεῖς, ὅμως κλῦθι) , Soph.
to limit single words, Lat. quamvis, ἀπάλαμόν περ ὅμως helpless though he be, Hes., etc.

div1.head: ὁμῶς
div1.sense: equally, likewise, alike, Lat. pariter, Hom., Trag.; πλῆθεν ὁμῶς ἵππων τε καὶ ἀνδρῶν was filled full both of men and horses alike, Il.; πάντες ὁμῶς all alike, Hom.
c. dat. like as, equally with, ἐχθρὸς ὁμῶς Ἀΐδαο πύλῃσι hated like the gates of hell, Il.
together with, Theogn.

div1.head: ὁμωχέτας
div1.sense: holding or dwelling together, τοὺς ὁμωχέτας δαίμονας worshipped in the same temple, Thuc.

div1.head: ὄναγρος
div1.sense: the wild ass, Strab., Babr.

div1.head: ὄναρ
div1.etym: only used in nom. and acc. sg., the other cases being supplied by ὄνειρος
div1.sense: a dream, vision in sleep, opp. to a waking vision (ὕπαρ) , Od., Soph., etc.; ὥστε μηδʼ ὄναρ ἰδεῖν, to express profound sleep, Plat.
proverb. of anything fleeting or unreal, ὀλιγοχρόνιον ὥσπερ ὄναρ Theogn.; παρέρχεται ὡς ὄναρ ἥβη Theocr.
ὄναρ as adv., in a dream, in sleep, ὄναρ ὑμᾶς καλῶ Aesch.; μηδʼ ἰδὼν ὄναρ not even in my dreams, Eur., etc.; cf. ὕπαρ.

div1.head: ὀνεία
div1.sense: ὀνεία, (sc. δορά) assʼs skin, fem. of ὄνειος, Babr.

div1.head: ὄνειαρ
div1.sense: anything that profits or helps, Il.: advantage, aid, succour, Hes., etc.
a means of strengthening, refreshment, Od., Hes.; στιβάδεσσιν ὄνειαρ good for beds, Theocr.
in pl. ὀνείατα, food, victuals, Hom.; also of rich presents Il.
of persons, πᾶσιν ὄνειαρ Il.

div1.head: ὀνείδειος
div1.sense: reproachful, Hom.
dishonourable, Anth.

div1.head: ὀνειδίζω
div1.sense: c. acc. rei et dat. pers. to throw a reproach upon one, cast in oneʼs teeth, object or impute to one, Lat. objicere, exprobrare, Hom., etc.; also, ὀνειδίζειν τινὶ ὅτι . . to impute it to him that . . , Il., Plat.
omitting the acc. rei, to reproach, upbraid,
c. dat. pers., Il., Hdt.
c. acc. pers., ἔπεσίν μιν ὀνείδισον Il.; τυφλόν μʼ ὠνείδισας (sc. ὄντα) didʼst reproach me with being blind, Soph.

div1.head: ὀνείδισμα
div1.sense: insult, reproach, blame, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀνειδιστήρ
div1.sense: full of reproach, Eur.

div1.head: ὀνειδιστής
div1.sense: one who reproaches with a thing, c. gen. rei, Arist.

div1.head: ὀνειδιστικός
div1.sense: reproachful, abusive, Luc.

div1.head: ὄνειδος
div1.sense: reproach, censure, blame, Hom.; ὄνειδος ἔχειν to be in disgrace, Hdt.; ὄνειδός ἐστι, c. inf., Eur.; ὡς ἐν ὀνείδει by way of reproach, Plat.:—pl., ὀνείδη ἔχειν τὰ μέγιστα Plat., etc.

matter of reproach, a reproach, disgrace, σοὶ, μὲν δὴ κατηφείη καὶ ὄν., Il.; c. gen., τὸ πόλεως ὄν. the reproach of the city, Aesch.; ὄν. Ἑλλάνων Soph.; so, Oedipus calls his daughters τοιαῦτʼ ὀνείδη Soph.

div1.head: ὄνειος
div1.sense: of an ass, Ar.; ὄν. γάλα assʼs milk, Dem.

div1.head: ὀνείρειος
div1.sense: dreamy, of dreams, ἐν ὀνειρείῃσι πύλῃσι at the gates of dreams, Od.

div1.head: ὀνειροκρίτης
div1.sense: an interpreter of dreams, Theocr., Theophr.

div1.head: ὀνειροκριτικός
div1.sense: for interpreting dreams, πινάκιον Plut.

div1.head: ὀνειρόμαντις
div1.sense: an interpreter of dreams, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀνειροπολέω
div1.sense: to deal with dreams, i. e. to dream, Plat.; ὀν. τι to dream of a thing. Ar.; πολλὰ ὀνειροπολεῖ ἐν τῇ γνώμῃ "builds many such castles in the air," Dem.
to cheat by dreams, Ar.

div1.head: ὀνειροπόλος
div1.sense: one occupied with dreams, a dreamer, or an interpreter of dreams, Il., Hdt.

div1.head: ὄνειρος
div1.etym: pl. ὄνειρα, but the metaph. form ὀνείρατα as if from ὄνειραρ was more common in nom. and acc.; so, gen. ὀνειράτων, dat. -ασι; also in sg., gen ὀνείρατος, dat. ὀνείρατι
div1.sense: a dream, Hom., etc.
as prop. n. Ὄνειρος, god of dreams, Hom., Hes.; cf. ἐνύπνιον.

div1.head: ὀνειρόφρων
div1.sense: versed in dreams and their interpretations, Eur.

div1.head: ὀνεύω
div1.sense: to draw up with a windlass (ὄνος III. 1), imperf. ὤνευον Thuc.

div1.head: ὀνηλάτης
div1.sense: a donkey-driver, Dem.

div1.head: ὀνήσιμος
div1.sense: useful, profitable, beneficial, Aesch., Soph.: aiding, succouring, Soph.

div1.head: ὀνησίπολις
div1.sense: useful to the state, Simon.

div1.head: ὄνησις
div1.sense: use, profit, advantage, good luck, Od., Soph.:—c. gen. rei, enjoyment of a thing, profit or delight from it, Aesch., etc.; so, ὄν. εὑρεῖν ἀπό τινος Soph.

div1.head: ὄνθος
div1.sense: the dung of animals, Il.

div1.head: ὀνίδιον
div1.sense: a little ass, donkey, Ar.

div1.head: ὀνικός
div1.sense: of or for an ass: ὀνικὸς μύλος, v. ὄνος III. 2.

div1.head: ὀνίνημι
div1.etym: impf. act for ὀνίνημι supplied by ὠφέλουν
div1.sense: Act. to profit, benefit, help, assist, and, like Lat. juvo, to gratify, delight; absol. and c. acc. pers., Il., etc.; πολλὰ ὀν. τινα Od.; ὡς ὤνησας ὅτι ἀπεκρίνω how you pleased me by answering, Plat.

Mid. to have profit or advantage, derive benefit, have enjoyment or delight, Hom., etc.; c. gen. to have advantage from, have enjoyment of, δαιτὸς ὄνησο Od.; τί σευ ἄλλος ὀνήσεται; what good will others have of thee, i. e. what good will you have done them? Il.; so, ὄνασθαί τι ἀπό τινος Plat.
aor.2 part. ὀνήμενος, felix, ἐσθλός μοι δοκεῖ εἶναι, ὀνήμενος he seems to me noble, favoured by the gods, Od.

aor. opt. ὀναίμην, αιο, αιτο, in protestations and wishes, ὄναιο, Lat. sis felix! Eur., etc.; and c. gen., ὄναιο τῶν φρενῶν bless thee for thy good sense, Eur.; μὴ νῦν ὀναίμην may I not thrive (where βίου must be supplied), Soph.:—also in ironical sense, ὄναιο μέν τἄν youʼd be the better of it! Ar.; ἁλσὶν διασμηχθεὶς ὄναιτʼ ἂν οὑτοσί heʼd be very nice if he were rubbed down with salt, Ar.

div1.head: ὀνίς
div1.sense: assʼs dung, in pl., Ar.

div1.head: ὀνοβατέω
div1.sense: to have a mare covered by an ass, Xen.

div1.head: ὀνομάζω
div1.sense: to name or speak of by name, call or address by name, Il., Hdt., Xen.
of things, to name, specify, Il.
ὀν. τινά τι to call one something, Hdt., Attic: in Mid., παῖδά μʼ ὠνομάζετο called me his son, Soph.:—Pass., ὄνομα δʼ ὠνομάζετο Ἕλενος Soph., etc.
εἶναι is often added pleon., τὰς οὐνομάζουσι εἶναι Ὑπερόχην καί . . whose names they say are Hyperoche and . . , Hdt.; σοφιστὴν ὀνομάζουσιν τὸν ἄνδρα εἶναι Plat.
to name or call after . . , ἐπί τινι Hdt., etc.; ἔκ τινος Soph.:—Pass., ἀπὸ τούτου τοῦτο οὐνομάζεται hence this saying has arisen, Hdt.
to use names or words, μάλα σεμνῶς ὀνομάζων Dem.

div1.head: ὀνομαίνω
div1.sense: to name or call by name, and of things, to name, repeat, Hom.
simply, to utter, speak, Od.: c. inf. fut, to promise to do, Od.
to nominate, appoint, Il.

div1.head: ὄνομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to blame, find fault with, throw a slur upon, treat scornfully, τι Hom.; ἦ οὔνεσθʼ, ὅτι μοι Ζεὺς ἔδωκεν; do ye complain that Zeus has given? Il.; c. gen., οὐδʼ σε ἔολπα ὀνόσσεσθαι κακότητος I hope thou wilt not quarrel with thy ill-luck (i. e. deem it too light), Od.; ὀν. τινα to throw a slur upon, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀνομακλήδην
div1.sense: calling by name, by name, Lat. nominatim, Od.

div1.head: ὀνομακλήτωρ
div1.sense: one who announces guests by name, Lat. nomenclator, Luc.

div1.head: ὀνομακλυτός
div1.sense: of famous name, Il.

div1.head: ὄνομα
div1.sense: Lat. nomen, a name, Hom., etc.:—absol., by name, πόλις ὄνομα Καιναί Xen., etc.; also in dat., πόλις Θάψακος ὀνόματι Xen.
ὄν. θεῖναί τινα to give one a name, Od.; but commonly in Mid., ὄν. θέσθαι Od., Attic; and for Pass., ὄν. κεῖταί τινι Ar., etc.; ὄν. ἔχειν ἀπό τινος Hdt.
ὄνομα καλεῖν τινα to call one by name, Od., Attic; so with pass. verbs. ὄν. ὠνομάζετο Ἕλενος Soph.; ὄν. κέκληται δημοκρατία Thuc.
name. fame, Ἰθάκης γε καὶ ἐς Τροίην ὄνομʼ ἵκει Od.; τὸ μέγα ὄν. τῶν Ἀθηνῶν Thuc.; ὄνομα or τὸ ὄν. ἔχειν to have a name for a thing (good or bad), 2 opt., Thuc.
a mere name, opp. to the real person or thing, Od.; opp. to ἔργον, Eur., etc.
a false name, pretence, pretext, ὀνόματι or ἐπʼ ὀνόματι under the pretence, Thuc.
ὄνομα is also used in periphr. phrases, ὄνομα τῆς σωτηρίας, for σωτηρία, Eur.; ὦ φίλτατον ὄν. Πολυνείκους Eur.
a phrase, expression, Xen.: generally, a saying, speech, Dem.
in Grammar, a noun, Lat. nomen, opp. to ῥῆμα, verbum, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὀνομαστί
div1.sense: by name, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ὀνομαστός
div1.sense: named, to be named, and οὐκ ὀνομαστός not to be named or mentioned, i. e. abominable, Lat. infandus, Od.
of name or note, notable, famous, Theogn., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὀνοματολόγος
div1.sense: telling peopleʼs names, Lat. nomenclator, Plut.

div1.head: ὀνοματοποιέω
div1.sense: to coin names, Arist.

div1.head: ὄνος
div1.sense: an ass, Il., Hdt., etc.:—proverb.,
περὶ ὄνου σκιᾶς for an assʼs shadow, i. e. for nothing at all, Lat. de lana caprina, Ar., Plat.
ὄνου πόκαι or πόκες, v. πόκος II.
ἀπʼ ὄνου πεσεῖν, of one who gets into a scrape by his own clumsiness, with a pun on ἀπὸ νοῦ πεσεῖν, Ar.
ὄνος ἄγων μυστήρια, of one heavily laden, Ar.
ὄνου ὑβριστότερος, of brutality, Xen.
ὄνου ὦτα λαβεῖν, like Midas, Ar.
ὄνων φάτνη a luminous appearance between the ὄνοι (two stars in the breast of the Crab), Lat. praesepe, Theocr.
from the ass as a beast of burden,
a windlass, pulley, Hdt.
the upper millstone, ὄνος ἀλέτης Xen.:—so, μύλος ὀνικός NTest.
a beaker, wine-cup, Ar.

div1.head: ὀνοστός
div1.sense: to be blamed or scorned, Il.

div1.head: ὀνοτάζω
div1.sense: to blame, Hhymn., Hes.

div1.head: ὀνοφορβός
div1.sense: an ass-keeper, Hdt.

div1.head: ὄντα
div1.sense: existing things, the present, opp. to the past and future; but also, reality, truth, opp. to that which is not, Plat.
that which one has, property, like οὐσία, Dem.

div1.head: ὄντως
div1.sense: really, verily, Eur., etc.; ὄντως τε καὶ ἀληθῶς really and truly, Plat.

div1.head: ὄνυξ
div1.sense: Lat. unguis, in Hom. only in pl. of the eagleʼs talons;— of human beings, a nail, Hes., Hdt., Attic:—of horses and oxen, a hoof, Xen.—Special phrases, εἰς ἄκρους τοὺς ὄνυχας ἀφίκετο (sc. ὁ οἶνος) warmed me to my fingersʼ ends, Eur.; ὄνυχας ἐπʼ ἄκρους στάς on tiptoe, Lat. summis digitis, Eur.; ἐξ ἁπαλῶν ὀνύχων from childhood, Hor. de tenero ungui, Anth.; ὀδοῦσι καὶ ὄνυξι, i. e. in every possible way, Luc.
a veined gem, onyx, Luc.

div1.head: ὀνύχινος
div1.sense: made of onyx, Plut.

div1.head: ὀξάλμη
div1.sense: a sauce of vinegar and brine, Ar.

div1.head: ὀξηρός
div1.sense: of or for vinegar, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξίνης
div1.sense: sharp, sour, tart, Ar.

div1.head: ὀξίς
div1.sense: a vinegar-cruet, Lat. acetabulum, Ar.; applied to a diminutive person, Ar.

div1.head: ὄξος
div1.sense: poor wine, vin-de-pays, Ar., Xen.
vinegar made therefrom, Aesch., Ar.
metaph. of a sour fellow, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀξύα
div1.sense: a kind of beech: a spear-shaft made from its wood, a spear, Eur.

div1.head: ὀξύβαφον
div1.sense: a vinegar-saucer, then, generally, a shallow vessel, saucer, Ar.

div1.head: ὀξυβελής
div1.sense: sharp-pointed, Il.

div1.head: ὀξυβόας
div1.sense: shrill-screaming, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξύγαλα
div1.sense: sour milk, whey, Strab.

div1.head: ὀξύγοος
div1.sense: shrill-wailing, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξυδερκής
div1.sense: quick-sighted, Hdt., Luc.

div1.head: ὀξύδουπος
div1.sense: sharp-sounding, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξύθηκτος
div1.sense: sharp-edged, sharp-pointed, Eur.
of a person, goaded to passion, infuriated, Soph.

div1.head: ὀξυθυμέω
div1.sense: to be quick to anger, Eur.
Pass. to be provoked, Ar.

div1.head: ὀξυθυμία
div1.sense: sudden anger, Eur.

div1.head: ὀξύθυμος
div1.sense: quick to anger, choleric, Eur., Ar., etc.: — sharp to punish, of the Areopagus, Aesch.: τὸ ὀξύθυμον, by crasis τοὐξύθυμον, ὀξυθυμία, Eur.

div1.head: ὀξύκομος
div1.sense: with pointed leaves, of a pine, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξυκώκυτος
div1.sense: wailed with shrill cries, Soph.

div1.head: ὀξυλαβέω
div1.sense: to seize quickly: to seize an opportunity, Xen.

div1.head: ὀξυλάλος
div1.sense: glib of tongue, Ar.

div1.head: ὀξυμάθεια
div1.sense: quickness at learning, Strab.

div1.head: ὀξυμέριμνος
div1.sense: keenly studied, Ar.

div1.head: ὀξυμήνιτος
div1.sense: bringing down the quick anger (of the Erinyes), Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξύμολπος
div1.sense: clear-singing, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξυντήρ
div1.sense: a sharpener, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξύνω
div1.sense: to sharpen: metaph. to goad to anger, provoke, Soph.:—Pass., Hdt.
to sharpen, quicken, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξυόεις
div1.sense: sharp-pointed, Il.

div1.head: ὀξυπαγής
div1.sense: sharp-pointed, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξύπεινος
div1.sense: ravenously hungry, Cic.

div1.head: ὀξυπευκής
div1.sense: sharp-pointed, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξύπους
div1.sense: swift-footed, Eur.

div1.head: ὀξύπρῳρος
div1.sense: sharp-pointed, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξύπτερος
div1.sense: swift-winged:— τὰ ὀξύπτερα swift wings, Aesop.

div1.head: ὀξύρροπος
div1.sense: turning quickly, of a delicate balance: metaph., ὀξ. πρὸς τὰς ὀργάς sudden and quick to anger, Plat.; ὀξ. θυμός sudden anger, Plat.

div1.head: ὀξύς
div1.sense: sharp, keen, Hom., Hes., etc.; ἐς ὀξὺ ἀπηγμένος brought to a point, Hdt.; τὸ ὀξύ the vertex of a triangle, Hdt.
of feeling, sharp, keen, ὀδύναι Il.; ὀξὺς ἠέλιος the piercing sun, Hhymn.; so, χιὼν ὀξεῖα, like Hor.ʼs gelu acutum, Pind.; μάχη ὀξέα keenly contested, Hdt.
of the sight, neut. as adv., ὀξύτατον δέρκεσθαι to be keenest of sight, Il.; so ὀξὺ νοεῖν to notice a thing sharply, Il.; ὀξὺ ἀκούειν to be quick of hearing, Il.
of things that affect the sight, dazzling, bright, of the sun, Il.; of colours, Ar.
of sound, sharp, shrill, piercing, Il.; and of the voice, ὀξὺ βοήσας, ὀξὺ λεληκώς Il., etc.
of musical tones, sharp, high, opp. to βαρύς, Plat.
of taste, sharp, pungent, acid, Xen., etc.
of smell, ὀξύτατον ὄζειν Ar.
metaph. of mind, sharp, keen: quick to anger, hasty, passionate, Il., Soph., etc.
sharp, quick, clever, Plat.; c. inf., ὀξ. ἐπινοῆσαι Thuc.; γνῶναι ὀξύτατοι Dem.
of motion, quick, swift, Ar.; ἡ νόσος ὀξεῖα φοιτᾷ καὶ ταχεῖʼ ἀπέρχεται Soph.; ὀξὺς νότος Soph.
regul. adv. ὀξέως, quickly, soon, Thuc., Plat.; but,
neut. ὀξύ and pl. ὀξέα as adv., v. supr.:—comp. ὀξύτερον Thuc., etc.; Sup. ὀξύτατον Il.; ὀξύτατα Plat.

div1.head: ὀξύστομος
div1.sense: sharp-toothed, sharp-fanged, Aesch.; of a gnat, Ar.:—of a sword, sharp-edged, Eur.

div1.head: ὀξύτης
div1.sense: sharpness, pointedness, Plat.
of sound, sharpness, opp. to βαρύτης, Plat.
of the mind, sharpness, cleverness, Plat.
of motion, quickness, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: ὀξυτόμος
div1.sense: sharp-cutting, keen, Pind.

div1.head: ὀξύτονος
div1.sense: sharp-sounding, piercing, of sound, Soph.
oxytone, having the acute accent, i. e. the accent on the last syllable.

div1.head: ὀξυτόρος
div1.sense: piercing, pointed, πίτυς ὀξ. the pine with its sharp spines, Anth.

div1.head: ὀξυφωνία
div1.sense: sharpness of voice, Arist.

div1.head: ὀξύφωνος
div1.sense: sharp-voiced, thrilling, Soph.

div1.head: ὀξύχειρ
div1.sense: quick with the hands, quick to strike, Theocr.
ὀξύχειρι σὺν κτύπῳ with quick beating of the hands in lamentation, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀξύχολος
div1.sense: quick to anger, Solon., Soph.

div1.head: ὀξυωπής
div1.sense: sharp-sighted, Arist., Luc.

div1.head: ὀπηδέω
div1.sense: to follow, accompany, attend, τινί Il., Pind.
of things, ἀνεμώλια γάρ μοι ὀπηδεῖ τόξα useless do they go with me, Il.; ἀρετὴν σήν, ἥ σοι ὀπηδεῖ Od., etc.

div1.head: ὀπαδός
div1.sense: attendant, Soph., Eur.: metaph., ἀοιδὰ στεφάνων ὀπαδός Pind.; πυκνοστίκτων ὀπ. ἐλάφων pursuing them, of Artemis, Soph.; ἀστέρες νυκτὸς ὀπ. Theocr.
as adj. accompanying, attending, c. dat., Hhymn.

div1.head: ὀπάζω
div1.sense: to make to follow, send with one, give as a companion, or follower, ἐπεί ῥά οἱ ὤπασα πομπόν Il.; πολὺν δέ μοι ὤπασε λαόν gave me many subjects, Il.:—Mid. to bid another follow one, take as a companion, Hom.
also of things, κῦδος ὀπάζει gives him glory to be with him, Il.; then simply, to give, grant, Hom., Pind., Aesch.
to give besides, add, ἔργῳ δʼ ἔργον ὄπαζε Hhymn.; ἔργον πρὸς ἀσπίδι ὤπασεν put a work of art on the shield, Aesch.
like διώκω, to press hard, chase, Ἕκτωρ ὤπαζε Ἀχαιούς Il.; χαλεπὸν δέ σε γῆρας ὀπάζει Il.:—Pass., χειμάρρους ὀπαζόμενος Διὸς ὄμβρῳ a torrent following, i. e. swollen with, rain, Il.

div1.head: ὀπαῖον
div1.sense: a hole in the roof, Plut.; cf. ἀνοπαῖα.

div1.head: ὄπατρος
div1.sense: by the same father, Il.;so, ὀπάτωρ, ορος, ὁ, ἡ, Anth.

div1.head: ὀπάων
div1.sense: a comrade in war, an esquire, such as was Meriones to Idomeneus, Phoenix to Peleus, Il.

div1.head: ὁ
div1.sense: ὁ, ἡ, τό, is
demonstr. Pronoun.
the definite Article.

in Epic, the relative Pronoun, when it is written with the accent ὅ, ἥ, τό ὅς, ἥ, ὅ. Besides the common forms, note Epic gen. sg. τοῖο for τοῦ; pl. nom. τοί, ταί; gen. fem. τάων [ᾰ], dat. τοῖσι, τῇς and τῇσι; dual gen, and dat. τοῖιν:— in Trag. we find τοὶ μέν . . , τοὶ δέ . . , for οἱ μέν . . , οἱ δέ . . ; dat. pl. also τοῖσι, ταῖσι: the dual has commonly but one gender, τώ for τά, τοῖν for ταῖν.
DEMONSTR. PRONOUN:
joined with a Subst., not as the Art., but like Lat. ille, ὁ Τυδείδης Tydeusʼs famous son, Il.; Νέστωρ ὁ γέρων Nestor— that aged man, Il.; τιμῆς τῆς Πριάμου for honour, namely that of Priam, Il.
without a Subst., he, she, it, ὁ γὰρ ἦλθε Il., etc.
pecul. usages,
before Relat. Pronouns, to call attention to the foregoing noun, ἐφάμην σε περὶ φρένας ἔμμεναι ἄλλων, τῶν ὅσσοι Λυκίκην ναιετάουσιν far above the rest, namely above those who . . , Il.
ὁ μέν . . , ὁ δέ . . , either in Opposition, ὁ μέν the former, ὁ δέ the latter), or in Partition, the one . . , the other . . , Lat. hic . . , ille . . .
absolute usages of single cases,
fem. dat. τῇ, there, on that spot, Hom.; τὸ μὲν τῇ, τὸ δὲ τῇ Xen.:—with a notion of motion towards, thither, Il.
of Manner, τῇπερ in this way, thus, Od.; τῇ μέν . . , τῇ δέ . . , in one way . . , in another . . , or partly . . , partly, Eur., etc.
relative, where, for ᾗ, Hom.
neut. gen. τοῦ, therefore, Hom.
neut. dat. τῷ, therefore, Hom., Soph.
thus, in this wise, then, if this be so, on this condition, Hom.
neut. acc. wherefore, Hom., Soph.; τὸ δέ, absol., but as to this . . , Plat.
τὸ μέν . . , τὸ δέ . . , partly . . , partly . . , or on the one hand . . , on the other . . , Od., Attic; τὰ μέν . . , τὰ δέ . . , Hdt., Soph., Thuc.; also, τὰ μέν τι . . , τὰ δέ τι . . , Xen.
with Prepositions, of Time, ἐκ τοῦ, Epic τοῖο, ever since, Il.
πρὸ τοῦ, sometimes written προτοῦ, before this, aforetime, Hdt., Aesch.; so, ἐν τῷ προτοῦ χρόνῳ Thuc.
ἐν τοῖς is often used in Prose with Superlatives, ἐν τοῖς θειότατον one of the most marvellous things, Hdt.; ἐν τοῖς πρῶτοι among the first, Thuc.

THE DEFINITE ARTICLE, the, the indefin. being τὶς, τὶ, a or an. The use of as the Article sprung from its use as demonstr. Pron., τὸν ὀπίστατον him that was hindmost, i.e. the hindmost man, Il.; τὸν ἄριστον him that was bravest, etc.;— also with Advs. τὸ πρίν, τὸ πάρος περ, τὸ πρόσθεν, τὸ τρίτον, τὰ πρῶτα all in Il.

the true Article is first fully established in Attic: it is omitted with prop. names and with appellatives which require no specification, as θεός, βασιλεύς:—but it is added to Prop. Names, when there has been previous mention of the person, as Thuc. speaks first of Πειθίας, and then refers to him as ὁ Π.; or to give pecul. emphasis, like Lat. ille, ὁ Λάϊος, ὁ Φοῖβος Soph.
with Infinitives, which thereby become Substantives, τὸ εἶναι the being; τὸ φρονεῖν good sense, etc.
in neuter, to specify any word or expression, τὸ ἄνθρωπος the word man; τὸ λέγω the word λέγω; τὸ μηδὲν ἄγαν the sentiment "ne quid nimis."
before Pronouns,
before the pers. Pron., to give them greater emphasis, but only in acc., τὸν ἐμέ, τὸν σὲ καὶ ἐμέ Plat.
before the interrog., to make the question more precise, τὸ τί; Aesch., etc.; τὰ ποῖα; Eur.
Elliptic. expressions:

before the gen. of a prop. n., to express descent, ὁ Διός (sc. παῖς) , ἡ Λητοῦς (sc. θυγάτηρ) often in Attic; but sometimes, as appears from the context, to denote husband, brother, friend, wife:— then before a gen. it indicates all general relations, as, τὰ τῆς πόλεως all that concerns the state; τὰ τῶν Ἀθηναίων φρονεῖν to hold with the Athenians, be on their side, Hdt.:—so with neut. of possess. Pron., τὸ ἐμόν, τὸ σόν what regards me or thee, my or thy business. But τὸ τινος is often also, a manʼs saying, as, τὸ τοῦ Σόλωνος Hdt.
with cases governed by Preps., οἱ ἐν τῇ πόλει, οἱ ἀπὸ (or ἐκ) τῆς πόλεως the men of the city; οἱ ἀμφί τινα, οἱ περί τινα such an one and his followers, but also periphr. for the person himself.
on μὰ τόν, v. μά IV.

πορεύεσθαι τὴν ἔξω τείχους (sc. ὁδόν) , Plat.; κρίνασθαι τὴν ἐπὶ θάνατον, v. θάνατος I. 2; ἡ αὔριον (sc. ἡμέρα) the morrow: —also with Advs., which thus take an Adject. sense, as, τὸ νῦν the present; οἱ τότε ἄνθρωποι the men of that time, also οἱ τότε, οἱ νῦν, etc.; τὸ πρίν formerly; τὸ πρόσθεν, τὸ πρῶτον, etc.; τὸ ἀπὸ τούτου, τὸ ἀπὸ τοῦδε from the present time, etc.

CRASIS OF ART.: —in Trag. with α make ᾱ, as ἁνήρ, ἅνθρωπος, ἁλήθεια, ἁρετή, τἀγαθόν, τἀδικεῖν, τᾄτιον; so, οἱ, αἱ, τά, as ἅνδρες, ἅνθρωποι, τἀγαθά, τἀκίνητα; also τοῦ, τῷ, as τἀγαθοῦ, τἀγαθῷ: —ὁ, οἱ, with ε become ου, οὑξ, οὑπί, οὑμός, τοὔργον, οὑπιχώριοι, etc.; also τοῦ, as τοὐμοῦ, τοὐπιόντος; but in one case ᾱ, ἅτερος, θἄτερον, for οὔτερος (which is Ionic); τῷ remains unchanged, τὠμῷ, τὠπιόντι:—ἡ with ε becomes ᾱ, ἁτέρα: —ὁ, τό before ο becomes ου, as Οὕλυμπιος, τοὔνομα:—ὁ, etc., before αυ donot change the diphthong, αὑτός, ταὐτό, ταὐτῷ; so, τὰ αὐτά ταὐτά, αἱ αὐταί αὑταί: —ἡ before εὐ becomes ηὑ, as ηὑλάβεια:—τῇ before ἡ becomes θη, as θἠμέρα: —τό before ὑ becomes θου-, as θοὔδωρ for τὸ ὕδωρ.

div1.head: ὅ
div1.sense: Ionic and Doric masc. for relat. pron. ὅς,
generally, neut. of the same.

div1.head: ὄπεας
div1.sense: an awl, Lat. subula, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁπηνίκα
div1.sense: at what point of time, at what hour, on what day, Soph., etc.; ὁπ. ἄν at whatever hour or time, Soph.

in indirect questions, ἢν ὥραν προσήκει ἰέναι, καὶ ὁπ. ἀπιέναι Aeschin.; in answer to a direct question, πηνίκ’ ἐστιν τῆς ἡμέρας;—ὁπηνίκα; what time of day is it? — what time, do you ask? Ar.: c. gen., ὁπ. τῆς ὥρας Xen.
in a causal sense, supposing that, ὁπ. ἐφαίνετο ταῦτα πεποιηκώς Dem.

div1.head: ὀπή
div1.sense: an opening, hole, Ar.
a hole in the roof, serving as a chimney, Ar.

div1.head: ὅπη
div1.etym: properly dat. from an old Pron. *ὁπός
div1.sense: of Place, by which way, Lat. qua; also = ὅπου, where, Lat. ubi, Hom.; sometimes much like ὅποι, whither, Lat. quo, Hom., Hdt., Aesch.
c. gen., ὅπη γᾶς, Lat. ubi terrarum, where in the world, Eur.
of Manner, in what way, how, Hom., Attic; ὅπη ἄν, with subjunct., like other Conjunctions, ὅπη ἂν δοκῇ ἀμφοτέροις Foed. ap. Thuc.:— ἔσθʼ ὅπη or ἔστιν ὅπη in any manner, in some way, Plat.

div1.head: ὀπίας
div1.sense: ὀπίας (sc. τυρός) cheese from milk curdled with fig-juice (ὀπός) , Ar. (with a pun on ὀπή) ; in full, τυρὸς ὀπίας Eur.

div1.head: ὀπίζομαι
div1.sense: Dep., to regard with awe and dread, Lat. vereri, revereri, Hom.:—absol., ὀπιζόμενος a pious man, Pind.; χάρις ὀπιζομένα pious gratitude, Pind.
to care for, c. gen., Theogn.: —so in Act. σώματος ὀπίζων Anth.

div1.head: ὀπιθόμβροτος
div1.sense: following a mortal, ὀπιθ. αὔχημα glory that lives after men, Pind.

div1.head: Ὀπικία
div1.sense: the country of the Opici, Thuc.
Ὀπικός, ή, όν barbarous, Anth.

div1.head: Ὀπικοί
div1.sense: the Opici, an ancient people of Southern Italy, Arist.; also Ὄπικες, Thuc.

div1.head: ὀπιπτεύω
div1.sense: to look around after, gaze curiously or anxiously at, c. acc., Hom.
to lie in wait for, watch, οὐ λάθρη ὀπιπτεύσας, ἀλλʼ ἀμφαδόν Il.

div1.head: ὄπισθεν
div1.sense: of Place, behind, at the back, Hom., etc.; οἱ ὄπιθεν those who are left behind, Od.; also, τοὺς ὄπισθεν ἐς τὸ πρόσθεν ἕξομεν shall bring the rear ranks to the front, Soph.; τὰ ὄπ. the rear, back, Il., Xen.:— εἰς τοὔπισθεν back, backwards, Eur., etc.
as prep. with gen. behind, ὄπιθεν δίφροιο Il.; ὄπισθε τῆς θύρης Hdt., etc.
of Time, in future, hereafter, Hom., etc.
ἐν τοῖσι ὄπισθε λόγοισι in the following books, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀπίσθιος
div1.sense: hinder, belonging to the hinder part, Lat. posticus, τὰ ὀπ. σκέλεα the hind- legs, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀπισθοβάμων
div1.sense: walking backwards, Anth.

div1.head: ὀπισθόγραφος
div1.sense: written on the back, or cover, Luc.

div1.head: ὀπισθοδάκτυλος
div1.sense: with back-bent fingers, Strab.

div1.head: ὀπισθόδομος
div1.sense: the back chamber or inner cell of the temple of Athena in the Acropolis at Athens, used as the Treasury, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: ὀπισθονόμος
div1.sense: grazing backwards, of certain cattle with large horns slanting forwards, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀπισθονυγής
div1.sense: pricking from behind, Anth.

div1.head: ὀπισθόπους
div1.sense: walking behind, following, attendant, Eur.:—also ὀπίσθοπος, ( cf. Οἴδιπος) , Aesch.

div1.head: ὀπισθοφυλακέω
div1.sense: to guard the rear, form the rear-guard, Xen.
to command the rearguard, Xen.

div1.head: ὀπισθοφυλακία
div1.sense: the command of the rear, Xen.

div1.head: ὀπισθοφύλαξ
div1.sense: one who guards the rear: οἱ ὀπ. the rear-guard, Xen.

div1.head: ὄπις
div1.sense: of the gods,
in bad sense, ὄπις θεῶν the vengeance or visitation of the gods for transgressing divine laws, Hom., Hes.; without θεῶν, divine vengeance, Od.
in good sense, the care or favour of the gods, Pind.
of men, the regard which men pay to the gods, religious awe, veneration, reverence, οὐδὲ θεῶν ὄπιν ἔχοντας paying no regard to the gods, Hdt.; ὄπι ξένων in his reverence towards strangers, Pind.

div1.head: ὀπίστατος
div1.sense: hindmost, Lat. postremus, Il.

div1.head: ὀπίσω
div1.sense: of Place, backwards, opp. to πρόσω, Il.:—in Prose also τὸ ὀπίσω, contr. τοὐπίσω, Hdt., Attic
back, back again, i. e. by the same way as one came, Od., Hdt.
again, ἀνακτᾶσθαι ὀπ. Hdt., etc.
c. gen., δεῦτε ὀπ. μου come after me, follow me, NTest.

of Time, hereafter, since the future is unseen or behind us, whereas the past is known and before our eyes, Hom.; ἅμα πρόσσω καὶ ὀπ. λεύσσει Il.; οὔτʼ ἐνθάδʼ ὁρῶν οὔτʼ ὀπίσω neither present nor future, Soph.
ἐν τοῖσι ὀπίσω λόγοις in the following books, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁπλέω
div1.sense: to make ready, Od.

div1.head: ὁπλή
div1.sense: a hoof, the solid hoof of the horse and ass, Il., Attic:—after Hom., like χηλή, the cloven hoof of horned cattle, Hhymn., Hes., etc.

div1.head: Ὅπλητες
div1.sense: name of one of the four old tribes at Athens, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: ὁπλίζω
div1.sense: to make or get ready, of meats and drink, Hom., Eur.:—Mid., δόρπον or δεῖπνον ὁπλίζεσθαι to prepare oneself a meal, Hom.; ὁπ. θυσίαν to cause a sacrifice to be prepared, Eur.

of chariot-horses, to get ready, harness, Il.; Mid. to get them ready for oneself, Il.:—Pass., of ships, Od.; of any implements, λαμπὰς ὡπλισμένη ready for use, Aesch.; ὡπλισμένος τινί furnished with a thing, Eur.

of soldiers, to equip, arm, Hdt., etc.:— also, to train, exercise, Hdt.:—in Attic Prose, to arm or equip as ὁπλῖται, Thuc.:—Mid. and Pass. to prepare or equip oneself, accoutre or arm oneself, get ready, Od.; ὅπλισθεν (for ὡπλίσθησαν) δὲ γυναῖκες the women got ready [for dancing], Od., etc.;—c. inf. to prepare oneself to do a thing, Il., Eur.:—in Mid., also, c. acc., ὁπλίζεσθαι χέρα to arm oneʼs hand, Eur.; ὁπλίζεσθαι θράσος to arm oneself with boldness, Soph.

div1.head: ὅπλισις
div1.sense: equipment, accoutrement, arming, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: ὅπλισμα
div1.sense: an army, armament, Eur.
a weapon, Eur.

div1.head: ὁπλιστέος
div1.sense: one must arm, Xen.

div1.head: ὁπλιστής
div1.sense: ὁπλιστὴς, κόσμος, a warrior-dress, Anth.

div1.head: ὁπλιταγωγός
div1.sense: carrying the heavy-armed, ναῦς ὁπλ. troop-ships, transports, Thuc.

div1.head: ὁπλιτεύω
div1.sense: to serve as a man-at-arms, Thuc., Xen.; οἱ ὁπλιτεύοντες men now serving, opp. to οἱ ὡπλιτευκότες, Arist.

div1.head: ὁπλίτης
div1.sense: heavy-armed, armed, δρόμος ὁπλ. a race of men in armour, opp. to the naked race, Pind.; ὁπλ. στρατός an armed host, Eur.; ὁπλ. κόσμος warrior-dress, armour, Eur.

as Subst., a heavy-armed foot-soldier, man-at-arms, who carried a large shield (ὅπλον) , whence the name, as the light-armed foot-soldier (πελταστής) had his from the light πέλτη, Hdt., Attic; ὁπλῖται are opp. to ψιλοί, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ὁπλιτικός
div1.sense: of or for a man-at-arms, Plat., Xen.
ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the art of using heavy arms, the soldierʼs art, Plat.; τὰ ὁπλιτικὰ ἐπιτηδεύειν to serve as a man-at-arms, Plat.
of persons, fit for service, opp. to ἄνοπλος, Arist.:— τὸ ὁπλιτικόν the soldiery, = οἱ ὁπλῖται, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: ὁπλοθήκη
div1.sense: an armoury, Plut.

div1.head: ὅπλομαι
div1.sense: to prepare, Il.

div1.head: ὁπλομανέω
div1.sense: to be madly fond of war, Anth.

div1.head: ὁπλομαχία
div1.sense: a fighting with heavy arms, the art of using them, Plat.:—generally, the art of war, tactics, Xen.

div1.head: ὁπλομάχος
div1.sense: fighting in heavy arms, Xen.
ὁπλ., one who teaches the use of arms, a drill-sergeant, Theophr.

div1.head: ὅπλον
div1.sense: a tool, implement, mostly in pl.:
a shipʼs tackle, tackling, Od., Hes.: esp. ropes, Od., Hdt.:—in sg. a rope, Od.
tools, of smithsʼ tools, Hom.:—in sg., ὅπλον ἀρούρης a sickle, Anth.; δείπνων ὅπλον, of a wine-flask, Anth.
in pl., also, implements of war, arms, Il., etc.:—rarely in sg., a weapon, Hdt., Eur.
in Attic, ὅπλον was the large shield, from which the men-at-arms took their name of ὁπλῖται, Ar., Thuc., etc.:—then, in pl., heavy arms, Hdt., Attic; ὅπλων ἐπιστάτης ὁπλίτης, Aesch.; whence,
ὅπλα, ὁπλῖται, men-at-arms, Soph., Thuc., etc.
τὰ ὅπλα, also, the place of arms, camp, Hdt., Xen.; ἐκ τῶν ὅπλων προϊέναι Thuc.
phrases, ἐν ὅπλοισι εἶναι to be in arms, under arms, Hdt.; εἰς τὰ ὅπλα παραγγέλλειν Xen.; ἐφʼ ὅπλοις or παρʼ ὅπλοις ἧσθαι Eur.; μένειν ἐπὶ τοῖς ὅπλοις Xen.; ὅπλα τίθεσθαι, v. τίθημι A. 1. 7.

div1.head: ὁπλοποιία
div1.sense: a making of arms, Il. 18, Strab.

div1.head: ὁπλότατος
div1.sense: youngest, Hom., Hes.—The orig. sense was perhaps (from ὅπλον), those capable of bearing arms, opp. to the old men and children, Il.:— but it soon came to mean simply younger or youngest; then, as the youngest are the last born, ἄνδρες ὁπλότεροι also means the latter generations, men of later days, Theocr.

div1.head: ὁπλότερος
div1.sense: comp. without any Posit. in use, the younger, Hom.; ὁπλότερος γενεῇ younger by birth, Lat. minor natu, Hom.; fem. gen. pl. ὁπλοτεράων Il.

div1.head: ὁπλοφορέω
div1.sense: to bear arms, be armed, Xen.
Pass. to have a body-guard, Plut.

div1.head: ὁπλοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing arms: a warrior, soldier, Eur., Xen.
= δορυφόρος, Xen.

div1.head: ὁποδαπός
div1.sense: of what country, what countryman, Lat. cujas, Hdt.; τίς καὶ ὁποδαπός Plat.

div1.head: ὁπόθεν
div1.sense: correlative to πόθεν:
chiefly in indirect questions, whence, from what place, Lat. unde, εἴρεαι ὁππόθεν εἰμέν thou askest whence we are, Od.
relat., γαμεῖν ὁπόθεν ἂν βούληται to marry a wife from whatever family he likes, Plat.:—also ὁποθενοῦν, Plat.

div1.head: ὁπόθι
div1.sense: correlative to πόθι, where, Il.
in indirect questions, εἰπέμεν ὁππόθʼ ὄλωλεν Od.

div1.head: ὁποῖος
div1.sense: correlat. to ποῖος·

as relat., of what sort or quality, Lat. qualis, ὁπποῖόν κʼ εἴπῃσθα ἔπος, τοῖόν κʼ ἐπακούσαις as is the word thou hast spoken, such shalt thou hear again, Il.; οὔθʼ οἷʼ ἔπασχεν οὔθʼ ὁποῖʼ ἔδρα κακά Soph.
in indirect questions, Od., etc.

with indefinite words added, ὁποῖός τις Hdt., Attic; ὁπποῖʼ ἄσσα of what sort was it, for ὁποῖά τινα, Od.;— ὁποιοσοῦν of what kind soever, Lat. qualiscunque, ὁποῖος δή, δήποτε, δηποτοῦν, and οὖν δή, Attic
neut. pl. used as adv. like as, Lat. qualiter, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ὅποι
div1.sense: correlat. to ποῖ:
to which place, whither, Lat. quo, Soph., etc.; ὅποι ἄν, with subjunct., whithersoever, Plat.:—in pregnant sense with Verbs of rest, διδάξαι μʼ ὅποι καθέσταμεν (i. e. ὅποι ἐλθόντες καθέσταμεν) Soph.
c. gen., ὅποι γῆς whither in the world, Lat. quo terrarum, Aesch., Ar.
in indirect questions, to what place, whither, ἀμηχανεῖν ὅποι τράποιντο Aesch.

div1.head: ὁποσάκις
div1.sense: as many times as, Lat. quoties, Xen.

div1.head: ὁποσάπους
div1.sense: how many feet long, Luc.

div1.head: ὁποσαχῇ
div1.sense: adv. at as many places as, Xen.

div1.head: ὁπόσος
div1.sense: correlat. to πόσος,

like ὅσος, of Number, as many as, Lat. quot, quotquot, Hom., etc.; ὁπόσαι ψάμαθοι κλονέονται, καθορᾶς Pind.; πᾶσι θεοῖς, ὁπόσοι τὴν Διὸς αὐλὴν εἰσοιχνεῦσιν Aesch.; τοσαῦτα, ὁπόσα σοι φίλον Plat.; ὁπόσους πλείστους ἐδυνάμην Xen.:—in Prose ὁπόσος ἄν with subj., ὁπόσοις ἂν δοκῇ Thuc.
of Quantity, as much as, of Size or Space, as great as, Lat. quantus, ὁπόσσον ἐπέσχε as far as it spread, Il.
with indefin. Particles added, ὁποσοσοῦν, how great or much soever, Lat. quantuscunque, Thuc.; Ion. dat. pl. fem. ὁκοσῃσιῶν, Hdt.;—so, ὁποσῳδήποτε Dem.
in indirect questions, ἠρώτων τὸ στράτευμα, ὁπόσον εἴη Xen.

div1.head: ὀπός
div1.sense: Lat. sapor, sap: esp. the juice of the figtree, used as rennet (τάμισος) for curdling milk, Il.

div1.head: ὁπόστος
div1.sense: in what relation of number, Lat. quotus, ὁπόστος εἰλήχει what number he had drawn, Plat.:— ὁποστοσοῦν, Lat. quotuscunque, Dem.

div1.head: ὁπόταν
div1.etym: related to ὅταν, as ὁπότε to ὅτε
div1.sense: Epic ὁππότε, κεν, adv., whensoever, Lat. quandocunque, with Subj., Hom., etc.:— ὁπότʼ ἂν τὸ πρῶτον, Lat. quum primum, Hhymn.

div1.head: ὁπότε
div1.sense: of Time, correlat. to πότε, much like ὅτε·
with the ind., when, Lat. quando, Hom.: —εἰς ὁπότε, with fut., when, by what time, λέγειν εἰς ὁπότʼ ἔσται Aeschin.
with the opt. in reference to the past, whenever, to express an event that has often occurred, ὁπότε Κρήτηθεν ἵκοιτο Il., etc.:—also in oratio obliqua, Soph., etc.
in indirect phrases, ἴδμεν, ὁππότε Τηλέμαχος νεῖται when he is to return, Od.; with opt., δέγμενος ὁππότε ναυσὶν ἐφορμηθεῖεν Il.
in causal sense, for that, because, since, like Lat. quando for quoniam, Theogn., Hdt., etc.: so ὁπότε γε, Lat. quandoquidem, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: ὁπότερος
div1.sense: as relat. which of two, whether of the twain, Lat. uter, Il., etc.:—properly in sg., but in pl. when there are several on either side, e. g. of two armies, Il., etc.:—also, ὁποτεροσοῦν Plat.
in indirect questions, Ζεὺς οἶδε, ὁπποτέρῳ θανάτοιο τέλος πεπρωμένον ἐστίν Il.; ἀσαφῶς ὁποτέρων ἀρξάντων, for ἀσαφὲς ὂν ὁπότεροι ἂν ἄρξωσιν, Thuc.
either of two, Lat. alteruter, Plat., etc.
adv. ὁποτέρως, in which of two ways, as relat., Thuc., etc.
also neut. ὁπότερον or -ερα as adv., in indirect questions, Lat. utrum, Hdt., Ar., etc.

div1.head: ὁποτέρωθε
div1.sense: from which of the two, from whether of the twain, Il.

div1.head: ὁποτέρωθι
div1.sense: on whether of the two sides, Xen.

div1.head: ὁποτέρωσε
div1.sense: to whichever of two sides, Thuc.
in which of two ways, ὁπ. βουληθείη Plat.

div1.head: ὅπου
div1.etym: relat. adv. of Place, properly gen. of an obsol. Pron. ὅπος, correlat. to ποῦ:
div1.sense: as a relat., Hdt., Attic;—sometimes with gen. loci, ὅπου γῆς, Lat. ubi terrarum, Plat.:— ἔσθʼ ὅπου in some places, Lat. est ubi, Aesch., Dem.:—with other Particles, ὅκου δή somewhere or other, Lat. nescio ubi, Hdt.:— ὅπου ἄν or ὅπουπερ ἄν, wherever, with Subjunct., Trag.:— ὁπουοῦν, Lat. ubicunque, Plat.

in indirect questions, ὄφρα πύθηαι πατρός, ὅπου κύθε γαῖα Od., etc.: —with Verbs of motion in pregnant sense, just as, reversely, ὅποι is used with Verbs of rest, κεῖνος δʼ ὅπου βέβηκεν, οὐδεὶς οἶδε Soph.:—in repeating a question, ἡ Λακεδαίμων ποῦ ʼστιν; Answ. ὅπου ʼστίν; (do you ask) where it is? Ar.
of Time or Occasion, like Lat. ubi, σιγᾶν ὅπου δεῖ Aesch., etc.
of Manner, οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπου there are no means by which, it is impossible that, Soph., Eur.
of Cause, whereas, Lat. quando, quoniam, Hdt., Attic;— ὅπουγε, Lat. quandoquidem Xen.

div1.head: ὀπτάζομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be seen, NTest.

div1.head: ὀπταλέος
div1.sense: roasted, broiled, Hom.

div1.head: ὀπτάνιον
div1.sense: a place for roasting, a kitchen, Ar.

div1.head: ὀπτασία
div1.sense: a vision, NTest.

div1.head: ὀπτάω
div1.etym: a part. pass. ὀπτεύμενος in Theocr.
div1.sense: to roast, broil, Hom., etc.; c. gen. partit., ὀπτῆσαί τε κρεῶν to roast some meat, Od.:— ὀπτᾶν was used of cooking by means of fire or dry heat, opp. to ἕψω to boil in water, which never appears in Hom.; and a Com. poet remarks that Homerʼs heroes ate only roast meat:—Pass., aor1 inf. ὀπτηθῆναι Od.
to bake bread, Hdt., Xen., Ar.:—also of bricks or pottery, to bake, burn, Hdt.
to bake, harden, of the sun, Bion.
metaph. in Pass. to be burned by love, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: ὀπτεύω
div1.sense: to see, Ar.

div1.head: ὀπτήρια
div1.sense: ὀπτήρια (sc. δῶρα) presents made by the bridegroom on seeing the bride without the veil: generally, presents for seeing, Eur.

div1.head: ὀπτήρ
div1.sense: one who looks or spies, a spy, scout, Lat. speculator, Od., Soph.
in Prose, an eyewitness, Xen.

div1.head: ὀπτίων
div1.sense: Lat. optio, an adjutant, Plut.

div1.head: ὀπτός
div1.sense: roasted, broiled, Od.; ἑφθὰ καὶ ὀπτά boiled meats and roast, Eur.
baked, Hdt.
of iron, forged, tempered, Soph.

div1.head: ὀπυίω
div1.sense: to marry, wed, take to wife, Hom., Hes., etc.
Pass. of the woman, to be married, Il.

div1.head: ὀπωπή
div1.sense: a sight or view, Od.
sight, power of seeing, Od.

div1.head: ὀπώρα
div1.sense: the part of the year between the rising of Sirius and of Arcturus (i. e. the end of July, all Aug., and part of Sept.), the end of summer, Od.: —later it was used for autumn, though φθινόπωρον or μετόπωρον were the proper terms for autumn, Ar., Xen.
since it was the fruit-time, it came to mean the fruit itself, Soph., Plat.
metaph. summer-bloom, i. e. the bloom of youth, Pind.

div1.head: ὀπωρίζω
div1.sense: to gather fruits, Plat.
to gather fruit off trees, c. acc., Hdt.

div1.head: ὀπωρινός
div1.sense: at the time of late summer, ἀστὴρ ὀπ., i. e. Sirius (cf. ὀπώρα 1), Hom.
div1.etym: ι Attic, ῑ in Hom. before another long syll.

div1.head: ὀπωροφορέω
div1.sense: to bear fruit, Anth.

div1.head: ὀπωροφόρος
div1.sense: bearing fruit, Anth.

div1.head: ὀπωρώνης
div1.sense: a fruiterer, Dem.

div1.head: ὅπως δή
div1.sense: how possibly, Il.
= ὁπωσοῦν, Plat.: —so, ὅπως δήποτε Dem.

div1.head: ὁπωσοῦν
div1.sense: or ὅπως, οὖν, in any way whatever, in some way or other, Lat. utcunque, Thuc., etc.;—so ὁπωστιοῦν, Plat.

div1.head: ὅπως ποτέ
div1.sense: how ever, Dem.

div1.head: ὅπως
div1.etym: compd. of the relat. ὅ or ὅς, and the adv. πῶς
div1.sense: Conj. of Manner, as, in such manner as, and with interrog. force how, in what manner, Lat. ut, quomodo.
FINAL CONJ., like ἵνα, that, in order that.
CONJ. OF MANNER, how, as:

Relative to ὥς or οὕτως, in such manner as, as, Lat. ut, sicut, ἔρξον ὅπως ἐθέλεις Hom.; with fut. Ind., esp. after Verbs of seeing, providing, taking care that, in what manner, how, ἔπρασσον ὅπως τις βοηθεία ἥξει Thuc.
with ἄν (Epic ke) and Subj. in indefinite sentences, just as, however, ὅππως κεν ἐθέλῃσιν Il.; οὕτως ὅπως ἂν αὐτοὶ βούλωνται Xen.
with opt. after historical tenses, οὕτως ὅπως βούλοιντο Xen.

οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπως there is no way in which, it cannot be that, οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπως σιγήσομαι Ar.; so, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅπως οὐ, fieri non potest quin, οὐκ ἔσθʼ ὅπως οὐ ναυτιᾷς Ar.: —so in questions, ἔσθʼ ὅπως ἔλθωμεν can we possibly come? Ar.
like ὡς in comparisons, as, like as, κῦμʼ ὅπως Aesch., etc.
also like ὡς or ὅτι, Lat. quam, with Sup. of Advs., ὅπως ἄριστα Aesch.; ὅπως ἀνωτάτω as high up as possible, Ar.
with a gen. added, σοῦσθε ὅπως ποδῶν (sc. ἔχετε) run as you are off for feet, i. e. as quick as you can, Aesch.
sometimes of Time, when, ὅπως ἴδον αἷμʼ Ὀδυσῆος Il., etc.; with opt., whenever, ὅπως μὲν εἴη καρπὸς ἁδρός Hdt.; with Sup. of Advs., ὅπως τάχιστα Aesch.

οὐχ ὅπως . . , ἀλλὰ . . , not only not . . but . . (where there is an ellipsis of λέγω or ἐρῶ) , οὐχ ὅπως κωλυταὶ . . . γενήσεσθε, ἀλλὰ καὶ . . . δύναμιν προσλαβεῖν περιόψεσθε, not only will you not become hinderers, but you will also . . , Thuc., etc.:—so sometimes μὴ ὅπως (where an imperat. must be supplied), μὴ ὅπως ὀρχεῖσθαι ἀλλʼ οὐδὲ ὀρθοῦσθαι ἐδύνασθε do not [think] that you can dance, but not even could you stand upright (i. e. so far from being able to dance), Xen.
in indirect questions, how, in what way or manner, οὐδὲ ἴδμεν ὅπως ἔσται τάδε ἔργα Il., etc.:—also λεύσσει ὅπως τι γένηται Il.
with Opt., after tenses of past time, μερμήριξεν ὅπως ἀπολοίατο νῆες Od.

ὅπως ἄν (κεν) with the Subj. makes the manner indefinite, πείρα ὅπως κεν δὴ σὴν πατρίδα γαῖαν ἵκηαι try how or that in some way or other, Od.; after Verbs of fear and caution, ὅπως and ὅπως μή are used with Fut. Ind. or Aor. Subj., δέδοιχʼ ὅπως μὴ τεύξομαι Ar.; ὅπως λάθω δέδοικα Eur.:—this construction is most freq. in an imperative sense, ἄθρει, ὅπως μὴ ἐκδύσεται Ar.:—hence ὅπως or ὅπως μή are used with fut. or Subj. just like the imperat., ὅπως παρέσει μοι πάρισθι, be present, Ar.;— ὅπως μὴ ᾖ τοῦτο Plat.
ὅπως is used as the echo to a preceding πῶς; in dialogue: A. καὶ πῶς; B. ὅπως; [dʼye ask] how? Ar.; A. πῶς με χρὴ καλεῖν; B. ὅπως; Ar.
as FINAL CONJ. that, in order that, Lat. quo
div1.etym: = ut, with Subj. after principal tenses, τὸν δὲ μνηστῆρες λοχῶσιν, ὅπως ὄληται Od.
div1.sense: with Opt. after historical tenses, πὰρ δέ οἱ ἔστη, ὅπως κῆρας ἀλάλκοι Il.
with Ind. of historical tenses, of consequence which has not followed or cannot follow, τί οὐκ ἔρριψʼ ἐμαυτὴν τῆσδʼ ἀπὸ πέτρας, ὅπως ἀπηλλάγην Aesch.

div1.head: ὅραμα
div1.sense: that which is seen, a sight, spectacle, Xen.

div1.head: ὅρασις
div1.sense: seeing, the act of sight, Lat. visus, Arist.
a vision, NTest.

div1.head: ὁρατός
div1.sense: to be seen, visible, Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὁράω
div1.sense: To see:

absol. to see or look, Hom., etc.; κατʼ αὐτοὺς αἰὲν ὅρα he kept looking down at them, Il.; ὁρόων ἐπὶ οἴνοπα πόντον looking over the sea, Il.:— ὁρᾶν πρός τι, like Lat. spectare ad, to look towards, ἀκρωτήριον τὸ πρὸς Μέγαρα ὁρῶν Thuc.

to have sight, Soph.: hence says Oedipus, ὅσʼ ἂν λέγωμεν, πάνθʼ ὁρῶντα λέξομεν [though I am blind], my words shall have eyes, i. e. shall be to the purpose, Soph.; ἀμβλύτερον ὁρᾶν to be dim-sighted, Plat.
to see to, look to, i. e. take heed, beware, ὅρα ὅπως . ., Ar.; ὅρα εἰ . . , see whether . . , Aesch., etc.
ὁρᾷς; ὁρᾶτε; seeʼst thou? dʼye see? parenthetically, esp. in explanations, like Lat. videnʼ? Ar.
c. acc. cogn. to look so and so, δεινὸν ὁρῶν ὄσσοισι Hes.; ἔαρ ὁρόωσα Theocr.
trans. to see an object, look at, behold, perceive, observe, c. acc., Hom., etc.; αἰεὶ τέρμʼ ὁρόων always keeping it in sight, Il.
poet. for ζάω, ζώει καὶ ὁρᾷ φάος Ἠελίοιο Hom.; so, φῶς ὁρᾶν Soph.; and in Mid., φέγγος ὁρᾶσθαι Eur.
to look out for, provide, τί τινι Soph., Theocr.
the inf. is used after an adj., δεινὸς ἰδεῖν terrible to behold, Solon; ἔχθιστος ὁρᾶν Soph., etc.
the Mid. is used by Poets just like the Act., Il., Aesch., etc.
Pass. to be seen, Aesch., etc.: also like φαίνομαι to let oneself be seen, appear, Plat.: τὰ ὁρώμενα all that is seen, things visible, Plat.
metaph., ὁρᾶν is used of mental sight, to discern, perceive, Soph., etc.; so blind Oedipus says, φωνῇ γὰρ ὁρῶ, τὸ φατιζόμενον I see by sound, as the saying is, Soph.

div1.head: ὀργάζω
div1.sense: to soften, knead, temper, Lat. subigere, Ar.:—Pass., ὠργασμένος well kneaded, Plat.

div1.head: ὀργαίνω
div1.sense: to make angry, enrage, Soph.
intr. to grow or be angry, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ὀργανικός
div1.sense: serving as instruments or engines, Plut. adv. -κῶς, by way of instruments, Arist.

div1.head: ὄργανον
div1.sense: an organ, instrument, tool, for making or doing a thing, Soph., Eur., etc.:—of a person, ἁπάντων ἀεὶ κακῶν ὄργ. Soph.
an organ of sense, Plat.
a musical instrument, Plat.
a surgical instrument, Xen.
a work, product, λαΐνεα Ἀμφίονος ὄργανα the stony works of Amphion, i. e. walls of Thebes, Eur.

div1.head: ὄργανος
div1.sense: working, ὀργάνη χείρ Eur.

div1.head: ὀργάς
div1.sense: ὀργάς (sc. γῆ) any well-watered, fertile spot, meadow-land, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: ὀργάω
div1.sense: to swell with moisture: of fruit, to swell and ripen, Hdt.; of corn, ὀργᾷ ἀμᾶσθαι is ripe for cutting, Hdt.
of persons, to wax wanton: then, generally, to be eager or ready, to be excited, Thuc.; ὀργῶν κρίνειν to judge under the influence of passion, Thuc.:—c. inf., ὄργα μαθεῖν be eager to learn, Aesch.
trans., like ὀργάζω, to soften, tan leather, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀργεών
div1.sense: at Athens, a citizen from every δῆμος, who had to perform certain sacrifices: then, generally, a priest, Aesch.:—an Epic acc. pl. ὀργειόνας in Hhymn.

div1.head: ὀργή
div1.sense: natural impulse or propension: oneʼs temper, temperament, disposition, nature, Hes., Theogn., etc.; ἀλωπέκων ὀργαῖς ἴκελοι Pind.; ὀργαὶ ἀστυνόμοι social dispositions, Soph.; πρὸς τὰ παρόντα τὰς ὀργὰς ὁμοιοῦν Thuc., etc.
passion, anger, wrath, Hdt., Soph., etc.; ὀργῇ χάριν δοῦναι Soph.; ὀργῇ εἴκειν Eur.; διʼ ὀργῆς ἔχειν τινά Thuc.; ἐν ὀργῇ ἔχειν or ποιεῖσθαί τινα Thuc., etc.
Adverbial usages, ὀργῇ, in anger, Hdt., etc.; so, διʼ ὀργῆς, ἐξ ὀργῆς, κατʼ ὀργήν Soph.; μετʼ ὀργῆς Plat.
Πανὸς ὀργαί panic fears (i. e. terrors sent by Pan), Eur.:—but, ὀργή τινος anger against a person or at a thing, Soph.; ἱερῶν ὀργάς wrath at or because of the rites, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀργιάζω
div1.sense: to celebrate orgies, Eur.: c. acc.cogn., ὀργ. τελετήν, ὄργια Plat.
to honour or worship with orgies, Strab.

div1.head: ὄργια
div1.sense: orgies, i. e. secret rites, secret worship, practised by the initiated alone, of the secret worship of Demeter at Eleusis, Hhymn., Ar.;—but, most commonly, of the rites of Bacchus, Hdt., Eur.
any worship, rites, sacrifices, Aesch., Soph.
div1.etym: Prob. from * ἔργω ἔρδω, ῥέζω, in the sense of performing sacred rites, sacra facere.

div1.head: ὀργιασμός
div1.sense: celebration of orgies, Strab.

div1.head: ὀργιαστικός
div1.sense: fit for orgies, exciting, Arist.

div1.head: ὀργίζω
div1.sense: to make angry, provoke to anger, irritate, Ar., Plat.

more common in Pass., with fut. mid. and pass. ὀργιοῦμαι, ὀργισθήσομαι: aor1 ὠργίσθην: perf. ὤργισμαι:— to grow angry, be wroth, Soph., etc.; τινι with a person or thing, Eur., Thuc., etc.; τὸ ὀργιζόμενον τῆς γνώμης their angry feelings, Thuc.

div1.head: ὀργίλος
div1.sense: prone to anger, irascible, Xen., Dem. adv., ὀργίλως ἔχειν to be angry, Dem.

div1.head: ὀργιλότης
div1.sense: irascibility, Arist.

div1.head: ὀργιοφάντης
div1.sense: a priest, one who initiates others into orgies, Anth.

div1.head: ὀργιστέος
div1.sense: one must be angry, Dem.

div1.head: ὀργυιαῖος
div1.sense: six feet long or large, Anth.

div1.head: ὄργυια
div1.note: ὄργυιᾰ, or ὀργυιά, Ionic -ή, ῆς, ἡ,
div1.sense: the length of the outstretched arms, about 6 feet, or 1 fathom, Hom., Hdt. (who says that 100 ὀργυιαί make one stadium).

div1.head: ὄρεγμα
div1.sense: an outstretching, Aesch.
a holding out, offering, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρέγνυμι
div1.sense: χεῖρας ὀρεγνύς Il.: Mid., χεῖρας ὀρεγνύμενος Anth.

div1.head: ὀρέγω
div1.sense: to reach, stretch, stretch out, Lat. porrigo, χεῖρʼ ὀρέγων Od.; esp. in entreaty, Od.
to reach out, hold out, hand, give, Hom., Hes., etc.
Mid. and Pass.,

absol. to stretch oneself out, stretch forth oneʼs hand, Hom.; ὀρέξασθαι ἀπὸ δίφρου to reach or lean over the chariot, Hes.; ἔγχει ὀρεξάσθω let him lunge with the spear (from the chariot, instead of dismounting), Il.; ποσσὶν ὀρωρέχαται πολεμίζειν, of horses, they stretched themselves, galloped, to the fight, Il.; ὀρέξατʼ ἰών he stretched himself as he went, i. e. went at full stride, Il.; ὀρωρέχατο προτὶ δειρήν stretched themselves with the neck (like Virgilʼs irasci in cornua, in clipeum assurgere), Il.:—of fish, to rise at the bait, Theocr.

c. gen. to reach at or to a thing, grasp at, οὗ παιδὸς ὀρέξατο he reached out to his child, Il.; also in a hostile sense, τοῦ Θρασυμήδης ἔφθη ὀρεξάμενος ὦμον hit him first on the shoulder, Il.; so, ἔφθη ὀρεξάμενος σκέλος (sc. αὐτοῦ) Il.
metaph. to reach after, grasp at, yearn for a thing, c. gen., Eur., Thuc., etc.:—c. inf., πόλιν ὠρέξατʼ οἰκεῖν Eur.
c. acc. to help oneself to, σῖτον Eur.

div1.head: ὀρειάρχης
div1.sense: mountain-king, i. e. Pan, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρειάς
div1.sense: of or belonging to mountains, πέτρα ὀρ. a mountain crag, Anth.
as Subst. an Oread, mountain-nymph, Bion.

div1.head: ὀρειβασία
div1.sense: a mountaineerʼs life, Strab.

div1.head: ὀρειβάσια
div1.sense: ὀρειβάσια (sc. ἱερά) a festival in which persons traversed the mountains, Strab.

div1.head: ὀρειβατέω
div1.sense: to roam the mountains, Anth., Plut.

div1.head: ὀρειβάτης
div1.sense: mountain-ranging, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ὀρειδρομία
div1.sense: a running on the hills, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρειδρόμος
div1.sense: running on the hills, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρεινόμος
div1.sense: mountain-ranging, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρεινός
div1.sense: mountainous, hilly, Hdt., Xen.
dwelling on the mountains, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: ὄρειος
div1.sense: of or from the mountains, mountain-haunting, Hhymn., Trag.

div1.head: ὀρειοχαρής
div1.sense: delighting in the hills, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρείτης
div1.sense: a mountaineer, Polyb.

div1.head: ὀρείφοιτος
div1.sense: mountain-roaming, Babr.

div1.head: ὀρείχαλκος
div1.sense: Lat. orichalcum, mountain-copper, i. e. copper ore, or copper made from it, Hes., Plat.

div1.head: ὀρεκτικός
div1.sense: of or for the desires, appetitive, Arist.; τὸ ὀρεκτικόν, the appetites, Arist.

div1.head: ὀρεκτός
div1.sense: stretched out, μελίαι ὀρ. pikes to be presented (not thrown), Il.

div1.head: ὄρεξις
div1.sense: desire, appetite, Arist.: c.gen. a longing or yearning after a thing, desire for it, Arist.

div1.head: ὀρεοπολέω
div1.sense: to haunt mountains, Luc.

div1.head: ὀρεσίτροφος
div1.sense: mountain-bred, Hom.

div1.head: ὀρέσκιος
div1.sense: overshadowed by mountains, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρεσκῷος
div1.sense: lying on mountains, mountainbred, of the Centaurs, Il.; of goats, Od.:—the Trag. form is ὀρέσκους, ουν, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ὀρέσσαυλος
div1.sense: mountain-dwelling, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρεσσιβάτης
div1.sense: mountain roaming, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρεσσίγονος
div1.sense: mountain-born, Ar.

div1.head: Ὀρέστεια
div1.sense: the tale of Orestes, the name of Aeschylusʼ Agamemnon, Choephoroe and Eumenides, being the only certain Trilogy extant, Ar.
Ὀρέστειον, τό, a temple of Orestes, Hdt.

div1.head: Ὀρέστειος
div1.sense: of Orestes, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρέστερος
div1.etym: poetic for ὀρεινός II, Hom., Trag.

div1.head: ὀρεστιάς
div1.sense: of the mountains, Νύμφαι ὀρεστιάδες Ὀρεάδες, Il.

div1.head: ὀρεύς
div1.sense: a mule, Il., Ar.
div1.etym: From ὄρος a mountain, mules being much used in mountainous countries.

div1.head: ὀρεχθέω
div1.etym: only in pres. and Epic imperf. ὀρέχθεον
div1.sense: either to stretch oneself or struggle in the throes of death (from ὀρέγομαι), or (akin to ῥοχθέω) , to gasp in the death-ruckle, Il.; of the heart, to palpitate, Ar.; of the sea, to stretch itself, i. e. roll up, to the beach, Theocr. (in Doric inf. ὀρεχθῆν) .

div1.head: ὀρεωκόμος
div1.sense: a muleteer, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: ὀρθιάδε
div1.sense: uphill, Xen.

div1.head: ὀρθιάζω
div1.sense: to speak in a high tone, ὀρθ. γόοις to shriek with loud wailings, Aesch.
trans., = ὀρθόω, to set upright, Anth.

div1.head: Ὀρθία
div1.sense: a name of Artemis in Laconia and Arcadia; at her altar the Spartan boys were whipped, Xen.

div1.head: ὀρθίασμα
div1.sense: a high pitch of voice: in pl. loud commanding tones, Ar.

div1.head: ὄρθιος
div1.sense: straight up, going upwards, steep, uphill, Hes., Eur.; ὄρθιον ἑτέραν (sc. ὁδὸν ἐπορεύοντο Thuc.; so, ὄρθιον or πρὸς ὄρθιον ἰέναι to march up-hill, Xen.; πρὸς ὄρθιον ἄγειν to lead by a steep path, Xen.:— τὰ ὄρθια the country from the coast upwards, Hdt.
upright, standing, Hdt., Eur.:— esp. of hair, Trag.: of animals, rampant, Pind.
of the voice, high-pitched, loud, shrill, Trag.; neut. as adv., ὄρθια ἤϋσε she cried aloud, Il.; ὄρθιον φωνεῖν Pind.
νόμος ὄρθιος the orthian strain, a favourite air at Athens, Hdt., Ar.; ὄρθιος alone, Ar.
in military language, ὄρθιοι λόχοι were companies formed in column, opp. to a line of battle, Xen.
generally, like ὀρθός, straight, Xen.; ἤθη ὄρθια straightforwardness, Plut.

div1.head: ὀρθοβατέω
div1.sense: to go straight on or upright, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρθόβουλος
div1.sense: right-counselling, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθοδαής
div1.sense: knowing rightly how to do a thing, c. inf., Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθοδίκας
div1.note: ὀρθο-δίκας (ῐ), Doric for ὀρθοδίκης, ου, ὁ,
div1.sense: judging righteously, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρθοδοξέω
div1.sense: to have a right opinion, Arist.

div1.head: ὀρθοδρομέω
div1.sense: to run straight forward, Xen.

div1.head: ὀρθοέπεια
div1.sense: correctness of diction, Plat.

div1.head: ὀρθόθριξ
div1.sense: with hair up-standing, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθόκραιρος
div1.sense: with straight horns, Hom.:—also of the two ends of a galley which turned up like horns, Il.

div1.head: ὀρθόκρανος
div1.sense: having a high head, lofty, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρθομαντεία
div1.sense: true prophecy, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθόμαντις
div1.sense: a true prophet, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρθονόμος
div1.sense: making right award, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθοποδέω
div1.sense: to walk uprightly, NTest.

div1.head: ὀρθόπολις
div1.sense: upholding the city, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρθόπους
div1.sense: with straight feet:
of a hill, steep, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρθός
div1.sense: straight, Lat. rectus:
in height, upright, erect, Hom., Hdt., Attic; ὀρθὸν οὖς ἱστάναι, i. e. to give attentive ear, Soph.:—of buildings, standing with their walls entire, τὸ Πάνακτον ὀρθὸν παραδοῦναι Thuc.

in line, straight, right, ὀρθὸς ἀντʼ ἠελίοιο right opposite the sun, Hes.; ὀρθὴ ὁδός Theogn.; ὀρθὴν κελεύεις, i. e. ὀρθὴν ὁδόν με κελεύεις ἰέναι, Ar.; διʼ ὀρθῆς (sc. ὁδοῦ) Soph.:—also, ὀρθᾷ χερί, ὀρθῷ ποδί straightway, Pind.; but ὀρθὸν πόδα τιθέναι is prob. to put the foot out, as in walking (cf. κατηρεφής I), Aesch.
βλέπειν ὀρθά, to see straight, opp. to being blind, Soph.; so, ἐξ ὀμμάτων ὀρθῶν, ὀρθοῖς ὄμμασιν, Lat. rectis oculis, Soph.
metaph.,
right, safe, happy, prosperous:
from signf. 1, ὀρθὸν ἱστάναι τινά ὀρθοῦν, to set up, restore, Pind., Eur.; so, στάντες τʼ ἐς ὀρθὸν καὶ πεσόντες ὕστερον Soph.; πλεῖν ἐπʼ ὀρθῆς (sc. νεώς, the state being represented as a ship), Soph.
from signf. II, κατʼ ὀρθὸν ἐξελθεῖν, of prophecies, Soph.; κατʼ ὀρθὸν οὐρίσαι to waft in straight course, Soph.

right, true, correct, Pind., Aesch., etc.; ὄρθʼ ἀκούειν to be rightly called, Soph.; ὀρθῷ λόγῳ strictly speaking, in very truth, Hdt.:—so in adv., ὀρθῶς λέγειν Hdt.; ὀ. φράσαι Aesch., etc.; ὀρθῶς ἔχει ʼtis right, c. inf., Plat.:—Sup. ὀρθότατα Hdt.
real, genuine, Arist.:— ὀρθῶς, really, truly, Plat.
upright, righteous, just, Soph., etc.; κατὰ τὸ ὀρθὸν δικάζειν Hdt.:—adv. ὀρθῶς, rightly, justly, Thuc.
of persons, steadfast, firm, Plat.
ἡ ὀρθή,
(sub. ὁδός) , v. supr. II.
(sub. γωνία) a right angle, Plat., etc.
(sub. πτῶσις) the nominative, Lat. casus rectus.
adv. ὀρθῶς, v. supr. III. 2-4.

div1.head: ὀρθοστάδην
div1.sense: standing upright, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθοστάτης
div1.sense: one who stands upright: an upright shaft, pillar, Eur.
a sort of cake used in funeral oblations, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρθόστατος
div1.sense: upstanding, upright, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρθότης
div1.sense: upright posture, erectness, Xen.
metaph. rightness, correctness, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ὀρθοτομέω
div1.sense: to cut in a straight line: metaph., ὀρθ. τὸν λόγον to teach it aright, NTest.

div1.head: ὀρθόω
div1.sense: to set straight:

in height, to set upright, set up one fallen or lying down, raise up, Il.; ὀρθοῦν κάρα, πρόσωπον Eur.:—of buildings, to raise up, rebuild, or, generally, to erect, build up, Eur., Thuc.:—Pass. to be set upright, Il., etc.: simply to rise from oneʼs seat, stand up, Aesch., Soph.
in line, to make straight, Arist.:— Pass., ἢν τόδʼ ὀρθωθῆι βέλος if this dart go straight, Soph.
metaph. (from signf. I) to raise up, restore to health, safety, happiness, Hdt., Aesch., etc.:—also to exalt, honour, Pind.

(from signf. II) to guide aright, Aesch.; ὀρθ. ἀγῶνας to bring to a happy end, Aesch.; ὀ. βίον Soph.:—Pass. to succeed, prosper, Hdt., Soph., etc.; τὸ ὀρθούμενον success, Thuc.:—of words and opinions, to be right, true, Hdt., Eur.; ἐν ἀγγέλωι κρυπτὸς ὀρθοῦται λόγος a secret message is rightly sent by messenger, not by letter, Aesch.
in Pass. also, to be upright, deal justly, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθρεύω
div1.sense: to rise early, to be awake early, Eur., Theocr.:—also in Mid., γόοισιν ὀρθρευομένα rising up early with groans, Eur.

div1.head: ὄρθριος
div1.sense: at day-break, in the morning, early, mostly with Verbs of motion, so as to agree with the person, ἀφίκετο ὄρθριος Hhymn.; ὄρθριος ἥκειν Plat.; also, ὄρθριον ᾄδειν (sc. ᾆσμα) , of the cock, Ar.:— τὸ ὄρθριον as adv., in the morning, early, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀρθροβόης
div1.sense: the early caller, chanticleer, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρθρογόη
div1.sense: the early-wailing, Hes.

div1.head: ὀρθρολάλος
div1.sense: early-twittering, Anth.

div1.head: ὄρθρος
div1.sense: day-break, dawn, cock-crow, Hhymn., Ar.; ὄρθρου at dawn, Hes.; ὄρθρου γενομένου Hdt.; ἅμα ὄρθρῳ Hdt., etc.; also, τὸν ὄρθρον, absol., in the morning, Hdt.; διʼ ὄρθρων each morning early, Eur.:— ὄρθρος βαθύς early dawn, just before daybreak, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ὀρθροφοιτοσυκοφαντοδικοταλαίπωροι
div1.sense: ὀρθρο-φοιτο-σῡκοφαντο-δικο-ταλαίπωροι τρόποι, early-prowling-base -informing-sad-litigious-plaguy ways, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρθώνυμος
div1.sense: rightly named, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρθωτήρ
div1.sense: one who sets upright, a restorer, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρίγανον
div1.sense: a bitter herb, marjoram, ὀρίγανον βλέπειν to look origanum, i. e. to look sour or crabbed, Ar.

div1.head: ὀριγνάομαι
div1.sense: to stretch oneself, ἔγχεσιν ὠριγνῶντο they fought with outstretched spears, Hes.
c. gen. to stretch oneself after a thing, reach at, grasp at, Eur., Theocr.

div1.head: ὁρίζω
div1.sense: to divide or separate from, as a boundary, c. acc. et gen., ὁ Νεῖλος τὴν Ἀσίην οὐρίζει τῆς Λιβύης Hdt.:—with two accs. joined by καί, to separate, be a boundary between, Τύρης ποταμὸς οὐρίζει τήν τε Σκυθικὴν καὶ τὴν Νευρίδα γῆν Hdt.
to bound, Thuc., Xen.:—Pass. to be bounded, Eur.; metaph., ὡρίσθω μέχρι τοῦδε so far let it go and no further, Thuc.
to pass between or through, διδύμους πέτρας Eur.
to part and drive away, banish, Eur.:—Pass. to depart from Eur.
to mark out by boundaries, mark out, Hdt., Soph.; so, ὁρ. θεόν to mark out his sanctuary, Eur.

to limit, determine, appoint, lay down, Trag., Xen.:—so, c. inf. to appoint, order, Eur.:—so, θάνατον ὥρισε τὴν ζημίαν determined the penalty to be death, Dem.:—Pass., perf. part. ὡρισμένος determinate, definite, Arist.
to define a word, mostly in Mid., Xen., etc.
Mid. to mark out for oneself, take possession of, Aesch., Eur.: —ὁρίζεσθαι βωμούς, στήλας to set them up, Soph., Xen.
to determine for oneself, to get a thing determined, Dem.
to define a word, Plat.;— c. acc. et inf., Xen., etc.
intr. to border upon, Hdt.
as Attic law-term, δισχιλίων ὡρισμένος τὴν οἰκίαν having the house marked with ὅροι (cf. ὅρος II), i. e. mortgaged to the amount of 2000 drachms, Dem.

div1.head: ὀρικός
div1.sense: of or for a mule, ὀρ. ζεῦγος a pair of mules, Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὀρίνω
div1.sense: to stir, raise, agitate, Hom.: metaph., θυμὸν ὀρίνειν Hom.:—Pass., ὠρίνετο θυμός his heart was stirred within him, Od.

div1.head: ὅριον
div1.sense: a boundary, limit, in pl. boundaries, the borders, frontier, Eur., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ὅριος
div1.sense: of boundaries, Ζεὺς ὅριος guardian of land-marks, Lat. Terminus, Dem.

div1.head: ὅρισμα
div1.sense: a boundary, limit, and in pl., boundaries, the borders, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: ὁρισμός
div1.sense: a marking out by boundaries, limitation, Arist.
the definition of a word, Arist.

div1.head: ὁριστέος
div1.sense: one must determine, Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὁριστής
div1.sense: one who marks the boundaries; in pl. officers appointed to settle boundaries, Plut.
one who determines, Dem.

div1.head: ὀρίτροφος
div1.sense: mountain-bred, Babr.

div1.head: ὁρκάνη
div1.sense: an enclosure, fence, Aesch.: a net, trap, or pitfall, Eur.

div1.head: ὁρκαπάτης
div1.sense: an oath-breaker, Anth.

div1.head: ὁρκίζω
div1.sense: to make one swear, Xen., Dem.; ὁρκίζω σε τὸν Θεόν I adjure one by God, NTest.

div1.head: ὅρκιον
div1.sense: an oath, Hom., etc.

mostly in pl., ὅρκια, τά, that which is sworn to, the articles of a treaty, Hom., etc.; ὅρκια πιστὰ ταμεῖν (v. τέμνω II), Il.:—on the other hand, ὅρκια δηλήσασθαι or ὑπὲρ ὅρκια δηλ. to violate a solemn treaty, Il.; ὅρκια πατῆσαι to trample on the treaties, Il.; so, ὅρκια συγχεῦαι, ψεύσασθαι Il.
the victims sacrificed on taking these solemn oaths, Il.
a surety resting on oath, in sg., Pind., Ar.

div1.head: ὅρκιος
div1.sense: belonging to an oath, i. e.
sworn, bound by oath, Aesch.; ὅρκιος λέγω I speak as if on oath, Soph.
that which is sworn by, ὅρκιοι θεοί the gods invoked to witness an oath, Eur.; so, θεοὶ οἱ ὅρκ. Thuc.; esp., Ζεὺς ὅρκιος Soph., Eur.; ξίφος ὅρκιον a sword sworn by, Eur.

div1.head: ὁρκισμός
div1.sense: administration of an oath, Plut.

div1.head: ὅρκος
div1.sense: the object by which one swears, the witness of an oath, as the Styx among the gods, Hom., etc.:—hence,

an oath, Hom., etc.; ὅρκος θεῶν an oath by the gods, Od.; ὅρκον ὀμόσαι to swear an oath, Hom., etc.; ὅρκον ἐπιορκεῖν to take a false oath, Aeschin.; ὅρκον διδόναι καὶ δέξασθαι to tender an oath to another and accept the tender from him, Hdt., Attic; ὅρκον ἀποδιδόναι to take an oath, ἀπολαμβάνειν to tender it, Dem.; so, ὅρκον διδόναι καὶ λαμβάνειν Arist.; ὅρκοις τινὰ καταλαμβάνειν to bind one by oaths, Thuc.; ὅρκῳ ἐμμένειν to abide by it, Eur.; εἶπαι ἐπʼ ὅρκου to say on oath, Hdt.
Ὅρκος, personified, son of Ἔρις, a divinity, who punishes the perjured, Hes., etc.
div1.etym: ὅρκος was orig. equiv. to ἕρκος, as ὁρκάνη to ἑρκάνη, from ἔργω, εἴργω, properly, that which restrains from doing a thing.

div1.head: ὁρκόω
div1.sense: to bind by oath, Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ὅρκωμα
div1.sense: an oath, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁρκωμοσία
div1.sense: a swearing, an oath, Epic

div1.head: ὁρκωμόσια
div1.sense: asseverations on oath, Plat.
