the sacrifice on taking an oath, Plat.
ὁρκωμόσιον, τό, the place where a treaty has been sworn to, Plut.

div1.head: ὁρκωμοτέω
div1.sense: to take an oath, Trag.:— foll. by inf. aor., ὁρκ. θεοὺς τὸ μὴ δρᾶσαι to swear by the gods that they did it not, Soph.; by inf. fut., Ἄρη ὡρκωμότησαν λαπάξειν made oath by Ares that they would destroy, Aesch.

div1.head: ὁρκωτής
div1.sense: the officer who administers the oath, Xen.

div1.head: ὁρμαθός
div1.sense: a string, chain, or cluster of things hanging one from the other, as of bats, Od.; so, ὁρμ. κριβανιτῶν, ἰσχάδων Ar.

div1.head: ὁρμαίνω
div1.etym: only in pres., imperf. and aor1 ὥρμηνα
div1.sense: to turn over or revolve anxiously in the mind, to debate, ponder, Lat. animo volvere, ὁρμαίνειν τι κατὰ φρένα or ἐνὶ φρεσί Hom.:—so also ὁρμαίνειν τι alone, to ponder over, meditate, πόλεμον, ὁδόν Hom.
absol., ὣς ὥρμαινε thus he debated with himself, Il.
foll. by a relat. clause, ἤ . . , ἤ . . , to debate whether . . , or . . , Hom.; ὁρμ. ὅπως . . , to debate, ponder how a thing is to be done, Il.
c. inf. to long, desire, wish, Theocr.
after Hom.,
to set in motion, θυμὸν ὁρμ. to gasp out oneʼs life, Aesch.; to excite, urge, Pind.
intr. to be eager, to chafe, fret, Aesch.; part. ὁρμαίνων eagerly, Pind.

div1.head: ὁρμάω
div1.sense: Act.
Causal, to set in motion, urge or push on, spur on, cheer on, Il., Hdt., Attic:—Pass., ὁρμηθεὶς θεοῦ inspired by the god, Od.; so, πρὸς θεῶν ὡρμημένος Soph.
with a thing as the object, to stir up, πόλεμον Od.:— Pass., ὡρμάθη πλαγά was inflicted, Soph.
intr. to make a start, hasten on,
c. inf., ὃς ὁρμήσῃ διώκειν who starts in chase, Il.; ὁσσάκι δʼ ὁρμήσειε πυλάων ἀντίον ἀΐξασθαι whenever he started to rush against the gates, Il.: to begin to do, Hdt., Soph.
c. gen. to rush headlong at one, Il.; so, ὁρμᾶν ἐπί τινα Hdt., etc.; εἴς τινα, κατά τινα Xen.; ἐπὶ τὸ σκοπεῖν Xen., etc.: also, ὁρμ. ἐς μάχην to hasten to battle, Aesch.; εἰς ἀγῶνα Eur.
absol. to start, begin, Plat.; αἱ μάλιστα ὁρμήσασαι νῆες the ships that had got the greatest start, Thuc.
Mid. and Pass., like intr. Act.:

c. inf., μὴ φεύγειν ὁρμήσωνται that they put not themselves in motion to flee, think of fleeing, Il.; so, διώκειν ὡρμήθησαν Il.; ὁ λόγος οὗτος ὡρμήθη λέγεσθαι this account began to be given, was taken in hand, Hdt.; but, λόγον, τὸν ὥρμητο λέγειν which he purposed to make, Hdt.; and with the inf. omitted, μενεήναμεν ὁρμηθέντε we eagerly desired, Od.
c. gen. to hasten after, Hom.; so, ὁρμᾶσθαι ἐπί τινι Od.; ἐπί τινα Soph., etc.:—rarely c. acc. loci, νερτέρας πλάκας Soph.

to start from, begin from, ἐνθεῦτεν ὁρμώμενοι going out from thence to do oneʼs daily work, Hdt.; so of a general, to make a place his headquarters or base of operations, Hdt., Thuc.; so, ὁρμ. ἀπὸ Σάρδεων Xen.; ἀπʼ ἐλασσόνων ὁρμώμενος setting out, beginning, with smaller means, Thuc.
absol. to rush on, Hom.:—generally, to hasten, be eager, Aesch.: to go forth, τὸ φέγγος ὁρμάσθω πυρός Aesch.; ὕβρις ἀτάρβητος ὁρμᾶται insult goes fearless forth, Soph.
in a really pass. sense, πρὸς θεῶν ὡρμημένος incited by the gods, Soph.

div1.head: ὁρμέω
div1.sense: to be moored, lie at anchor, of a ship, Hdt., Eur., etc.:—proverb. phrases, ἐπὶ δυοῖν ἀγκύραιν ὁρμεῖν, v. ἄγκυρα; μέγας ἐπὶ σμικροῖς ὁρμεῖν to be dependent on small matters, Soph.

div1.head: ὅρμημα
div1.sense: stir, impulse, Ἑλένης ὁρμήματά τε στοναχάς τε longings and sighs [of the Greeks] for Helen, or, their struggles and sighs for her recovery (Ἑλένης being an objective gen.), Il.

div1.head: ὁρμή
div1.sense: a violent movement onwards, an assault, attack, onset, Lat. impetus, Il., Hdt., Xen.
of things, πυρὸς ὁρμή the rage of fire, Il.; ὑπὸ κύματος ὁρμῆς by the shock of a wave, Od.; ἐς ὁρμὴν ἔγχεος ἐλθεῖν within reach of my spear, Il.

the first stir or start in a thing, an effort or attempt to reach a thing, impulse to do it, Hom., Hdt., Attic:— μιᾷ ὁρμῇ with one impulse, Lat. uno impetu, Xen.; so, ἀπὸ μιᾶς ὁρμῆς Thuc.:—c. gen. objecti, eager desire of or for a thing, Thuc.
a start on a march, ἐν ὁρμῇ εἶναι to be on the point of starting, Xen.

div1.head: ὁρμητήριον
div1.sense: any means of stirring up or rousing, a stimulant, incentive, Xen.
(from Mid. ὁρμάομαι) , a starting place, military position, base of operations, point dʼ appui, Dem., etc.

div1.head: ὁρμιά
div1.sense: a fishing-line of horsehair, Eur., Theocr.

div1.head: ὁρμίζω
div1.sense: to bring to a safe anchorage, bring into harbour, to moor, anchor, Od., etc.; οἴκαδε ὁρμ. πλάτην to bring the ship safe home, Eur.:—metaph. to put a child to sleep, Aesch.
Mid. and Pass. to come to anchor, lie at anchor, anchor, Hdt., Attic:—metaph., ὁρμίζεσθαι ἐκ τύχης to be dependent on fortune, Eur.

div1.head: ὁρμιηβόλος
div1.sense: throwing a line, Anth.

div1.head: ὁρμοδοτήρ
div1.sense: harbour-giver, of a god, Anth.

div1.head: ὅρμος
div1.sense: a cord, chain, esp. a necklace, collar, Hom., Attic
generally, anything strung like a necklace, a wreath, chaplet, Pind.; στεφάνων ὅρμος a string of crowns, i. e. of praises, Pind.
a dance performed in a ring, Luc.
a roadstead, anchorage, moorings, Il., Hdt., Attic
metaph. a haven, place of shelter or refuge, Eur., Anth.
= ἕρμα 1, Anth.

div1.head: ὄρνεον
div1.sense: a bird, Il., Ar.
τὰ ὄρνεα the bird-market, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρνεόφοιτος
div1.sense: frequented by birds, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρνίθαρχος
div1.sense: king of birds, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρνίθειος
div1.sense: of or belonging to a bird, ὀρνίθεια (sc. κρέα) fowlʼs flesh, chicken, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρνιθευτής
div1.sense: a fowler, bird-catcher, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ὀρνιθευτικός
div1.sense: of or for bird-catching: —ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) , the art of bird-catching, fowling, Plat.

div1.head: ὀρνιθεύω
div1.sense: to catch or trap birds, Xen.

div1.head: ὀρνιθικός
div1.sense: of or for birds, Luc.

div1.head: ὀρνίθιον
div1.sense: a small bird, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀρνιθόγονος
div1.sense: sprung from a bird, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρνιθοθήρας
div1.sense: a bird-catcher, fowler, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρνιθομανέω
div1.sense: to be bird-mad, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρνιθομανής
div1.sense: bird-mad, Ath.

div1.head: ὀρνιθοπέδη
div1.sense: a snare for birds, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρνιθοσκόπος
div1.sense: observing and predicting by the flight and cries of birds: —θᾶκος ὀρν. an augurʼs seat, Lat. templum augurale, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρνιθοτροφία
div1.sense: a keeping of birds, Plut.

div1.head: ὄρνις
div1.etym: gen. ὄρνῑθος; acc. ὄρνιθα and ὄρνιν
div1.sense: a bird, Hom., etc.; often added to the specific names, ὄρνισιν ἐοικότες αἰγυπιοῖσιν Il.; λάρῳ ὄρνιθι ἐοικώς Od.; ὄ. ἀηδών, πέρδιξ Soph.; ὄ. ἁλκυών, ὄ. κύκνος Eur.
like οἰωνός, a bird of omen, from the flight or cries of which the augur divined, Hom., Soph.
metaph., like Lat. avis for augurium, the omen or prophecy taken from the flight or cries of birds, Hom., etc.:—then, generally, an omen, presage, without direct reference to birds, Il.
in Attic, ὄρνις, is mostly a cock, ὄρνις, ἡ, a hen, Soph., Ar., etc.
in pl. sometimes the bird-market, Ar., Dem.
Μοισᾶν ὄρνιθες birds of the Muses, i. e. Poets, Theocr.:— proverb., ὀρνίθων γάλα "pigeonʼs milk, " i. e. any marvellous dainty or good fortune, Ar.

div1.head: ὄρνυμι
div1.etym: * !ὄρω is the Root from which most tenses are formed
to the Med also belongs the pf. ὄρωρα (once ὤρορε)
div1.sense: radical sense to stir, stir up: esp.,

of bodily movement, to set on, urge on, incite, Il., Hes.: —c. inf., Ζεὺς ὦρσε μάχεσθαι urged him on to fight, Il.:—Mid., with perf. ὄρωρα, to move, stir oneself, εἰσόκε μοι φίλα γούνατʼ ὀρώρηι while my limbs have power to move, Hom.; aor1 imperat. ὄρσεο, ὄρσευ, ὄρσο rouse thee! up! arise! Hom.:—in hostile sense, to rush on, rush furiously, Il., Aesch., etc.

to make to arise, to awaken, call forth, Il.; of animals, to rouse, start, chase, Hom.:—Mid. to arise, start up, esp. from bed, Il.; in perf. mid., ὤρορε θεῖος ἀοιδός Od.:—c. inf. to rise to do a thing, set about it, ὦρτο ἴμεν Il.; ὦρτο Ζεὺς νιφέμεν started or began to snow, Il.

to call forth, excite, Lat. ciere, of storms and the like, which the gods call forth, Hom., Aesch.; so ὄρσαι ἵμερον, φόβον, μένος, πόλεμον, etc., Hom.:—Mid. to break forth, arise, Lat. orior, Il.; ὄρνυται πένθος, στόνος, etc., Il.; δοῦρα ὄρμενα πρόσσω the darts flying onwards, Il.

div1.head: ὀρόγυια
div1.sense: poet. for ὀργυιά.

div1.head: ὀροδαμνίς
div1.sense: a sprig, spray, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀρόδαμνος
div1.sense: a branch, Anth.

div1.head: ὀροθύνω
div1.sense: to stir up, rouse, urge on, excite, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: ὄρομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to watch, keep watch and ward, Il.

div1.head: ὀρομαλίδες
div1.sense: wild apples, Theocr.

div1.head: Ὀροσάγγαι
div1.sense: Persian word for benefactors, Hdt.

div1.head: ὄρος
div1.sense: a mountain, hill, Hom., etc.; pl. οὔρεα, Hom.

div1.head: ὅρος
div1.sense: a boundary, landmark, and in pl. bounds, boundaries, Il., etc.:— the boundary between two places is expressed by putting both in gen., οὖρος τῆς Μηδικῆς καὶ τῆς Λυδικῆς Hdt.: generally, a boundary, limit, ἑβδομήκοντα ἔτη οὖρον τῆς ζόης ἀνθρώπῳ προτίθημι I set 70 years as the limit of human life, Hdt.; metaph. of a womanʼs mind, Aesch.
in pl. marking-stones (στῆλαι, cippi), bearing inscriptions, Hdt.: in Attic Law, stone tablets set up on mortgaged lands as a register of the debt, Dem.
a limit, rule, standard, measure, Plat., Dem., etc.
an end, aim, Dem., etc.
in Aristotleʼs Logic, the term of a proposition:—its definition, species: so, in Mathematics, ὅροι are the terms of a ratio or proportion, Arist.

div1.head: ὀρός
div1.sense: Lat. serum, the watery part of milk, whey, Od.

div1.head: ὀροτύπος
div1.sense: driven from the mountain, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρούω
div1.sense: to rise and rush violently on, to move quickly, rush on, hasten, dart forward, Hom., etc.
c. gen. objecti, to rush at, strive after, Pind.
c. inf. to be eager to do, Pind.

div1.head: ὀροφή
div1.sense: the roof of a house, or the ceiling of a room, Od., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὀροφηφάγος
div1.sense: roof-destroying, Anth.

div1.head: ὀροφηφόρος
div1.sense: bearing a roof, Anth.

div1.head: ὀροφίας
div1.sense: living under a roof, μῦς ὀρ. the common mouse, opp. to μ. ἀρουραῖος, Ar.

div1.head: ὄροφος
div1.sense: in collective sense, the reeds used for thatching houses, Il.
= ὀροφή, a roof, Orac. ap. Hdt., Aesch., etc.

div1.head: ὄρπηξ
div1.note: .ὄρπηξ, Attic ὅρπηξ, ηκος, Doric ὄρπαξ, ᾱκος,
div1.sense: a sapling, young tree, Il., Theocr.
anything made of such trees, a goad, Hes.; a lance, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρροπύγιον
div1.sense: the rump of birds:—generally, the tail or rump of any animal, Ar.

div1.head: ὄρρος
div1.sense: the rump, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρρωδέω
div1.sense: to fear, dread, shrink from, c. acc., Hdt., Eur., etc.: c. gen. rei, to fear for or because of a thing, Hdt.; so, ὀρρ. περί τινος etc.
div1.etym: Formed so as to express the shuddering of fear.

div1.head: ὀρρωδία
div1.sense: terror, affright, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: ὀρσίκτυπος
div1.sense: stirring or making noise, Ζεὺς ὀρς. the rouser of thunder, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρσινεφής
div1.sense: cloud-raising, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρσίπους
div1.sense: swift-footed, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρσοθύρη
div1.sense: prob. a door approached by steps, a side-door, Od.

div1.head: ὀρσολοπεύω
div1.sense: to irritate, provoke, Hhymn.:— Pass., θυμὸς ὀρσολοπεῖται my heart is troubled, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρσόλοπος
div1.sense: eager for the fray, of Ares, Anacr.

div1.head: ὀρσοτρίαινα
div1.sense: wielder of the trident, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρτάλιχος
div1.sense: a chick, chicken, Ar., Theocr.:— generally, a young bird, Aesch. Boeot. word.

div1.head: Ὀρτυγία
div1.sense: quail-island, ancient name of Delos, whence Artemis is called Ὀρτυγία, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρτυγοθήρας
div1.sense: a quail-catcher, Plat.

div1.head: ὀρτυγομήτρα
div1.sense: a bird which migrates with the quails, perh. the land-rail, ludicrously applied to Latona, the Ortygian mother (cf. Ὀρτυγία) , Ar.

div1.head: ὀρτυγοτρόφος
div1.sense: keeping quails, Plat.

div1.head: ὄρτυξ
div1.sense: the quail, Lat. coturnix, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ὄρυγμα
div1.sense: a trench, ditch, moat, Lat. scrobs, Hdt., Thuc., etc.: a tunnel, mine, Hdt., Xen.: —ὄρ. τύμβου the grave, Eur.
= ὄρυξις, Luc.

div1.head: ὀρυκτός
div1.sense: formed by digging, opp. to a natural channel, Il., Hdt., Attic

div1.head: ὀρυμαγδός
div1.sense: a loud noise, din, Hom.; ὀρ. δρυτόμων the sound of wood-cutters, Il.; the rattling made by throwing a bundle of wood on the ground, Od.; of the roar of a torrent, Il.

div1.head: ὄρυξις
div1.sense: a digging, Plut.

div1.head: ὄρυξ
div1.sense: a pickaxe, Anth.

div1.head: ὄρυς
div1.sense: a Libyan animal, perh. an antelope, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀρύσσω
div1.sense: to dig a trench, etc., Hom., Hdt., Attic; τὸ ὀρυχθέν ὄρυγμα, α trench, Hdt.
to dig up a plant, Od.: —Mid., λίθους ὀρύξασθαι to have stones dug or quarried, Hdt.:—Pass., ὁ ὀρυσσόμενος χοῦς the soil that was dug up, Od.
to dig through, i. e. make a canal through, (like διορύσσειν) , τὸν ἰσθμὸν ὀρ. Orac. ap. Hdt.; τὸ χωρίον ὀρώρυκτο Hdt.
to bury, ἔγχος ὀρύξας Soph.
πὺξ ὀρ., of a pugilist, to give a dig or heavy blow, Ar.

div1.head: ὀρφάνευμα
div1.sense: orphan state, orphanhood, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρφανεύω
div1.sense: to take care of, rear orphans, Eur.: —Pass. c. fut. mid. to be an orphan, Eur.

div1.head: ὀρφανία
div1.sense: orphanhood, Plat.
bereavement, want of, στεφάνων Pind.

div1.head: ὀρφανίζω
div1.sense: to make orphan, make destitute, Eur.:—c. gen. to bereave of a thing, Pind.:—Pass. to be bereaved of, Soph.: absol. to be left in orphanhood, Pind.

div1.head: ὀρφανικός
div1.sense: orphaned, fatherless, Il.; ἦμαρ ὀρφανικόν the day which makes one an orphan, i. e. orphanhood, Il.
of or for orphans, Plat.

div1.head: ὀρφάνιος
div1.sense: desolate, Anth.

div1.head: ὀρφανιστής
div1.sense: a tender of orphans, a guardian, Soph.

div1.head: ὀρφανόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be destitute of, c. gen., Anth.

div1.head: ὀρφανός
div1.sense: Lat. orbus, orphan, without parents, fatherless, Od., Hes., Attic:—as Subst., an orphan, Plat.
c. gen. bereaved or bereft,
of children, ὀρφ. πατρός reft of father, Eur.
of parents, ὀρφ. παίδων Eur.; νεοσσῶν ὀρφανὸν λέχος Soph.
generally, ὀρφ. ἑταίρων Pind.; ἐπιστήμης Plat., etc.

div1.head: ὀρφανοφύλαξ
div1.sense: guardian of an orphan who had lost the father in war, Xen.

div1.head: Ὀρφεοτελεστής
div1.sense: one who initiates into the mysteries of Orpheus: generally, a hierophant, Theophr.

div1.head: Ὀρφεύς
div1.sense: Orpheus, a famous Thracian bard, Pind., etc.:—adj. Ὄρφειος, η, ον of Orpheus, Orphic, Eur.; so, Ὀρφικός, ή, όν, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀρφναῖος
div1.sense: dark, dusky, murky, Hom., Eur., etc.
nightly, by night, Aesch.

div1.head: ὄρφνη
div1.sense: the darkness of night, night, Theogn., Pind., Eur.

div1.head: ὄρφνινος
div1.sense: brownish gray, Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὄρχαμος
div1.sense: the first of a row, a file-leader: then, generally, a leader, chief, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: ὄρχατος
div1.sense: a row of trees or plants, Il.:— as collective noun, a garden, Od.

div1.head: ὀρχέομαι
div1.sense: to dance in a row, and generally, to dance, Hom., etc.; δώσω τοι Τεγέην ὀρχήσασθαι will give thee Tegea to dance in or on, Orac. ap. Hdt.; c. acc. cogn., Λακωνικὰ σχήματα ὀρχεῖσθαι to dance Laconian figures, Hdt.
trans. to represent by pantomimic dancing, ὀρχεῖσθαι τὸν Αἴαντα (as Horace, Cyclopa moveri), Luc.
metaph. to bound, ὀρχεῖται καρδία φόβωι Aesch.

div1.head: ὀρχηδόν
div1.sense: in a row, one after another, man by man, Lat. viritim, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀρχηθμός
div1.sense: a dancing, the dance, Hom.

div1.head: ὄρχημα
div1.sense: in pl. dances, dancing, Soph., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὄρχησις
div1.sense: dancing, the dance, Hdt., Attic:esp. pantomimic dancing, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: ὀρχηστής
div1.sense: a dancer, Il., Pind., etc.
a dancing-master, Plat.

div1.head: ὀρχηστικός
div1.sense: of or fit for dancing, of the trochaic verse, Arist.
pantomimic, Luc.

div1.head: ὀρχηστοδιδάσκαλος
div1.sense: a dancing-master, Xen.

div1.head: ὀρχηστομανέω
div1.sense: to be dancing-mad, Luc.

div1.head: ὀρχήστρα
div1.sense: the orchestra, in the Attic theatre a semicircular space in which the chorus danced, between the stage and the audience, Plat.

div1.head: ὀρχηστύς
div1.sense: the dance, Hom., Eur.

div1.head: ὀρχίλος
div1.sense: the golden-crested wren, Ar.

div1.head: ὄρχις
div1.sense: the testicles, Hdt.

div1.head: Ὀρχομενός
div1.sense: the name of several Greek cities, the most famous being Ὀ. Μινύειος in Boeotia, Hom.

div1.head: ὄρχος
div1.sense: a row of vines or fruit-trees, Od., Ar., etc.

div1.head: ὁσάκις
div1.sense: as many times as, as often as, Lat. quoties, Il.; relative to τοσσάκι, Od.

div1.head: ὁσαχῆ
div1.sense: in as many ways, Plat.

div1.head: ὁσαχοῦ
div1.sense: in as many places as, Dem.

div1.head: ὅς γε
div1.sense: ὅς, γε who or which at least, Hdt., Soph.
= Lat. qui quidem or quippe qui, οἵ γε ὑπῆρξαν since it was they who began, Hdt.

div1.head: ὁσημέραι
div1.sense: as many days as are, i. e. daily, day by day, Lat. quotidie, Ar., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ὁσία
div1.sense: divine law, natural law, οὔκ ἐστι ὁσίη it is not lawful, nefas est, Od., Hdt.; πολλὴν ὁσίαν τοῦ πράγματος νομίσαι to hold a thing fully sanctioned, Ar.
the service owed by man to God, ὁσίης ἐπιβῆναι to undertake the due rites, Hhymn.
proverb., ὁσίας ἕκατι ποιεῖσθαί τι to do a thing for formʼs sake, Lat. dicis caussa, Eur.

div1.head: ὅσιος
div1.sense: hallowed, sanctioned by the law of God, Theogn., Trag.:— οὐχ ὅσιος unhallowed, Eur., etc
opp. to δίκαιος (sanctioned by human law), sanctioned by divine law, τὰ ὅσια καὶ δίκαια things of divine and human ordinance, Plat.; θεοὺς ὅσιόν τι δρᾶν to discharge a duty men owe the gods, Eur.

opp. to ἱερός (sacred to the gods), permitted or not.forbidden by divine law, ἱερὰ καὶ ὅσια things sacred and profane, Thuc., etc.:— ὅσιόν or ὅσιά ἐστι, foll. by inf., it is lawful, fas est, Hdt., etc.; οὐκ ὅσιόν ἐστι nefas est, Hdt.; ὅσιον χωρίον a place which may be trodden without impiety, and so = βέβηλος, Lat. profanus, Ar.; so, ὅσια ποιέειν Hdt.; φρονεῖν Eur.
of persons, pious, devout, religious, Aesch., Eur., etc.
pure, ἱερῶν πατρῴων ὅσιος scrupulous in performing the rites of his forefathers, Aesch.; ὅσιαι χεῖρες pure, clean hands, Aesch.

adv. ὁσίως Eur., etc.; οὐχ ὁσίως Thuc.:— ὁσίως ἔχει τινί, c. inf., it is allowed for one to do, Xen.:—also ὅσια as adv., ἐξ ἐμοῦ οὐχ ὅσιʼ ἔθνησκες in unholy manner, Eur.:—comp. ὁσιώτερον, Eur.: Sup., ὡς ὁσιώτατα Plat.

div1.head: ὁσιότης
div1.sense: piety, holiness, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: ὁσιόω
div1.sense: to make holy, purify, set free from guilt by offerings, Lat. expiare, Eur.:—Mid., στόμα ὁσιοῦσθαι to keep oneʼs tongue pure, not to speak profanely, Eur.:—Pass. to be purified, Plut.

div1.head: ὀσμάομαι
div1.sense: Mid. to smell at a thing: metaph. to perceive, remark, c. gen., Soph.

div1.head: ὀσμή
div1.etym: ὀσμή Attic form of the older ὀδμη
div1.sense: a smell, scent, odour, good or bad, Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: ὁσονοῦν
div1.sense: ever so little, Hdt.

div1.head: ὅσος
div1.sense: quantus, of Size, as great as, how great; of Quantity, as much as, how much; of Space, as far as, how far; of Time, as long as, how long; of Number, as many as, how many; of Sound, as loud as, how loud; in pl. as many as, Lat. quot:—its antecedent is τόσος, after which ὅσος is simply as; τόσσον χρόνον, ὅσσον ἄνωγας so long time as thou dost order, Il.:—often the antec. is omitted, φωνὴ ὅση σκύλακος Od.
with τις, to denote indefinite size or number, ὅσον τι δένδρον Hdt., etc.
with Adjs. expressing Quantity, ὄχλος ὑπερφυὴς ὅσος prodigiously large, Ar.; θαυμαστὸν ὅσον διαφέρει differs amazingly, Plat.;—so in Lat. mirum quantum, immane quantum.
with Sup., ὅσα πλεῖστα the most possible, Hdt., etc.; v. infr. III. 4.
c. inf. so much as is enough, ὅσον ἀποζῆν enough to live off, Thuc.; ὅσον δοκεῖν enough for appearance, Soph.
with ind., ὅσσον ἔγωγε γιγνώσκω so far as I know, Il.; ὅσονπερ σθένω Soph., etc.
followed by Particles: ὅσος ἄν how great soever, with Subjunct., Hom., etc.
ὅσος δή how much, ἐπὶ μισθῷ ὅσῳ δή for payment of a certain amount, Hdt.:— ὁσοσοῦν, Ionic -ῶν, ever so small, Hdt.
ὅσον and ὅσα as adv.:
so far as, so much as, οὐ μέντοι ἐγὼ τόσον αἴτιός εἰμι, ὅσσον οἱ ἄλλοι Il.; c. inf., ὅσον γʼ ἔμʼ εἰδέναι so far as I know, Ar.
how far, how much, ἴστε ὅσσον περιβάλλετον ἵπποι ye know how much they excel, Il.;—with Adjs. how, ὅσον μέγα Hes., etc.
only so far as, only just, ὅσον ἐς Σκαιάς τε πύλας καὶ φηγὸν ἵκανεν Il.; εἰ μὴ ὅσον γραφῇ except only by a picture, Hdt.
in reference to distances, ὅσον τε, about, nearly, ὅσον τʼ ὄργυιαν Od.; ὅσον τε δέκα στάδια Hdt.
with Adjs., ὅσσον βασιλεύτερός εἰμι so far as, inasmuch as I am a greater king, Il.; ὅσον εἰμὶ κάρτιστος how I am far the strongest, Il.: —so with Advs., ὅσον τάχιστα Attic; ὅσον μάλιστα Aesch.

with negatives, ὅσον οὐ or ὁσονού, Lat. tantum non, only not, all but, Thuc.; ὅσον οὐκ ἤδη immediately, Eur.: οὐχ ὅσον οὐκ ἠμύναντο, ἀλλʼ not only did they not avenge themselves, Thuc.:— ὅσον μή so far as not, save or except so far as, ὅσον γε μὴ ποτιψαύων so far as I can without touching . . , Soph., etc.
ὅσῳ, ὅσῳ περ, by how much, ὅσῳ πλέον Hes.; διέδεξε, ὅσῳ ἐστὶ τοῦτο ἄριστον Hdt.
ὅσῳ with comp. when followed by another comp. with τοσούτῳ, like Lat. quo or quanto melior, eo magis, ὅσῳ μᾶλλον πιστεύω, τοσούτῳ μᾶλλον ἀπορῶ Plat.
ἐς ὅσον, ἐφʼ ὅσον, καθʼ ὅσον are often used much like ὅσον, εἰς ὅσον σθένω Soph.; ἐφʼ ὅσον ἠδύνατο Thuc.
ἐν ὅσῳ, while, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: ὅς
div1.sense: Pronoun, which in early Greek was used (A.) as a Demonstr. = οὗτος, ὅδε. (B.) as a Relat.
DEMONSTR., this, that; sometimes also for αὐτός, he, she, it, only in nom.:
in Hom., ἀλλὰ καὶ ὃς δείδοικε Il.; ὃ γὰρ γέρας ἐστὶ θανόντων Od.
in later Greek,
at the beginning of a clause, καὶ ὅς and he, καὶ ἥ and she, καὶ οἵ and they, Hdt., Plat.
ὃς καὶ ὅς such and such a person, Hdt.
ἦ δʼ ὅς, ἦ δʼ ἥ said he, said she, Plat.
in oppositions, Λέριοι κακοί· οὐχ ὁ μέν, ὃς δʼ οὐ Phocyl.; ὃς μὲν . . , ὁ δὲ . . , Mosch., etc.

RELAT., who, which, Lat. qui, quae, quod: properly, the Relat. is governed by the Noun or Verb in its own clause, but it often takes the case of the Anteced. by attraction, τῆς γενεῆς, ἧς Τρωὶ Ζεὺς δῶκε (where the proper case would be ἥν) Il.; οὐδὲν ὧν λέγω (for οὐδὲν τούτων ἃ λέγω) Soph.:—reversely the Anteced. passes into the case of the Relat., τὰς στήλας, ἃς ἵστα, αἱ πλεῦνες (for τῶν στηλῶν, ἃς ἵστα, αἱ πλεῦνες) Hdt.
the neut. was used in Attic without an Antecedent, ὃ δὲ δεινότατόν γʼ ἐστὶν ἁπάντων, ὁ Ζεὺς γὰρ ἕστηκεν but what is the strangest thing of all is, that Zeus stands, Ar., etc.

in many instances the Gr. Relat. must be resolved into a Conjunction and Pron., ἄτοπα λέγεις, ὅς γε κελεύεις (for ὅτι σύ γε) Xen.; συμφορὰ δʼ, ὃς ἂν τύχῃ κακῆς γυναικός (for ἐάν τις) Eur.:—it is also used, where we should use the Inf., ἄγγελον ἧκαν, ὃς ἀγγείλειε nuncium miserunt, qui nunciaret, sent a messenger to tell, Od.; πέμψον τινʼ, ὅστις σημανεῖ Eur.
the Relat. Pron. joined with Particles or Conjunctions:
ὅς γε, v. ὅσγε.
ὃς δή, v. δή I. 5.
ὃς καί who also, but καὶ ὅς and who.
ὅς κε or κεν, Attic ὃς ἄν, much like ὅστις, Lat. quicunque, whosoever, who if any.
absol. usages of certain Cases of the Relat. Pron.:

gen. sg. οὗ, of Place, like ὅπου, where, Aesch., Trag., etc.:— ἔστιν οὗ in some places, Eur.; οὐκ εἶδεν οὗ γῆς in what part of the earth, Eur.:—in pregnant phrases, μικρὸν προϊόντες, οὗ ἡ μάχη ἐγένετο (for ἐκεῖσε οὗ) having gone on to the place where . . , Xen.
ἐξ οὗ (sub. χρόνου) from the time when, Hom., etc.
dat. fem. ᾗ, Doric ᾇ, of Place, like Lat. qua, where: also with Sup. adv., ᾗ μάλιστα, ᾗ ῥᾷστα, ᾗ ἄριστον, etc., like ὡς μάλιστα, etc., and Lat. quam celerrime, Xen.
acc. sg. neut. ὅ for διʼ ὅ or ὅτι, that, how that, also because, Lat. quod, Hom.:—also wherefore, Lat. quapropter, Eur.
POSSESSIVE PRON.:
of 3rd person, for ἑός, his, her, Lat. suus, Hom., old Attic
of 2nd person, for σός, thy, thine, Hes.
of 1st person, for ἐμός, my, mine, Od.

div1.head: ὅσπερ
div1.sense: the very man who, the very thing which, but often simply for ὅς, Hom., etc.
absol. ἅπερ, as, like καθάπερ (v. καθά) , Aesch.
ᾗπερ, which way, where, whither, Il., Xen., etc.; Ionic τῇπερ: — also as, Il., etc.

div1.head: ὄσπριον
div1.sense: pulse of all kinds, Hdt.; in pl., Xen.

div1.head: ὄσσα
div1.sense: a rumour, Lat. fama, which, from its origin being unknown, was held divine, a word voiced abroad, ὄσσα ἐκ Διός Od.; personified as messenger of Zeus, Hom.
generally, a voice, Hes.
still more generally, a sound, of the harp, Hhymn.; the din of battle, Hes.
an ominous voice, prophecy, warning, Pind.

div1.head: ὁσσάτιος
div1.etym: Epic lengthd. form of ὅσος, Il.

div1.head: ὄσσε
div1.sense: the two eyes, nom. and acc. with adj. in the pl., ὄσσε φαεινά, αἱματόεντα Il.; with Verb in sg., πυρὶ δʼ ὄσσε δεδῄει Il.; a gen. pl. ὄσσων Hes., Aesch.; dat. ὄσσοις, ὄσσοισι Hes.

div1.head: ὁσσίχος
div1.sense: as little, how little, Lat. quantulus, Theocr.

div1.head: ὄσσομαι
div1.etym: only in pres. and imperf. without augm.
div1.sense: Epic Dep., to see, ὀσσόμενος πατέρʼ ἐσθλὸν ἐνὶ φρεσίν (so Shaksp. "in my mindʼs eye"), Od.
to presage, have foreboding of, κακά, ἄλγεα Hom.
to foretoken, Hom.

div1.head: ὀστάριον
div1.sense: a little bone, Anth.

div1.head: ὀστέϊνος
div1.sense: made of bone, of bone, Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: ὀστέον
div1.sense: Lat. os, ossis, a bone, Hom., Hdt., Attic; λευκὰ ὀστέα the bleached bones of the dead, Od.

div1.head: ὅστε
div1.sense: who, which, just like the simple ὅς or ὅστις, Hom., etc.; neut. τό τε Hes.; pl. τά τε Il.; pl. fem. τάς τε Il.
ἐξ οὗτε from the time when, Aesch.

div1.head: ὄστινος
div1.sense: τὰ ὄστινα, Lat. tibiae, bone-pipes, Ar.

div1.head: ὅστις
div1.sense: any one who, anything which, i. e. whosoever, whichsoever, differing from ὅς, as Lat. quisquis, from qui, Hom., etc.; ὅντινα κιχείη whomsoever he caught, Il.; ὅτις κ ἐπίορκον ὀμόσσῃ whoso forswears himself, Il., etc.: — ἔστιν ὅστις, Lat. est qui, often with a negat., οὐκ ἔστιν ὅτῳ μείζονα μοῖραν νείμαιμʼ there is no one to whom I would give more, Aesch., etc.: —οὐδὲν ὅ τι οὐ everything, Hdt.
hardly different from ὅς, who, βωμόν, ὅστις νῦν ἔξω τῆς πόλεώς ἐστι the altar, which . . , Thuc.
in indirect questions, ξεῖνος ὅδʼ, οὐκ οἶδʼ ὅστις Od.:—in dialogue, when the person questioned repeats the question asked by τίς, as οὗτος τί ποιεῖς; Answ. ὅ τι ποιῶ; [you ask] what Iʼm doing? Ar.
neut. ὅ τι used absol. as a Conjunction, v. ὅ τι.
ἐξ ὅτου from which time, Soph., etc.
from what cause, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ὀστοφυής
div1.sense: of bony nature or substance, Batr.

div1.head: ὀστρακεύς
div1.sense: a potter, Anth.

div1.head: ὀστρακίζω
div1.sense: fut. ίσω, to banish by potsherds, ostracize, Thuc.—Ostracism (ὀστρακισμός) was adopted at Athens to check the power of individuals, which had become too great for the liberties of the people.

div1.head: ὀστρακίνδα
div1.sense: played with potsherds or oyster-shells, παιδιὰ ὀστρ. a game in which an ὄστρακον, black on one side and white on the other, was thrown on a line, and according as the black or white turned up, one party was obliged to fly and the other pursued, ὀστρ. βλέπειν (with a reference to ὀστρακισμός) , Ar.

div1.head: ὀστράκινος
div1.sense: earthen, of clay, Anth., NTest.

div1.head: ὀστρακισμός
div1.sense: ostracism, v. ὀστρακίζω.

div1.head: ὄστρακον
div1.sense: an earthen vessel, Lat. testa, Ar.
a tile or potsherd, esp. the tablet used in voting (v. ὀστρακίζω), Plat.
a sort of earthenware castanet, Ar.
the hard shell of testaceous animals, as snails, muscles, tortoises, Hhymn., Theocr.

div1.head: ὀστρακόσδερμος
div1.sense: with a shell like a potsherd, hard-shelled, Batr.

div1.head: ὀστρακοφορία
div1.sense: a voting with ὄστρακα, Plut.

div1.head: ὀστρακόχρως
div1.sense: with metapl. acc. ὀστρακόχροα, with a hard skin or shell, Anth.

div1.head: ὀστρειογραφής
div1.sense: purple-painted, Anth.

div1.head: ὄστρεον
div1.sense: an oyster, Lat. ostrea, Aesch., Plat.

div1.head: ὀστώδης
div1.sense: like bone, bony, Xen.

div1.head: ὀσφραίνομαι
div1.sense: to catch scent of, smell, scent, track, c. gen., Hdt., Ar., etc.; absol., Plat.

div1.head: ὀσφραντήριος
div1.sense: smelling, able to smell, sharp-smelling, Ar.

div1.head: ὄσφρησις
div1.sense: the sense of smell, smell, Plat.

div1.head: ὀσφύς
div1.sense: the loin or loins, the lower part of the back, Hdt., Aesch., etc.: —ἀναζώννυσθαι τὴν ὀσφύν to gird up oneʼs loins, NTest.; ὁ καρπὸς τῆς ὀσφύος the fruit of the loins, i. e. a son, NTest.

div1.head: ὄσχος
div1.sense: a vine-branch, Ar.

div1.head: ὀσχοφόρια
div1.sense: one day of the Athen. festival Σκίρα, on which boys, carrying vine-branches loaded with grapes (v. ὄσχος), went in procession from the temple of Bacchus to that of Ἀθηνᾶ Σκιράς, Plut.

div1.head: ὅταν
div1.sense: for ὅτ’ ἄν ( ὅτε ἄν) , adverb of Time, whenever, Lat. quandocunque, foll. by Subjunct., Hom., etc.; in Epic also ὅτε κεν Il.:— εἰς ὅτε κεν until such time as. . , Od.:— ὅταν τάχιστα, Lat. quum primum, Xen.

div1.head: ὅτε
div1.sense: relat. adv. of Time, formed from the relat. stem ὁ and τε ( v. τε B), answering to demonstr. τότε, and interrog. πότε:— when, Lat. quum, quando, foll. by Ind., Hom., etc.;—by Opt.:—of future events represented as uncertain, Il.:—in Hom. sometimes for ὅταν, with Subj.
elliptical in phrase ἔστιν ὅτε or ἔσθʼ ὅτε, like Lat. est ubi, there are times when, sometimes, now and then, Hdt., Attic
in Causal sense, like Lat. quum, whereas, Il., Attic
ὁτέ absol. adv., like ἔσθʼ ὅτε, sometimes, ὁτὲ μὲν. . , ἄλλοτε . . , ὁτὲ μὲν . . , ἄλλοτε δʼ αὖ . . , Il.; ὅτε μὲν . . , ὅτε δὲ . . , Arist.

div1.head: ὅτι
div1.etym: ὅ τι, Epic ὅ ττι, (often written ὅ, τι ὅ, ττι— to distinguish them from ὅτι, ὅττι, that), neut. of ὅστις
div1.sense: used as an adv. like διότι, in indirect questions, for what, wherefore, ὅς κʼ εἴποι, ὅ τι τόσσον ἐχώσατο who might say, wherefore he is so angry, Il.; ἢν μὴ φράσῃς ὅ τι . . unless you tell me why . . , Ar.
ὅ τι μή or ὅτι μή, after a negat. clause, except, Il.; οὐδαμοί, ὅτι μὴ Χῖοι μοῦνοι Hdt.

with Sup. adv., ὅ ττι τάχιστα, as quick as possible, Hom.;—so, ὅ τι τάχος Hdt., etc.; ὅ τι μάλιστα, ὅ τι ἐλάχιστα, etc., Thuc.; also with Adjs., ὅ τι πλεῖστον ναυτικόν, ὅ τι πλεῖστον χρόνον Xen.; ὅ τι πλείστη εὐδαιμονία Plat.

div1.head: ὅτι
div1.sense: that, Lat. quod, after Verbs of seeing or knowing, thinking or saying, used in quoting another personʼs words, ἠγγέλθη, ὅτι Μέγαρα ἀφέστηκε news came that Megara has revolted (where we say had), Thuc.; ἀποκρινάμενοι ὅτι πέμψουσι (where we say that they would send), Thuc.;— in orat. obliq., with opt., ἠπείλησʼ ὅτι βαδιοίμην I threatened that I would go, Ar.

pleonast. before the very words of a speech (where in our idiom the Conjunction is left out, its place being supplied by inverted commas), καὶ ἐγὼ εἶπον, ὅτι ἡ αὐτή μοι ἀρχή ἐστι and I said: "I will begin at the same point, " Plat.

ὅτι in Attic may represent a whole sentence, esp. in affirm. answers, οὐκοῦν τὸ ἀδικεῖν κάκιον ἂν εἴη τοῦ ἀδικεῖσθαι; Answ. δῆλον δὴ ὅτι (i. e. ὅτι κάκιον ἂν εἴη) , Plat.; so in the affirmations conveyed by οἶδʼ ὅτι, οἶσθʼ ὅτι, etc., and in δηλονότι (i. e. δῆλόν ἐστιν ὅτι) used as adv.

οὐχ ὅτι . . , ἀλλὰ or ἀλλὰ καὶ . . , not only, but also . . , Xen.; οὐ μόνον ὅτι ἄνδρες, ἀλλὰ καὶ γυναῖκες Plat.:— οὐχ ὅτι, not followed by a second clause, means although, οὐχ ὅτι παίζει καί φησι Plat.
for ὅτι μή, v. ὅ τι II.
as a Causal Particle for that, because, seeing that, inasmuch as, Lat. quod, Hom., etc.

div1.head: ὁτιή
div1.sense: because, Ar.
= ὅ τι, wherefore, ὁτιὴ τί; why so? wherefore so? Ar.

div1.head: ὁτιοῦν
div1.etym: = ὅτι οὖν, neut. of ὅστις οὖν
div1.sense: whatsoever, Thuc.

div1.head: ὀτλεύω
div1.sense: to suffer, endure, Babr.

div1.head: ὄτλος
div1.sense: a burden, distress, Aesch.

div1.head: ὄτοβος
div1.sense: any loud noise, as the din of battle, Hes.; the rattling of chariots, Aesch.; the crash of thunder, Soph.; also of the flute, γλυκὺν αὐλῶν ὄτ. Soph.

div1.head: ὀτοτοῖ
div1.sense: an exclamation of pain and grief, ah! woe! Trag.: so ὀτοτοτοῖ Aesch.; ὀτοτοτοῖ τοτοῖ Aesch.; ὀτοτοτοτοῖ τοτοῖ Soph.; ὀτοτοτοτοτοτοῖ Eur.

div1.head: ὀτοτύζω
div1.sense: to wail aloud, Ar.; fut. ὀτοτύξομαι, Ar.:—Pass. to be bewailed, Aesch.

div1.head: Ὀτοτύξιοι
div1.sense: Com. pr. n., men of Wails, with a play on Ὀλοφύξιοι (men of Olophyxus near Mt. Athos), Ar.

div1.head: ὀτραλέος
div1.etym: used by Hom. and Hes. only in adv. ὀτρᾰλέως
div1.sense: -ως, quickly, readily.

div1.head: ὀτρηρός
div1.sense: quick, nimble, busy, ready, Hom., Ar.:—adv. -ρῶς, ὀτραλέως, Od.

div1.head: ὀτρυντύς
div1.sense: a cheering on, exhortation, Il.

div1.head: ὀτρύνω
div1.sense: to stir up, rouse, egg on, spur on, encourage, Il.; c. inf., ὀτρ. τινὰ πολεμίζειν Il.; γήμασθαι Od., etc.; inf. omitted, ἦ τινα ὀτρυνέεις ἐπίσκοπον (sc. ἰέναι) ; wilt thou urge one (to go) as a spy? Il.:—Mid. or Pass. to bestir oneself, hasten, Od., etc.; c. inf., ὀτρυνώμεθʼ ἀμυνέμεν ἀλλήλοισιν Il.
of thing, to urge forward, quicken, speed, Hom., etc.

div1.head: οὐαί
div1.sense: exclam., Lat. vae! ah! οὐαί σοι woe to thee! NTest.

div1.head: οὐά
div1.sense: Lat. vah! exclam., ha! ah! NTest.

div1.head: οὐατόεις
div1.sense: long-eared, Anth.

div1.head: οὐ γὰρ ἀλλά
div1.sense: an ellipt. phrase, used in Attic to express a negation and give a reason for it, Lat. enimvero, μὴ σκῶπτέ μʼ, οὐ γὰρ ἀλλʼ ἔχω κακῶς (i. e. μὴ σκῶπτέ με: οὐ γὰρ σκωπτικῶς, ἀλλὰ κακῶς ἔχω) Ar.

div1.head: οὐ γὰρ οὖν
div1.sense: in answer to a negat. propos., where οὖν refers to a foregone proof as conclusive, why no, —certainly not, Plat.

div1.head: οὐ γάρ
div1.sense: for not, assigning a negative reason, Hom., etc.: οὐ γάρ, in answers, why no, Plat.
elliptic, in interrogative replies, where yes must be supplied, τούτους ἀγαθοὺς ἐνόμισας; Answ. οὐ γάρ . . ; yes, for why shouldnʼt I? yes; why not? Ar.
in questions, where an affirm. answer is expected, οὐ γὰρ ὁ Παφλαγὼν ἀπέκρυπτε ταύτας; why, did not he keep them hidden? Ar.

div1.head: οὐ γάρ που
div1.sense: for in no manner, Plat.

div1.head: οὐ γάρ τοι
div1.sense: merely οὐ γάρ strengthd., Od., etc.:—so οὐγάρ, τοι ἀλλά Plat.

div1.head: οὐδαῖος
div1.sense: infernal, of Pluto, Anth.

div1.head: οὐδαμῆ
div1.sense: of Place, nowhere, in no place, Hes., Aesch.; οὐδ. ἄλλῃ Hdt.; ἄλλῃ οὐδ. in no other place, Hdt.; c. gen., οὐδ. Αἰγύπτου in no part of Egypt, Hdt.
in no direction, no way, Hdt.
of Manner, in no way, in no wise, Hdt., Aesch., etc.:— not at all, never, Hdt., Soph.—The Poets use either οὐδαμῆ Doric -μα= [ᾱ], or οὐδαμά [-mᾰ], as the metre requires.

div1.head: οὐδαμόθεν
div1.sense: from no place, from no side, Plat., etc.

div1.head: οὐδαμόθι
div1.sense: nowhere, in no place, Hdt.

div1.head: οὐδαμοῖ
div1.sense: no-whither, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: οὐδαμόσε
div1.etym: adverb of οὐδαμός, οὐδαμοῖ, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: οὐδαμός
div1.etym: for οὐδὲ ἀμός, Ionic for οὐδείς
div1.sense: not even one, no one, only in pl., none, Hdt.

div1.head: οὐδαμοῦ
div1.sense: nowhere, answering to ποῦ; where? Hdt., Thuc., etc.; c. gen., οὐδαμοῦ γῆς Hdt.; οὐδαμοῦ ἦν φρενῶν Eur.

οὐδαμοῦ λέγειν τινά to esteem as naught, Lat. nullo in loco habere, Soph.; so, θεοὺς νομίζων οὐδ. Aesch.; οὐδ. (or μηδαμοῦ) εἶναι, φαίνεσθαι, like Ciceroʼs ne apparere quidem, not to be taken into account, Plat.
of Manner, ἄλλοθι οὐδαμοῦ in no other way, Plat.

div1.head: οὐδαμῶς
div1.sense: in no wise, Hdt., Attic; ἄλλως οὐδαμῶς Hdt.; οὐδέποτε οὐδαμῆ οὐδαμῶς Plat.

div1.head: οὖδας
div1.sense: the surface of the earth, the ground, earth, Hom.; πῖαρ οὖδας the rich soil, Od.; ὀδὰξ ἕλον οὖδας they bit the dust, of dying men, Hom.; οὔδει ἐρείσθη he propped himself on the ground, Il.; ἀπʼ οὔδεος from the ground, οὖδάσδε to the ground, to earth, Hom.; πρὸς οὖδας φορεῖσθαι, πεσεῖν, βεβλῆσθαι Trag.
the floor or pavement of rooms and houses, Hom.:—proverb., ἐπʼ οὔδεϊ καθίζειν τινά to bring a man to the pavement, i. e. to strip him of all he has, Hhymn.

div1.head: οὐδείς
div1.sense: and not one, i. e. no one, none, as Lat. nullus, for ne ullus, Hom., etc.:—rare in pl. (οὐδαμοί being used instead), Xen.; πρὸς οὐδένας τῶν Ἑλλήνων Dem.; v. infr. II. 3.

οὐδεὶς ὅστις οὐ, Lat. nemo non, every one, Hdt., Attic; οὐδὲν ὅ τι οὐ, Lat. nihil non, every, Hdt.; this came to be regarded as one word, so that οὐδείς passed into the same case as the relative, οὐδένα ὅντινα οὐ κατέκλασε Plat.
naught, good for naught, Ar.
in neut. of persons, οὐδέν εἰμι Hdt.; πρὸς τὸν οὐδένα Eur.; οὐδὲν εἶναι to be good for nothing, Ar.
in pl., οὐδένες ἐόντες being nobodies, Hdt.; ὄντες οὐδένες Eur.; ὁ μηδὲν ὢν κἀξ οὐδένων κεκλήσομαι Eur.
with Preps., παρʼ οὐδὲν ἄγειν, θέσθαι to make of no account, Soph., Eur.; διʼ οὐδενὸς ποιεῖσθαι Soph.; ἐν οὐδενὸς εἶναι μέρει Dem.
neut. οὐδέν as adv. not at all, naught, Il., etc.
οὐδὲν ἄλλο ἤ, v. ἄλλος.

div1.head: οὐδένεια
div1.sense: nothingness, worthlessness, Plat.

div1.head: οὐδενόσωρος
div1.sense: worth no notice or regard, Il.

div1.head: οὐδέ
div1.sense: οὐ δέ, Negat. Particle, related to μηδέ as οὐ to μή·

as Conjunct., but not, answering to μέν, ἄλλοις μὲν πᾶσιν ἐήνδανεν, οὐδέ ποθʼ Ἥρῃ, οὐδὲ Ποσειδάωνʼ, οὐδὲ γλαυκώπιδι κούρῃ Il.:— and not, nor, Lat. neque, nec, τραχὺς μόναρχος οὐδʼ ὑπεύθυνος Aesch.; ἄθικτος οὐδʼ οἰκητός Soph.
with a simple negat. preceding, nor, οὐκέτι σοὶ μένος ἔμπεδον οὐδέ τις ἀλκή Od.

when οὐδέ is repeated at the beginning of two following clauses, the first οὐδέ is often adverbial (infr. III), not even . . , nor yet . . , marking a stronger opposition than οὔτε . . , οὔτε, neither . . , nor . . , Od., Attic
as adv. not even, Lat. ne . . quidem, οὐδʼ ἠβαιόν not even a little, not at all, οὐδὲ τυτθόν, οὐδὲ μίνυνθα Il., Attic:—before ἕν (one) it is not elided, οὐδὲ ἕν Ar.
οὐδέ is often repeated with other negatives: ἀλλʼ οὐ γὰρ οὐδὲ νουθετεῖν ἔξεστί σε Soph.; so, οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδέ Il., etc.

div1.head: οὐδέπη
div1.sense: in no wise, Od.

div1.head: οὐδέποτε
div1.sense: and not ever or nor ever, not even ever, never, Lat. ne unquam quidem, nunquam, Hom., etc.

div1.head: οὐδέ πω
div1.sense: and not yet, not as yet, Aesch., Plat.:— in Hom., with a word between, οὐδέ τί πω, οὐδʼ ἄν πω.

div1.head: οὐδεπώποτε
div1.sense: nor yet at any time, never yet at any time, Soph., Plat.

div1.head: οὐδέτερος
div1.sense: not either, neither of the two, Lat. neuter for ne uter, Hdt.; in pl., when each party is pl., Hes., Hdt.:—adv. οὐδετέρως, in neither of two ways, Plat.; also neut. pl. as adv. = οὐδετέρως, Plat.
neutral, τῶν μὲν αἱρετῶν οὐσῶν, τῶν δὲ φευκτῶν, τῶν δʼ οὐδετέρων Arist.

div1.head: οὐδετέρωσε
div1.sense: to neither of two sides, neither way, Il., Theogn.

div1.head: οὐδʼἔτι
div1.sense: certainly not, Lat. non sane, Hom.

div1.head: οὐδήεις
div1.sense: terrestrial, v. l. Od.

div1.head: οὐ δή που
div1.sense: I suppose not, v. δήπου.

div1.head: οὐ δῆτα
div1.sense: no truly, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: οὐδός
div1.sense: a threshold, Hom., Hes.:— the threshold or entrance to any place, Hom., Soph.
metaph., ἐπὶ γήραος οὐδῷ on the threshold, i. e. the verge, of old age, Hom.

div1.head: οὐδός2
div1.sense: a way, Od.

div1.head: οὖθαρ
div1.sense: the udder of animals, Od., Hdt.: rarely of women, the breast, Aesch.
metaph., οὖθαρ ἀρούρης the richest, most fertile land, like Virgilʼs uber arvi, Il.; of the vine, οὖθαρ βοτρύων Anth.

div1.head: οὐθάτιος
div1.sense: of the udder, Anth.

div1.head: οὔθην
div1.sense: surely not, certainly not, Hom.

div1.head: οὐκέτι
div1.sense: or οὐκ, ἔτι, no more, no longer, no further, opp. to οὔπω (not yet), Hom., etc.

div1.head: οὐκοῦν
div1.sense: orig. identical with οὔκουν, but losing all negat. force, therefore, then, accordingly, Lat. ergo, igitur, itaque, Soph., etc.
in questions, so then? mostly in irony, Xen.
in answers, why yes, doubtless, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: οὔκουν
div1.sense: in direct negation, not therefore, so not, Lat. non ergo, non igitur, itaque non, Hdt., Soph., etc.; rarely in apodosi:—but the inferential force is scarcely discernible, like Lat. non sane, in narrative, οὔκων δὴ ἔπειθε so he failed to persuade him, Hdt.
in interrog. not therefore? not then? and so not? like Lat. nonne ergo? Aesch.; cf. οὐκοῦν.

div1.head: οὐκ ἄρα
div1.sense: so not, not then, surely not, Hom.
in questions, οὔκ ἄρʼ ἔμελλες οὐδὲ θανὼν λήσεσθαι χόλου; so not even in death canst thou forget thine anger? Od.

div1.head: οὐλαί
div1.sense: barley-corns, barley-groats, which were sprinkled on the head of the victim before the sacrifice, Od., Hdt., Attic
div1.etym: Commonly derived from οὖλος, ὅλος, as if οὐλαί or ὀλαί were whole grains, unground barleycorns. Others from ἀλέω, to grind, as Lat. mola from molere.

div1.head: οὐλαμός
div1.sense: a throng of warriors, οὐλαμὸς ἀνδρῶν Il.
later, a troop of cavalry, Lat. turma, ala, Polyb., Plut.

div1.head: οὐλή
div1.sense: a scar, Lat. cicatrix, Od., Eur., Xen.

div1.head: οὔλιος
div1.sense: = ὀλοός, baleful, baneful, οὔλιος ἀστήρ of the dog-star, Il.; of Ares, Hes.

div1.head: οὐλόθριξ
div1.sense: with curly hair, Hdt.

div1.head: οὐλοκάρηνος
div1.sense: with crisp, curling hair, Od.
οὐλόποδʼ, οὐλοκάρηνα, poet. for ὅλους πόδας, ὅλα κάρηνα, Hhymn.

div1.head: οὐλόκερως
div1.sense: with twisted horns, Strab.

div1.head: οὐλόμενος
div1.etym: aor2 mid. part. of ὄλλυμι, used as adj.
div1.sense: destructive, baneful, Lat. fatalis, Hom., Hes., etc.
unhappy, undone, lost, Lat. perditus, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: οὖλον
div1.note: οὖλον, ου, mostly in pl., οὖλα, ων, τά,
div1.sense: the gums, Aesch., Plat.

div1.head: οὖλος
div1.sense: whole, entire, v. ὅλος:—of sound, continuous, incessant, οὖλον κεκλήγοντες screaming incessant, Il.; so, οὖλον γεράνων νέφος Anth.

div1.head: οὖλος2
div1.sense: woolly, woollen, Hom.; οὔλη λάχνη thick, fleecy wool, Il.; οὖλαι κόμαι crisp, close-curling hair, Od.; οὐλότατον τρίχωμα of the hair of negroes, Hdt.
of plants, twisted, curling, Anth.:— generally, twisted, crooked, οὖλα σκέλη ap. Arist.

div1.head: οὖλος3
div1.sense: destructive, baneful, Il.

div1.head: οὐλοτριχέω
div1.sense: to have curly hair, Strab.

div1.head: οὐλοχύται
div1.sense: barley-groats or coarsely-ground barley sprinkled over the victim before a sacrifice, Hom.; cf. ἄρχω II. 2.

div1.head: Οὐλυμπόθεν
div1.sense: from Ol., Pind.

div1.head: οὔλω
div1.sense: to be whole or sound, imperat. οὖλε, Lat. salve, as a salutation, health to thee, οὖλέ τε καὶ μέγα χαῖρε health and joy be with thee, Od.

div1.head: οὐ μάν
div1.sense: assuredly not, Doric and Epic for οὐ μήν, Hom.

div1.head: οὐ μὲν οὖν
div1.sense: or οὐ μενοῦν verily and indeed not, Ar.
in answers, ἐγώ σοι οὐκ ἂν δυναίμην ἀντιλέγειν; Answ. οὐμενοῦν τῇ ἀληθείᾳ δύνασαι ἀντιλέγειν nay it is not me, but rather truth, that thou canst not gainsay, Plat.

div1.head: οὐ μέν
div1.sense: no truly, nay verily, Hom.

div1.head: οὐ μέντοι
div1.sense: not surely, not verily, Il.
not however, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; οὐ μέντοι ἀλλά not but that Plat.
in interrog. οὐ μέντοι; is it not surely? where an affirm. answer is expected, Plat.

div1.head: οὐ μὴν ἀλλά
div1.sense: οὐ μὴν ἀλλά . . γε; also, οὐ μὴν ἀλλὰ καί . . γε, nevertheless, notwithstanding, yet, still, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: οὐ μήν
div1.sense: not however, Aesch., etc.; —οὐ μὴν οὐδέ not at all however, Thuc., Xen., etc.
οὐ μὴν . . γε after a negative, no nor even yet, Lat. nedum, Ar.

div1.head: οὐ μή
div1.sense: in independent sentences used either in Denial or in Prohibition.

in Denial, with Subj., chiefly of aor., οὔ τι μὴ ληφθῶ I shall not be captured, Aesch.; οὐ μὴ ἐσβάλωσιν they shall not make an inroad, Thuc., etc.:—οὐ μή with Subj. is commonly explained by the ellipsis of words expressing fear, which indeed are sometimes expressed, οὐ γὰρ ἦν δεινὸν μὴ ἁλῷ κοτε Hdt.; οὐχὶ δέος μή σε φιλήσῃ Ar. But οὐ μή are also used with fut. Ind., οὔ σοι μὴ μεθέψομαί ποτε Soph.; οὐ μὴ δυνήσεται εὑρεῖν he will not be able to find, Xen.
in Prohibition, οὐ μή is used interrogatively with fut. Ind. (chiefly of the 2nd person), = οὐ μὴ προσοίσεις χεῖρα; μὴ πρόσφερε χεῖρα Eur.; οὐ μὴ πρόσει μὴ πρόσιθι, Ar.

div1.head: οὕνεκα
div1.etym: in Poets before a vowel οὕνεκεν
div1.sense: on which account, wherefore, Hom.
relative to τοὔνεκα, for that, because, Pind., Trag.
after certain Verbs, just like ὅτι, Lat. quod, that, i. e. the fact that, after εἰδέναι, νοεῖν, ἐρέειν, Od.; after ἴσθι, μαθεῖν, Soph.:—cf. ὁθούνεκα.
as prep. c. gen., equiv. to ἕνεκα, εἵνεκα, on account of, because of, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: οὖν
div1.sense: really, at all events, used like γοῦν to dismiss a perplexing subject, οὔτʼ οὖν ἀγγελίῃς ἔτι πείθομαι, οὔτε θεοπροπίης ἐμπάζομαι Od.; ἐλέχθησαν λόγοι ἄπιστοι μὲν ἐνίοισι Ἑλλήνων, ἐλέχθησαν δʼ ὦν but they really were spoken, Hdt.; εἴτʼ οὖν, εἴτε μὴ γενήσεται whether it shall be really so, or no, Eur.; εἴτʼ οὖν ἀληθὲς εἴτʼ οὖν ψεῦδος Plat.; εἰ δʼ ἔστιν, ὥσπερ οὖν ἔστι, θεός if he is, as he surely is, a god, Plat.

added to indef. Pronouns and Advs., like Lat. cunque, ὅστις whoever, ὁστισοῦν whosoever; ὅπως how, ὁπωσοῦν howsoever; ἄλλος ὁστισοὖν another, be he who he may; so, ὁποιοσοῦν, ὁποσοσοῦν, ὁπωσοῦν, ὁποθενοῦν, etc.

to continue a narrative, οἱ δʼ ἐπεὶ οὖν ἤγερθεν so when they were assembled, Il., etc.:—also to resume after an apodosis, I say, Hdt., etc.; Hdt. inserts it between the prep. and its Verb, ἐπεὰν δὲ ταῦτα ποιήσωσι, ἀπʼ ὦν ἔδωκαν.
in Inferences, then, therefore, Lat. igitur, Hdt., etc.; so, δὴ οὖν, οὖν δή Plat.

div1.head: οὔ νυ
div1.sense: nearly like οὐ δή, surely not, Hom.

div1.head: οὗ
div1.sense: where, v. ὅς, ἥ, ὅ b. III.

div1.head: οὗπερ
div1.etym: v. ὅς, ἥ, ὅ B. III

div1.head: οὔπερ
div1.sense: not at all, Il.

div1.head: οὔπη
div1.sense: nowhere, Hom.
in no wise, Hom.

div1.head: οὔ ποθι
div1.sense: nowhere, Il.: —οὐδέ ποθι nor anywhere, Hom.

div1.head: οὔ ποτε
div1.sense: not ever, never, Hom.

div1.head: οὔ που
div1.sense: Attic adv. surely you do not mean that . .? Eur.

div1.head: οὐ
div1.sense: used in direct negation not, Lat. non.
USAGE:
adhering to single words so as to form a quasi-compd. with them, οὐ δίδωμι to withhold, οὐκ ἐῶ to refuse, οὐκ ἐθέλω nolo, οὔ φημι nego.
as negativing the whole sentence, τὴν δʼ ἐγὼ οὐ λύσω Il., etc.
in dependent clauses οὐ is used,
with ὅτι or ὡς, after Verbs of saying or knowing, ἔλεξε ὡς Ἕλληνες οὐ μενοῖεν Aesch.
in Causal sentences, and in Temporal sentences that involve special times, ἄχθεται ὅτι οὐ κάρτα θεραπεύεται Hdt.; οὐκ ἔσθʼ ἐραστὴς ὅστις οὐκ ἀεὶ φιλεῖ Eur.
in a conditional clause μή is necessary, except,
when οὐ is closely attached to the Verb (v. supr. I), εἴ φθονέω τε καὶ οὐκ εἰῶ διαπέρσαι Il.
when the subjoined clause is hypothetical in form only, μὴ θαυμάσῃς, εἰ πολλὰ οὐ πρέπει σοι (where εἰ = ὅτι) Isocr.; δεινὸν γὰρ ἂν εἴη πρῆγμα, εἰ Ἕλληνας οὐ τιμωρησόμεθα Hdt.
οὐ is used with Inf. in oratio obl., when it represents the Ind. of oratio recta, λέγοντες οὐκ εἶναι αὐτόνομοι Thuc.; οἶμαι οὐκ ὀλίγον ἔργον αὐτὸ εἶναι Plat.
οὐ is used with the Participle, when it can be resolved into a finite sentence with οὐ; κατενόησαν οὐ πολλοὺς τοὺς Θηβαίους ὄντας ὅ τι οὐ πολλοί εἰσι, Thuc.

Adjectives and abstract Substantives with the Article commonly take μή (v. μή B. 6), but οὐ is occasionally used, τῶν γεφυρῶν οὐ διάλυσιν the nondissolution of the bridge, the fact of its not being broken up, Thuc.; so, ἡ οὐ περιτείχισις Thuc.

ACCUMULATION: the negative is often repeated, so that two negatives do not make an affirmative, Attic, οὐκ ἔστιν οὐδὲν κρεῖσσον φίλου Eur.; καθεύδων οὐδεὶς οὐδενὸς ἄξιος οὐδὲν μᾶλλον τοῦ μὴ ζῶντος Plat.; οὐδενὶ οὐδαμῆ οὐδαμῶς οὐδεμίαν κοινωνίαν ἔχει Plat.

PLEONASM OF οὐ: after Verbs of denying, doubting, and disputing, followed by ὡς or ὅτι, οὐ is inserted, where in Engl. the negat. is not required, ἀμφισβητεῖ ὡς οὐ δεῖ δίκην διδόναι Plat. Like this is the appearance of οὐ in the second member of a negative comparative sentence, ἥκει ὁ Πέρσης οὐδέν τι μᾶλλον ἐπʼ ἡμέας ἢ οὐ καὶ ἐπʼ ὑμέας Hdt.
in Poetry, if ἤ stands before οὐ, the two sounds coalesce into one syllable, as in ἢ οὐ, μὴ οὐ.
οὐ in connexion with other Particles will be found in alphabetical order, οὐ γάρ, οὐ μή, etc.

div1.head: οὔπω
div1.sense: not yet, Lat. nondum, opp. to οὐκέτι (no longer, no more), Hom., Hes., etc.
as a stronger form of the negat., not, not at all, σοὶ δʼ οὔ πω θεοὶ κοτέουσιν Il., etc.

div1.head: οὐπώποτε
div1.sense: never yet at any time, Hom., Attic

div1.head: οὔπως
div1.sense: οὔ πως, no-how, in no wise, not at all, Il., etc.

div1.head: οὐραγία
div1.sense: the rear, Polyb.

div1.head: οὐραγός
div1.sense: leader of the rear-guard, Xen.

div1.head: οὐραῖος
div1.sense: of the tail, τρίχες οὐραῖαι Il.: —generally, hindmost, οὐρ. πόδες the hind- feet, Theocr.; cf. οὐραία.
οὐραῖον, ου, the tail, in pl., οὐραῖα the hinder part, rear, Eur., Luc.

div1.head: Οὐρανία
div1.sense: Urania, the heavenly one, one of the Muses, Hes.
name of Aphrodite, Plat.

div1.head: Οὐρανίδης
div1.sense: son of Uranus, Hes., Pind.: —Οὐρανίδαι the Titans, Hes.

div1.head: οὐράνιος
div1.sense: heavenly, of or in heaven, dwelling in heaven, οὐρ. θεοί Aesch., Eur.; οὐράνιαι alone, the goddesses, Pind.
generally, in or of heaven, ἀστήρ Pind.; πόλος Aesch.; οὐρ. βρέτας fallen from heaven, Eur.; οὐρ. ὕδατα, i. e. rain, Pind.; οὐρ. ἄχος, of a storm, Soph.
reaching to heaven, high as heaven, οὐρ. κίων, of Aetna, Pind.; ἐλάτης οὐράνιος κλάδος Eur.; σκέλος οὐράνιον ἐκλακτίζειν, ῥίπτειν to kick up sky-high, Ar.
metaph. enormous, awful, furious, οὐρ. ἄχη Aesch.; οὐράνιόν γʼ ὅσον, like θαυμάσιον ὅσον, Lat. immane quantum, Ar.: —οὐράνια, as adv. vehemently, Eur.

div1.head: οὐρανίσκος
div1.sense: the vault of a room or tent, a canopy, Plut.

div1.head: Οὐρανίωνες
div1.sense: the heavenly ones, the gods above, Lat. coelites, with or without θεοί, Il.;—also the Titans, as descendants of Uranus, Il.:—fem., θεαὶ Οὐρανιῶναι Anth.

div1.head: οὐρανογνώμων
div1.sense: skilled in the heavens, Luc.

div1.head: οὐρανόδεικτος
div1.sense: shewn from heaven, shewing itself in heaven, Hhymn.

div1.head: οὐρανόθεν
div1.sense: from heaven, down from heaven, Hom., Hes.; properly an old gen. of οὐρανός, and therefore joined with Preps., ἀπʼ οὐρανόθεν Il.; ἐξ οὐρανόθεν Il.

div1.head: οὐρανόθι
div1.sense: adv. in the heavens: but οὐρανόθι πρό πρὸ οὐρανοῦ, in the front of heaven (cf. οὐρανόθεν), Il.

div1.head: οὐρανομήκης
div1.sense: high as heaven, shooting up to heaven, exceeding high or tall, Od.; δένδρεα Hdt.; λαμπάς Aesch.
metaph. stupendous, Ar.

div1.head: οὐρανός
div1.sense: heaven: in Hom. and Hes.,

the vault or firmament of heaven, the sky, conceived as a concave hemisphere resting on the verge of earth, upborne by the pillars of Atlas, Od., Hes., etc.; conceived to be of solid metal, χάλκεος, πολύχαλκος, σιδήρεος, Hom.: on this vault the sun performed his course, Od.; the stars were fixed upon it, and moved with it, for it was supposed to be always revolving, Il.
heaven, as the seat of the gods, above this skyey vault, the portion of Zeus, Hom.; πύλαι οὐρανοῦ Heavengate, which the Hours lifted and put down like a trapdoor, Il.

in common language, heaven, the sky, Hom., etc.; πρὸς οὐρανὸν βιβάζειν τινά to exalt to heaven, as Hor. evehere ad Deos, Soph.; εἰς τὸν οὐρ. ἥλλοντο leapt up on high, Xen.: a region of heaven, climate, Hdt.
as prop. n. Uranus, son of Erebus and Gaia, Hes.; or husband of Gaia, parent of the Titans, Hes., Aesch.

div1.head: οὐρανοῦχος
div1.sense: holding heaven, ἀρχὴ οὐρ. the rule of heaven, Aesch.

div1.head: οὐρά
div1.sense: the tail, of a lion, dog, etc., Hom., Hdt.

of an army marching, the rear-guard, rear, Xen.; κατʼ οὐράν τινος ἕπεσθαι to follow in his rear, Xen.; ὁ κατʼ οὐράν the rear-rank man, Xen.; ἐπί or κατʼ οὐράν to the rear, backwards, Xen.; ἐπʼ οὐρᾷ in rear, Xen.
ῥήματος οὐρή, i. e. its echo, Anth.

div1.head: οὐρεόφοιτος
div1.sense: mountain haunting, Anth.: fem. -φοιτάς, άδος, Anth.

div1.head: οὐρεσιβώτης
div1.sense: feeding on the mountains, Soph.

div1.head: οὐρεύς
div1.sense: a mule, Il.
= οὖρος a guard, in Il. 10. 84 the sense is uncertain.

div1.head: οὐρέω
div1.sense: to make water, Hes., Hdt.

div1.head: οὐρητιάω
div1.sense: Desiderat. of οὐρέω, to want to make water, Ar.

div1.head: οὐρίαχος
div1.sense: the hindmost part, bottom, ἔγχεος οὐρ. the butt-end of the spear, shod with iron, Il.

div1.head: οὐριβάτης
div1.sense: walking the mountains, Eur.: also ὀριβάτης, Ar.

div1.head: οὐρίζω
div1.sense: to carry with a fair wind, to waft on the way, of words and prayers, Aesch.; κατʼ ὀρθὸν οὐρ. to speed on the way, guide prosperously, Soph.
intr. to blow favourably, Aesch.

div1.head: οὐρίθρεπτος
div1.sense: mountain-bred, Eur.

div1.head: οὔριος
div1.sense: with a fair wind, Lat. vento secundo, οὔρ. πλοῦς, δρόμος a prosperous voyage, Soph.
metaph. prosperous, successful, Aesch., Eur.:—neut. pl. οὔρια as adv., Eur.
prospering, favouring, fair, of winds, Eur., Thuc.; comically of the bellows, οὐρίᾳ ῥιπίδι Ar.
οὐρία (sc. πνοή) , = οὖρος, a fair wind, οὐρίᾳ ἐφιέναι (sc. ἑαυτόν) to run before the wind, Plat.; so, ἐξ οὐρίων δραμοῦσα (sc. δρόμων) after having run a fair course, Soph.; ἀφήσω ἐμαυτὸν οὔριον Ar.
Ζεὺς οὔριος, as sending fair winds, i. e. conducting things to a happy issue, Aesch., Anth.

div1.head: οὐριοστάτης
div1.sense: steady and prosperous, Aesch.

div1.head: οὐριόω
div1.sense: to give to the winds, Anth.

div1.head: οὔρισμα
div1.sense: a boundary-line, Hdt.

div1.head: οὖρον
div1.sense: urine, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: οὖρον
div1.sense: boundary, used by Hom. in three places, viz., ὅσα δίσκου οὖρα πέλονται as far as is the limit or space of a quoitʼs throw (cf. δίσκουρα) , Il.; ὅσσον τʼ ἐπὶ οὖρα πέλονται ἡμιόνων as far as is the range of mules (in ploughing), Il.; and so, more fully ὅσσον τʼ οὖρον πέλει ἡμιόνοιϊν, τόσσον ὑπεκπροθέων Od.: —what the distance expressed by the range of mules may be is uncertain; the common explanation is the length by which mules would distance oxen in ploughing a given space in the same time.

div1.head: οὖρος
div1.sense: a fair wind, Hom., etc.; ἡμῖν δʼ αὖ κατόπισθε νεὼς οὖρον ἵει Od.; πέμψω δέ τοι οὖρον ὄπισθεν Od.; ἂψ δὲ θεοὶ οὖρον στρέψαν the gods changed the wind again to a fair one, Od.; πέμπειν κατʼ οὖρον to send down (i. e. with) the wind, speed on its way, Orac. ap. Hdt.; so, metaph., ἴτω κατʼ οὖρον let it be swept before the wind to ruin, Aesch.; ταῦτα μὲν ῥείτω κατʼ οὖρον let these things drift with the wind, Soph.
οὖρός ἐστι, like καιρός, ʼtis a fair time, Soph.; ἐγένετο τις οὖρος ἐκ κακῶν Eur.

div1.head: οὖρος
div1.sense: a watcher, warder, guardian, Hom., Pind.
div1.etym: From the same Root as ὁράω and ὤρα cura.
div1.head: οὖρος
οὖρος
div1.sense: Lat. urus, a buffalo, Anth.

div1.head: οὐρός
div1.sense: a trench or channel for hauling up ships and launching them again, Il.

div1.head: οὐσία
div1.sense: that which is oneʼs own, oneʼs substance, property, Hdt., Eur.
= τὸ εἶναι, being, existence, Plat.; τὰς ἄπαιδας οὐσίας her childless state, Soph.
the being, essence, nature of a thing, Plat., etc.

div1.head: οὖς
div1.sense: auris, the ear, Hom.; ὀρθὰ ἱστάναι τὰ ὦτα, of horses, Hdt.; βοᾷ ἐν ὠσὶ κέλαδος rings in the ear, Aesch.; φθόγγος βάλλει διʼ ὤτων Soph.; διʼ ὤτων ἦν λόγος, i. e. heard generally, Eur.; εἰς οὖς into the ear, secretly, Eur.; so, εἰς ὦτα φέρειν Soph.:—metaph. of spies, Xen.; —τὰ ὦτα ἐπὶ τῶν ὤμων ἔχοντες, of persons who slink away ashamed (hanging their ears like dogs), Plat.:—athletes are described as having their ears bruised and swollen, τεθλαγμένος οὔατα πυγμαῖς Theocr.
the ear or handle, of pitchers, cups, etc., οὔατα δʼ αὐτοῦ τέσσαρʼ ἔσαν Il.

div1.head: οὐτάζω
div1.sense: to wound, c. dupl. acc., Κυπρίδα οὔτασε χεῖρα wounded Venus on the hand, Il.; also, σάκος οὔτασε pierced the shield, Il.; c. acc. cogn., ἕλκος, ὅ με βροτὸς οὔτασεν ἀνήρ the wound which a man struck me withal, Il.

div1.head: οὐτάω
div1.etym: forms generated as if both from οὐτάω and from οὔτημι.
div1.sense: to wound, hurt, hit with any kind of weapon, οὖτα δὲ δουρί, οὐτ. ἔγχεϊ, χαλκῶι, etc., Il.; properly opp. to βάλλω, to wound by striking or thrusting, Il.; cf. οὐτάζω; κατʼ οὐταμένην ὠτειλήν by the wound inflicted, Il.; τὸ ξίφος διανταίαν πληγήν οὐτᾶι Aesch.
sometimes, generally, to wound, like βάλλω, Eur.

div1.head: οὔτε
div1.sense: and not, Il., Hdt.

mostly repeated, οὔτε . . , οὔτε . . , neither . . , nor . . , Lat. neque . . , neque . . , Hom., etc.: —οὔτε may be foll. by a posit. clause with τε, Lat. neque . . , et . . , οὔτʼ αὐτὸς κτενέει, ἀπό τʼ ἄλλους πάντας ἐρύξει he will both not kill and will defend, Il.:—the former οὔτε is sometimes omitted, ναυσὶ δʼ οὔτε πεζός [neither] by sea nor by land, Pind.

div1.head: οὔτησις
div1.sense: a wounding, Zonar.

div1.head: οὐτήτειρα
div1.sense: she who wounds, Anth.

div1.head: οὐτιδανός
div1.sense: of no account, worthless, Hom.
regardless, reckless, Aesch.

div1.head: οὔτι
div1.sense: not, I suppose . . , surely you do not mean that . . , Pind., Soph., etc.

div1.head: οὔτι πη
div1.sense: in no wise, Hes., Theocr.

div1.head: οὔτι πω
div1.sense: not at all yet, Hdt.

div1.head: Οὖτις
div1.sense: Nobody, Noman, a name assumed by Ulysses to deceive Polyphemus, Od.

div1.head: οὔτις
div1.sense: no one or nobody, Lat. nemo, nullus, neut. nothing, Lat. nihil, Hom., etc.: —οὐδείς being used in Prose.
neut. οὔτι as adv. not a whit, by no means, not at all, Il., Hdt., Attic
as prop. n. with changed accent,

div1.head: οὔτοι
div1.sense: indeed not, Lat. non sane, Hom., Hes., etc.; in Attic before oaths, οὔτοι μὰ τὴν Δήμητρα, μὰ τὸν Ἀπόλλω Ar., etc.

div1.head: οὑτοσί
div1.etym: οὗτος strengthd. by the demonstr. affix -ί [ῑ]
div1.sense: this man here, Lat. hic-ce, Ar. and Attic Prose: after a vowel, γ is often inserted, αὑτηγί for αὑτηΐ γε, ταυταγί for ταυταί γε, etc., Ar.

div1.head: οὗτος
div1.sense: demonstr. Pron. this, Lat. hic, to designate the nearer of two things, opp. to ἐκεῖνος, the more remote (cf. ὅδε) , Hom., etc.
when, of two things, one precedes and the other follows, ὅδε generally refers to what follows, οὗτος to what precedes, Soph., etc.
so also, οὗτος is used emphat., generally in contempt, while ἐκεῖνος (like Lat. ille) denotes praise, ὁ πάντʼ ἄναλκις οὗτος, i. e. Aegisthus, Soph.; οὗτος ἀνήρ Plat.; τούτους τοὺς συκοφάντας Plat.
in Attic law-language, οὗτος is commonly applied to the opponent, whether plaintiff or defendant, whereas in Lat. hic was the client, iste the opponent, Dem.
often much like an adv., in local sense (cf. ὅδε init.), τίς δʼ οὗτος κατὰ νῆας ἔρχεαι; who art thou here that comest . . ? Il.; often in Attic, τίς οὑτοσί; whoʼs this here? Ar.
with Pron. of 2nd pers., οὗτος σύ, Lat. heus tu! ho you! you there! Soph., etc.; and then οὗτος alone like a Vocat., οὗτος, τί ποιεῖς; Aesch.; ὦ οὗτος οὗτος, Οἰδίπους Soph.
this phrase mostly implies anger, impatience, or scorn:—so, οὗτος ἀνήρ for ἐγώ, Od.
καὶ οὗτος is also added to heighten the force of a previous word, ναυτικῷ ἀγῶνι, καὶ τούτῳ πρὸς Ἀθηναίους Thuc.; v. infr. III. 5.
neut. ταῦτα in various phrases,
ταῦτʼ, ὦ δέσποτα yes Sir, (i. e. ταῦτά ἐστι, etc.), Ar.; so ταῦτα δή Ar.
ταῦτα μὲν δὴ ὑπάρξει so it shall be, Plat.
καὶ ταῦτα μὲν δὴ ταῦτα, Lat. haec hactenus, Plat.
διὰ ταῦτα therefore, Attic; πρὸς ταῦτα so then, therefore, Trag.:—also ταῦτα absol., therefore, Il.; ταῦτʼ ἄρα Ar.; ταῦτα δή Aesch.; ταῦτʼ οὖν Soph.

καὶ ταῦτα, adding a circumstance heightening the force of what has been said, and that, Lat. et hoc, ἄνδρα θανεῖν, καὶ ταῦτα πρὸς γυναικός to think that a man should die, and that by a womanʼs hand, Aesch., etc.
τοῦτο μέν . . , τοῦτο δέ . . , on the one hand . . , on the other . . , partly . . , partly. . , Hdt.
dat. fem. ταύτῃ on this spot, here, Soph., etc.
in this point, herein, Ar., etc.
in this way, thus, Trag., etc.
ἐκ τούτου or τούτων, thereupon, Xen.: therefore, Xen.
ἐν τούτῳ herein, so far, Thuc., Plat., etc.
in the meantime, Thuc., Xen.
πρὸς τούτοις besides, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: οὑτωσί
div1.etym: strengthd. for οὕτως v. οὑτοσί, Attic Prose.

div1.head: οὕτως
div1.etym: adverb of οὗτος, as Lat. sic of hic
div1.sense: in this way or manner, so, thus:—properly, οὕτως is antec. to ὡς, as Lat. sic to ut, Hom., etc.; οὕτω δὴ ἔσται so it shall be, ratifying what goes before, Od., etc.:—in Prose οὕτως alone in answers, even so, just so, Xen.
in wishes or prayers, οὕτω νῦν Ζεὺς θείη (as Hor. sic te diva regat), Od.; οὕτως ὀναίμην τῶν τέκνων, μισῶ τὸν ἄνδρα (as in Engl., so help me God), Ar.; οὕτω νομιζοίμην σοφός . . Ar.
beginning a story, οὕτω ποτʼ ἦν μῦς καὶ γαλῆ so once upon a time . . , Ar.; ἦν οὕτω δὴ παῖς Plat.
οὕτως ἔχειν, οὕτως ἔχειν τινός, v. ἔχω B. II. 2; ἔχειν is sometimes omitted, τούτων μὲν οὕτω so much for this, Aesch.
= εἰς τοῦτο, οὕτω τάρβους to such a pitch of terror, Eur.

οὕτω, or οὕτω δή, introduces the apodosis after a protasis, ἐπειδὴ περιελήλυθε ὁ πόλεμος, οὕτω δὴ Γέλωνος μνῆστις γέγονε Hdt.:— after participles, ἐν κλιβάνῳ πνίξαντες, οὕτω τρώγουσι, i. e. ἐπειδὴ ἔπνιξαν, οὕτω . . , Hdt.
inferential Lat. itaque, Soph., Plat.
with an adj. or adv. so, so much, so very, καλὸς οὕτω Il.; πρυμνόθεν οὕτως so entirely, Aesch.

like αὔτως, with a diminishing power, so, merely so, simply, like Lat. sic, μὰψ οὕτως Il.; οὕτω πίνοντας πρὸς ἡδονήν (as Hor. jacentes sic temere), Plat.; also off-hand, at once, Plat.; οὐ .. οὕτως ἄπει impune, Eur.

div1.head: ὀφειλέτης
div1.sense: a debtor, τινί Plat.: ὀφ. εἰμί, c. inf., I am under bond to do a thing, Soph.:—fem. ὀφειλέτις, ιδος, Eur.

div1.head: ὀφείλημα
div1.sense: that which is owed, a debt, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: ὀφειλή
div1.sense: a debt, NTest.:— oneʼs due, NTest.

div1.head: ὀφείλω
div1.sense: to owe, have to pay or account for, Hom., etc.; ὀφ. τινί to be debtor to another, Ar.; absol. to be in debt, Ar.:—Pass. to be owed, to be due, Hom., Attic: of persons, to be liable to, θανάτωι πάντες ὀφειλόμεθα (as Horace debemur morti), Anth.
c. inf. to be bound, to be obliged to do a thing, Il., etc.:—Pass., σοι ταῦτʼ ὀφείλεται παθεῖν it is thy destiny to suffer this, Soph.; πᾶσιν κατθανεῖν ὀφείλεται Eur.
in this sense Epic imperf. ὤφελλον, ὄφελλον and aor2 ὤφελον, ὄφελον are used of that which one ought to have done (ought being the pret. of owe), ὤφελεν εὔχεσθαι Il., etc.

these tenses are also used, foll. by inf., to express a wish that cannot be accomplished, τὴν ὄφελε κατακτάμεν Ἄρτεμις would that Artemis had slain her! (but she had not), Lat. utinam interfecisset! Il.; often preceded by εἴθε (Epic αἴθε) , αἴθʼ ὄφελες ἄγονός τʼ ἔμεναι O that thou hadst been unborn, Il.; αἴθʼ ὤφελλʼ ὁ ξεῖνος ὀλέσθαι Od.; —so with ὡς, ὡς ὄφελον ὤλέσθαι O that I had taken! Il.; ὡς ὤφελες ὀλέσθαι Il.; with negat., μηδʼ ὄφελες λίσσεσθαι would thou hadst never prayed! Il.; so in Attic:—in late Greek with Ind., ὄφελον ἐβασιλεύσατε, for βασιλεῦσαι, would ye were kings, NTest.
impers. ὀφείλει, Lat. oportet, c. acc. et inf., Pind.

div1.head: ὀφέλλω
div1.sense: to increase, enlarge, strengthen, Hom.; ἲς ἀνέμου κύματʼ ὀφέλλει the force of the wind raises high the waves, Il.; μῦθον ὀφ. to multiply words, Il.; ὄφρʼ ἂν Ἀχαιοὶ υἱὸν ἐμὸν τίσωσιν, ὀφέλλωσί τέ ἑ τιμῆι and may advance him in honour, Il.: —Pass., οἶκος ὀφέλλεται it waxes great, prospers, Od.

div1.head: ὄφελος
div1.sense: furtherance, advantage, help, used often (like opus) as an indecl. adj., αἴ κʼ ὄφελός τι γενώμεθα whether we can be of any use, Il.; τί δῆτʼ ἂν εἴης ὄφ. ἡμῖν; what good couldst thou be to us? Ar.; c. inf., τί ὄφ. σώματι κάμνοντι σιτία διδόναι; Plat.; c. gen., τῶν ὄφελός ἐστι οὐδέν of which there is no profit, Hdt.; ὄφ. οὐδὲν γεωργοῦ ἀργοῦ Xen.;—but, ὅ τι περ ὄφελος στρατεύματος the serviceable part of the army, Xen.

div1.head: ὀφεώδης
div1.sense: snake-like, Plat.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμία
div1.sense: ophthalmia, Ar., Xen., etc.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμιάω
div1.sense: to suffer from ophthalmia, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμοδουλεία
div1.sense: eye-service, NTest.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμός
div1.sense: the eye, mostly in pl., Hom., etc.; ἐλθεῖν ἐς ὀφθαλμούς τινος to come before oneʼs eyes, Il.; ἐν ὀφθαλμοῖσιν before oneʼs eyes, Lat. in oculis, Hom., Attic; πρὸ τῶν ὀφθ. Aeschin.; ἐξ ὀφθαλμῶν out of oneʼs sight, Hdt.; κατʼ ὀφθαλμούς to oneʼs face, Ar.

in sg. the eye of a master or ruler, πάντα ἰδὼν Διὸς ὀφθ. Hes.; so a king is called ὀφθ. οἴκων Aesch.; and in Persia ὀφθαλμὸς βασιλέως, the kingʼs eye, was a confidential officer, through whom he beheld his subjects, Hdt., Ar., etc.
ἑσπέρας ὀφθ., νυκτὸς ὀφθ., of the moon, Pind.
the dearest, best, as the eye is the most precious part of the body, ὀφθαλμὸς Σικελίας Pind.; μέγας ὀφθαλμός a great comfort, Soph.
the eye or bud of a plant or tree, Xen.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμότεγκτος
div1.sense: wetting the eyes, Eur.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμοφανής
div1.sense: apparent to the eye, Strab.

div1.head: ὀφθαλμωρύχος
div1.sense: tearing out the eyes, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀφιόπους
div1.sense: with serpents for legs, Luc.

div1.head: ὄφις
div1.sense: a serpent, snake, Il., Hdt., Trag.:—metaph., πτηνὸν ὄφιν, of an arrow, Aesch.
div1.etym: The first syll. is sometimes made long, when it was pronounced (and perh. ought to be written) ὄπφις, v. ὀχέω.

div1.head: ὄφλημα
div1.sense: a fine incurred in a lawsuit, Dem.

div1.head: ὀφλισκάνω
div1.sense: to owe, to be liable to pay a fine, Eur., etc.
δίκην ὀφλεῖν to be cast in a suit, lose oneʼs cause, Ar.; so, ὀφλεῖν δίαιταν to lose in an arbitration, Dem.; τὰς εὐθύνας ὀφλεῖν to have oneʼs accounts not passed, Aeschin.
absol. to be cast, to be the losing party, Ar., Thuc.
c. gen. criminis, ὀφλὼν κλοπῆς δίκην to be convicted in an action for theft, Aesch.; then, without δίκην, ὠφληκὼς φόνου found guilty of murder, Plat.: also c. gen. poenae, θανάτου δίκην ὀφλ. Plat.

generally, of anything which one deserves or brings on oneself, αἰσχύνην, βλάβην ὀφλ. to bring infamy, loss on oneself, incur them, Eur.; ὀφλ. γέλωτα to be laughed at, Eur.; δειλίην ὤφλεε πρὸς βασιλῆος he drew upon himself the reproach of cowardice from the king, Hdt.; so, μωρίαν ὀφλισκάνω Soph.

div1.head: ὄφρα
div1.sense: Final and Temporal Conj. in Ionic and Doric Poets:
Final Conj., like ἵνα, ὡς, that, in order that, to the end that, Hom., Pind.
Temporal Conj., like ἕως, Lat. donec, so long as, while, mostly with imperf., ὄφρα μὲν ἠὼς ἦν Od.
with subj., it commonly has ἄν (κε or κεν) with it, Hom.

until, ὄφρα καὶ αὐτὼ κατέκταθεν till they too were slain, Il.; with subj., of future time, ἔχει κότον, ὄφρα τελέσσηι he bears malice till he have satisfied it, Il.; —but in this case, ἄν (κε or κεν) is commonly added.

div1.head: ὀφρυάω
div1.sense: to have ridges, Strab.

div1.head: ὀφρύη
div1.etym: Ionic for ὀφρύς II, Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: ὀφρυόεις
div1.sense: on the brow of a rock, beetling, Il., ap. Hdt.
metaph. majestic, Anth.

div1.head: ὀφρύς
div1.sense: the brow, eyebrow, Lat. supercilium, mostly in pl., the brows, Hom.; ἐπʼ ὀφρύσι νεῦσε Κρονίων, i. e. ἐπένευσε ὀφρύσι, nodded assent, Il.; ἀνὰ δʼ ὀφρύσι νεῦσεν ἑκάστῳ made a sign not to do, Od.: used in phrases to denote grief, scorn, pride, τὰς ὀφρῦς ἀνασπᾶν Ar.; ὀφρῦς ἐπαίρειν Eur., etc.; τὰς ὀφρῦς συνάγειν to knit the brows, frown, Ar.:—on the other hand, καταβάλλειν, λύειν, μεθιέναι τὰς ὀφρῦς to let down or unknit the brow, Eur.
ὀφρύς alone, like Lat. supercilium, scorn, pride, Anth.
the brow of a hill, a beetling crag, Il., etc.

div1.head: ὄχανον
div1.sense: the holder of a shield, a bar across the hollow of the shield, through which the bearer passed his arm, Hdt.

div1.head: ὄχα
div1.sense: adv., used to strengthen the Sup. ἄριστος, ὄχʼ ἄριστος far the best, Il., etc.

div1.head: ὀχεία
div1.sense: a covering or impregnating, of the male animal, Xen.

div1.head: ὀχετεύω
div1.sense: to conduct water by a conduit or canal, Hdt.:—Pass. to be conducted, conveyed, Hdt.; metaph., ὠχετεύετο φάτις Aesch.

div1.head: ὀχετηγός
div1.sense: conducting or drawing off water by a ditch or conduit, Il.: metaph., πνεῦμα ὀχ., of the flute, Anth.

div1.head: ὀχετός
div1.sense: a means for carrying water, a water-pipe, Hdt., Thuc., etc.: a conduit, channel, aqueduct, Arist.
in pl. streams, Pind., Eur.
metaph., ὀχετὸν παρεκτρέπειν to make a side channel or means of escape, Eur.

div1.head: ὀχεύς
div1.sense: anything for holding or fastening:
a strap for fastening the helmet under the chin, Il.
in pl. the fastenings of the belt, Il.
a bar to fasten the door inside, Hom.

div1.head: ὀχεύω
div1.sense: of male animals, to cover, Plat.: Pass., of the female: Mid. of both sexes, Hdt.

div1.head: ὀχέω
div1.sense: frequent. of ἔχω to uphold, sustain, endure, Od., Pind.; νηπιάας ὀχέειν to keep playing childish tricks, Od.; φρουρὰν ὀχήσω will maintain a watch, Aesch.
to carry, Eur., Xen.
to let another ride, to mount him, αὐτὸς βαδίζω, τοῦτον δʼ ὀχῶ Ar.; of a general, to let the men ride, Xen.
Mid. to have oneself carried, to be carried or borne, Hom., Hdt., Attic
absol. (without the dat. ἵππωι or νηί), to drive, ride, sail, [ἵπποι ἀλεγεινοὶ ὀχέεσθαι difficult to use in a chariot, Il.

of a ship, to ride at anchor, λεπτή τις ἐλπίς ἐστʼ ἐφʼ ἧς ὀχούμεθα ʼtis but a slender hope on which we ride at anchor, Ar.; so, ὠχεῖσθʼ Ar.; cf. Plat.; so, ἐπʼ ἀσθενοῦς ῥώμης ὀχεῖσθαι Eur. [In Pind. the first syll. is made long, when it was pronounced (and perh. ought to be written) ὀκχέω, v. ὄφις.

div1.head: ὄχημα
div1.sense: anything that bears or supports, γῆς ὄχημα, stay of earth, = γαιήοχος, Eur.
a carriage, a chariot, Lat. vehiculum, Hdt., Soph., Eur.
of ships, but mostly with some addition, λινόπτερα ναυτίλων ὄχ. Aesch.; ὄχ. ναός Soph.
of animals that are ridden, ὄχημα κανθάρου a riding beetle (as we say a riding-horse), Ar.

div1.head: ὄχησις
div1.sense: a bearing, carrying, Plat.
(from Pass.) a being carried, ἵππων ὀχήσεις riding, Plat.

div1.head: ὀχθέω
div1.sense: to be sorely angered, to be vexed in spirit, Hom.

div1.head: ὄχθη
div1.sense: older form of ὄχθος, a rising ground, a bank, dyke by the side of a river, Il.: mostly in pl. the raised banks of a river, Hom.; ὄχθαι καπέτοιο the banks of the trench, Il.; also the dunes or denes along the sea (cf. θίς) , Od.

div1.head: ὀχθηρός
div1.sense: hilly, Anth.

div1.head: ὄχθος
div1.sense: a bank, hill, Hhymn., Hdt., Attic: a barrow or mound, Lat. tumulus, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀχλαγωγία
div1.sense: mob-oratory, Plut.

div1.head: ὀχλέω
div1.sense: to move, disturb, ψηφῖδες ἅπασαι ὀχλεῦνται (Ionic for -οῦνται) all the pebbles are rolled or swept away by the water, Il.
to trouble, importune, Hdt., Aesch.:—absol. to be troublesome or irksome, Soph.

div1.head: ὀχληρός
div1.sense: troublesome, irksome, importunate, Hdt., Eur., Plat.

div1.head: ὀχλίζω
div1.sense: to move by a lever, to heave up, τὸν λᾶαν οὔ κε δύʼ ἀνέρε ὀχλίσσειαν Hom.

div1.head: ὀχλοκόπος
div1.sense: a mob-courtier, Polyb.; cf. δημο-κόπος.

div1.head: ὀχλοκρατία
div1.sense: mob-rule, the lowest grade of democracy, Polyb.

div1.head: ὀχλοποιέω
div1.sense: to make a riot, NTest.

div1.head: ὄχλος
div1.sense: a moving crowd, a throng, mob, Pind., Aesch., etc.; ὁ ὄχλος τῶν στρατιωτῶν the mass of the soldiers, Xen.; τῷ ὄχλῳ in point of numbers, Thuc.; οἱ τοιοῦτοι ὄχλοι undisciplined masses like these, Thuc.
in political sense, the populace, mob, Lat. turba, opp. to δῆμος, Thuc., Xen.
generally, a mass, multitude, ὄχλος λόγων Aesch.
like Lat. turba, annoyance, trouble, ὄχλον παρέχειν τινί to give one trouble, Hdt.; διʼ ὄχλου εἶναι, γενέσθαι to be or become troublesome, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: ὀχλώδης
div1.sense: like a mob, and so,
turbulent, unruly, Plat.; τὸ ὀχλ. troublesomeness, Thuc.
common, vulgar, Plut.

div1.head: ὀχμάζω
div1.sense: to grip fast, Eur.; τὸν λεωργὸν ὀχμάσαι to bind him fast, Aesch.; ἵππον ὀχμάζει he makes the horse obedient to the bit, Eur.

div1.head: ὄχνη
div1.sense: a wild pear, Theocr.

div1.head: ὄχος
div1.sense: anything which bears, a carriage, Lat. vehiculum, Hdt., Aesch., etc.; by Hom. in heterocl. neut. pl. ὄχεα, ων, τά, of a single chariot, ἐξ ὀχέων Il.; and in poet. dat. ὄχεσφι, -φιν, Il.; later in masc. pl. ἐπʼ εὐκύκλοις ὄχοις, of the Scythian waggons, Aesch.
τροχαλοὶ ὄχοι ἀπήνης the swift-running bearers of the chariot, i.e. the wheels, Eur.
anything which holds, νηῶν ὄχοι steads for ships, harbours, Od.

div1.head: ὀχυροποιέομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to make secure, fortify, Polyb.

div1.head: ὀχυρός
div1.sense: like ἐχυρός, firm, lasting, stout, Hes., Aesch.
of places, strong, secure, Eur.: esp. of a stronghold or position, strong, tenable, Xen.
adv. -ρῶς, Eur.

div1.head: ὀχυρόω
div1.sense: to make fast and sure, fortify, Polyb.: —the Mid. just like Act., Xen.

div1.head: ὀχύρωμα
div1.sense: a stronghold, fortress, Xen.

div1.head: ὀχυρωτέος
div1.sense: one must strengthen, Plut.

div1.head: ὀψαμάτης
div1.note: ὀψ-ᾱμάτης, voc. -ᾶτα, Doric for -αμήτης, ου, ὁ,
div1.sense: one who mows till late at even, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀψαρότης
div1.sense: one who ploughs late, Hes.

div1.head: ὀψείω
div1.sense: Desiderat. of ὁράω, to wish to see a thing, c. gen., Il.

div1.head: ὀψέ
div1.sense: after a long time, late, Lat. sero, Hom., etc.; ὀψὲ διδάσκεσθαι or μανθάνειν to be late in learning, learn too late, Aesch., Soph.
late in the day, at even, opp. to πρωί, Hom., Thuc., etc.; ὀψὲ ἦν, ὀψὲ ἐγίγνετο it was, it was getting, late, Xen.; so, ἐς ὀψέ Thuc.
c. gen., ὀψὲ τῆς ἡμέρας late in the day, Livyʼs serum diei, Thuc.; so, τῆς ὥρας ἐγίγνετο ὀψέ Dem.; ὀψὲ τῆς ἡλικίας late in life, Luc.

div1.head: ὀψία
div1.sense: ὀψία (sc. ὥρα) the latter part of day, evening, opp. to ὄρθρος, often also joined with δείλη, δείλη ἦν ὀψίη Hdt.; περὶ δείλην ὀψίαν Thuc.; δείλης ὀψίας late in the evening, Dem. Cf. δείλη.

div1.head: ὀψίγονος
div1.sense: late-born, after-born, Hom.
of a son, late-born, born in oneʼs old age, Hhymn.
later-born, i. e. younger, Hdt.: young, Theocr.

div1.head: ὀψίζω
div1.sense: to do, go or come late, Xen.:— Pass., ὀψισθέντες belated, benighted, Xen.

div1.head: ὀψίκοιτος
div1.sense: going late to bed, Aesch.

div1.head: ὀψιμαθέω
div1.sense: to learn late, Luc.

div1.head: ὀψιμαθής
div1.sense: late in learning, late to learn, Hor.ʼs serus studiorum, Plat.:— too old to learn, c. gen., Xen.
vain of late-gotten learning, pedantic, Theophr.

div1.head: ὀψιμαθία
div1.sense: late-gotten learning, Theophr.

div1.head: ὄψιμος
div1.sense: late, slow, τέρας ὄψ. a prognostic late of fulfilment, Il.:— late in the season, Xen., NTest.

div1.head: ὀψίνοος
div1.sense: late-observing, of Epimetheus, Pind.

div1.head: ὄψιος
div1.sense: late, Lat. serus, Pind.: Attic comp. ὀψιαίτερος, η, ον, earlier; Sup. ὀψιαίτατος, η, ον, earliest, Xen.:—neut. ὀψιαίτερον as adv., comp. of ὀψέ, Plat.; Sup. ὀψιαίτατα Plat., Xen.

div1.head: ὄψις
div1.sense: look, appearance, aspect of a person or thing, Lat. species oris, aspectus, Il., Soph.; εἰκάζεσθαι ἀπὸ τῆς φανερᾶς ὄψεως Thuc.:—acc. absol. in appearance, Pind., Attic
the countenance, face, Eur., etc.
= θέαμα, a sight, Aesch., Eur., etc.; ἄλλην ὄψιν οἰκοδομημάτων other architectural sights, Hdt.; τῇ ὄψει from what they saw, opp. to τῇ γνώμῃ, Thuc.
a vision, apparition, Hdt., Trag.
eyesight, vision, Hom., Hdt., Attic: in pl. the organs of sight, the eyes, Soph., Xen.
view, sight, Lat. conspectus, ἀπικέσθαι ἐς ὄψιν τινί to come into oneʼs sight, i. e. presence, Hdt.; εἰς ὄψιν τινός or τινὶ ἥκειν, μολεῖν, ἐλθεῖν, περᾶν Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ὀψιτέλεστος
div1.sense: to be late fulfilled, Il.

div1.head: ὄψον
div1.sense: properly, cooked meat, or, generally, meat, opp. to bread and other provisions, Hom., Ar.
anything eaten with bread or food, to give it flavour and relish, κρόμυον, ποτῷ ὄψον onions, a zest or relish to wine, Il.; ἐσθίουσι ἐπὶ τῷ σίτῳ ὄψον Xen.
seasoning, sauce, Plat.; κολλύραν καὶ κόνδυλον ὄψον ἐπʼ αὐτῇ pudding and knuckle- sauce withal, Ar.; λιμῷ ὅσαπερ ὄψῳ διαχρῆσθε, i. e. "hunger is the best sauce," Xen.
generally, dainty fare, in pl. dainties, Plat.
at Athens, mostly, fish, the chief dainty of the Athenians, Ar.
the fish-market, Ar., Aeschin.

div1.head: ὀψοποιέω
div1.sense: to eat meat or fish with bread, Xen.

div1.head: ὀψοποιητικός
div1.sense: of or fit for cookery: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) the art of cookery, Arist.

div1.head: ὀψοποιία
div1.sense: cookery, esp. fine cookery, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: ὀψοποιός
div1.sense: one who cooks meat, a cook, Hdt.; distinguished from ἀρτοποιός and σιτοποιός, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: ὀψοπόνος
div1.sense: dressing food elaborately, Anth.

div1.head: ὀψοφαγέω
div1.sense: to eat things meant to be eaten only with bread, to live daintily, Ar.

div1.head: ὀψοφαγία
div1.sense: dainty living, Aeschin.

div1.head: ὀψοφάγος
div1.sense: one who eats things meant to be only eaten with bread, such as fish and dainties, a dainty fellow, epicure, gourmand, Ar., Xen.:— irreg. Sup. ὀψοφαγίστατος Xen.

div1.head: ὄψ
div1.etym: only used in obl. cases of sg. ὀπός, ὀπί, ὄπα
div1.sense: a voice, Hom., Hes., Trag.; of flutes, Theogn.
a word, Il., Soph.

div1.head: ὀψωνέω
div1.sense: to buy fish and dainties, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: ὀψώνης
div1.sense: one who buys fish or victuals, a purveyor, Ar.

div1.head: ὀψωνιασμός
div1.sense: a furnishing with provisions, the supplies and pay of an army, Polyb.

div1.head: ὀψώνιον
div1.sense: provisions or provision-money, Lat. obsonium, supplies and pay for an army, Polyb.: —metaph., ὀψώνια ἁμαρτίας the wages of sin, NTest.
